title: UK’s October heatwave finally set to come to an end this week
lead: Temperatures have reached 26°C during an unusually hot October so far, but the scorching conditions look set to come to an end, according to forecasters
author: Jason Arunn Murugesu

body.text: The UK’s unseasonably warm October is likely to come to an end this week.

Last Sunday saw the warmest October day in the UK for the past five years, according to the , with temperatures hitting 25.8°C in Kew Gardens in west London. The average temperature in the city during October is around 17°C.
But the mini-heatwave is likely to come to an end this week, forecasters have said, as heavy rain is expected to sweep in from Wednesday morning.
Wales and parts of central and southern England are expected to see heavy rain on Wednesday. Conditions will be brighter on the south coast but temperatures are not expected to rise above 20°C.
In Scotland and the north of England, showers will become more frequent and heavier as the week goes on and some Scottish mountains can expect snow, the Met Office added.
Daytime temperatures in southern England will be potentially almost 10°C colder than the start of the week by the weekend, with thermometers not expected to climb above 17°C.

Met Office deputy chief meteorologist Brent Walker said: “As we head through [to the] second half of this week cold air will push southwards across the country and there is a risk that showers over mountains of Scotland could turn wintry.”
“By the weekend we expect all regions of the UK to be in the cold air mass and overnight frosts are possible,” he said.
While the temperatures did not reach the October record of 29.9°C recorded in 2011, the Met Office said this month’s warm weather was unusual for this time of year.

title: Half of British public think the Government is failing to provide access to safe water
lead: Experts have predicted that the UK is likely to face water shortages from the 2030s onwards due to climate change
author: Lucie Heath

body.text: Nearly half of the public think the Government is failing in its responsibility to maintain access to safe, usable , polling has found.

Research by the cross-party think-tank Demos, shared exclusively with i, has revealed a growing concern amongst the British public in relation to water access, as experts warn the UK will increasingly experience water shortages due to .

A survey of 1,267 adults found just 4 per cent felt the Government was fully meeting its responsibility to maintain access to safe, usable water, while 48 per cent think the Government is either not really meeting its responsibility or not meeting its responsibility at all.
One in five people (19 per cent) said they were worried about  affecting their household in the future.
was highlighted as a main concern, with 70 per cent of those surveyed answering that the UK was either  or was at risk of drought over the next decade.
Andrew O’Brien, Demos director of policy and impact, said the research shows the public is becoming “increasingly aware of the risks that are facing our country in keeping the taps flowing”.
The  (CCC), which advises the Government on climate, has previously found that UK water companies will likely be unable to meet water demand in some areas from the 2030s.
Its research found that 27 of the 133 water resource zones in England and Wales will have a supply-demand deficit of greater than five million litres per day by this period.

The has estimated the amount of water available in the UK by 2050 could be reduced by 10-15 per cent due to climate change, while the UK’s population is projected to continue rising by over four million over the same period.
“There seems to be a disconnect between the level of importance placed on this by the public and the steps that the UK is taking to deal with the risks,” Mr O’Brien said.

“We are rapidly running out of time to increase our water resilience. We need policymakers, the water industry, business and the public to work together to develop a comprehensive approach to tackling this issue and avoiding an unnecessary water crisis in the years ahead.”
Last week,  on water infrastructure projects, raising bills by an average of £156 per year to meet these costs.
However, doubts have been raised over the companies’ ability to meet their investment pledges after the water regular, Ofwat, revealed  in investment funding allocated for the 2020-23 period.

A Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs spokesperson said: “We have one of the safest and purest water supplies in the world. Customers are much less likely to suffer from supply interruptions than before privatisation of water companies, which are required to carry out regular risk assessments and sampling to make sure that drinking water supplies remain safe and plentiful.

“We have also set out an ambitious programme of activities to improve water resilience in our Environment Improvement Plan and Plan for Water, which sets out more investment, stronger regulation and tougher enforcement to tackle and clean up our water environments.”

title: How flooding due to climate change is wrecking the UK’s football pitches – with grassroots teams most affected
lead: Awareness of the problems being caused by climate change is growing but not nearly enough action is being taken to tackle the problem, experts warn
author: Tom Bawden

body.text: football club in Bristol has to call off so many games due to that teams often have to play three matches a week towards the end of the season to catch up.
The club, set up in 1966 and home to more than ten youth and adult teams, frequently suffers from waterlogged pitches in the autumn and winter.
And in the summer it can be hit by rock hard, largely grass-free surfaces as replace intense rainfall.
This means that anything from a third to a half of fixtures have to be postponed in a season, according to club chairman Jamie Andrews-Britton.
He says the situation has deteriorated significantly since he joined the club 16 years ago, when he estimates around 10 per cent of games were postponed, as has made weather ever more extreme.

“It’s getting worse because you get such a substantial amount of in such a short time these days. Before, a game would probably be called off if you had two weeks worth of rain. But now you might only get a day’s worth of rain and that’s it, everything’s called off,” he told i.

“We’re not on a flood plain but we’re certainly on a wet plain. We had a really good drainage system put in when we were built but the subsoil on top of it wasn’t so great – it was backfilled from the building site so the drainage has been a bit of a disaster,” he said.

While Bromley Heath is being hit particularly hard by  it is far from alone, with the Football Association estimating that about 150,000 grassroots games a year are cancelled in the UK due to poor pitches, with most of the cancellations occurring after bad weather.

There is not yet enough data to know how the number of football matches cancelled in the UK due to climate change-induced extreme weather has changed over time, but there is a growing body of anecdotal evidence that .
At the same time, there are many scientific studies saying that extreme weather is increasing – and that this is as a result of climate change.
A  estimates there are 40,000 amateur football teams in the UK, which have an average of 5.4 games postponed or cancelled a year.

by the Sport and Recreation Alliance, back in 2014, found that more than a third of grassroots teams lose two to three months of playing time a season due to the weather. And the situation has deteriorated since then, experts say.

“Today, we’re witnessing undeniable impacts of climate change on football, with the grassroots and women’s game being impacted the most. And things are getting worse,” said Elliot Arthur-Worsop, founder of Football For Future, a charity set up to make football sustainable that has worked with Tottenham Hotspur, Chelsea FC, and Fifa, the international governing body of football.
“The frequency and intensity of extreme weather events, like flooding, and continue to disrupt matches across the UK annually, impacting the social and physical wellbeing of players,” he said.

The experience of footballers on the ground tallies with Met Office data about the UK’s changing weather.“The UK has experienced unprecedented rainfall events in recent years, and since 1998 the UK has seen six of the ten wettest years on record,” said Met Office science fellow Elizabeth Kendon.

“have shown that some recent heavy rainfall events in the UK associated with flooding can be linked to human-caused climate change. Events such as the wettest February on record in 2020, or the record-breaking rainfall seen on 3 October, 2020, are expected to become more frequent by 2100 due to climate change,” she said.
Tadcaster Albion, a semi-professional club based near the banks of the River Wharf in North Yorkshire, is a club that has been hit much harder than most by extreme weather.
Andy Charlesworth, a director at the club, said game cancellations have “doubled if not tripled” in the past decade.

“It can be an absolute nightmare. It’s always flooded and it’s just that over the last few years it’s been more frequent and it’s been to a larger degree with a greater intensity of rain and depth of flood water, which has caused significant problems,” he said.
While grassroots teams are worst affected by climate change because they have less money to deal with it, professional clubs are also at risk – especially those outside the Premier League.

A new report from the Zurich UK insurance group found that football faces severe disruption from climate change as increasing cases of flooding, windstorms and drought threaten to disrupt or postpone matches on a regular basis.

It predicts that one in five of England’s 92 professional football club grounds will be at “high to very high” risk of severe flooding by 2050 unless they take significant action – meaning they could see floodwater more that half a metre high “multiple times a decade or even per year”.
Lower league and amateur sides, in particular, face risks as many lack the pitch maintenance budgets of bigger clubs, the report warns – as are clubs involved in other sports.
Grimsby Town, which plays at Blundell Park less than 200 metres from the North Sea, is based in the most at-risk location, with high risk of flooding and heavy rain.
It is followed by Lincoln City and Norwich City – with Leeds United, Huddersfield Town, Leicester City and Blackburn Rovers all high in the climate change league.
Crystal Palace is the sole Premier League club to make the top 20, with the risk of strong windstorms putting it at number 14 in the table.

Overall, the report, based on climate modelling, found that 42 per cent of England’s professional football clubs face heightened risk of severe disruption from severe floods, torrential rain, droughts and windstorms over the next 30 years.
These extreme weather events could damage stadiums, lead to flash flooding and water-logged pitches and disrupt or cancel matches if the sport fails to adapt, the report warns.

The analysis does not factor in any actions that may have been taken by clubs or local authorities to protect against climate hazards, such as flood defences, although it is thought that, by and large, very little action has been taken.

“When you walk into a ground can you see temporary flood barriers that could be slotted into place? I’ve yet to see any. From a visual perspective, I think most clubs are really relying on what the town’s infrastructure has in place. There’s no visual indication that clubs are taking floods seriously in protecting their locations,” said Kumu Kumar, head of Zurich Resilience Solutions UK.

Garry Nelson, a former professional footballer who made more than 750 first team appearances for clubs, including Charlton, Brighton and Plymouth, said: “Ask any player what conditions they dislike most and strong winds will be the universal answer. Quality of play is always diminished, the spectacle in the stadium and for the live TV audience is reduced, and results can hinge on a weather-related incident, rather than a sublime piece of skill. Intense rainfall also poses a threat to matches, impacting the flow of the game and heightening the risk of injury to players.”
Although the report only looked at professional English football clubs, the authors said the findings also broadly applied to amateur clubs – and to venues for other kinds of venues – across the UK.

author of The Ball Is Round: A Global History of Football and The Game of Our Lives: The Meaning and Making of English Football said climate change is “a big threat” to football that is hardly being addressed.
“We are focusing a little bit on the top end but the huge bottom of the pyramid is just not being looked at at all,” he said.
It is the job of many organisations to tackle climate change in football – such as local authorities, the  and the clubs themselves, he argues.

But the Football Association, in particular, needs to do more to highlight and tackle the threat and lead the process, as it represents tens of thousands of clubs around the UK, giving it the best national platform for the sport, he argues.

A spokesperson for the Football Association (FA) said: “The climate crisis presents one of the most pressing issues of our time, and we are determined to play our part in inspiring positive and meaningful change. In July, we launched our new five-year , which sets out our clear ambition to make a positive impact on the environment and the communities that we serve.

“Across grassroots football, our ambition is to transform grass pitch quality in England to improve player experience and withstand adverse weather conditions. We currently support around 6,000 pitches through the Football Foundation Grass Pitch Maintenance Fund to help clubs, towns and parish councils, and school sites across the country to improve, maintain and manage their pitches – and we would encourage anyone eligible for this fund to come forward.”

As part of the programme, clubs, schools, and town and parish councils have free access to PitchPower, the Football Foundation’s innovative digital assessment tool to understand the current state of play with a grassroots pitch.

Following this assessment, each site will receive a recommended maintenance programme to get the pitches in a good condition, alongside some funding to implement the new maintenance programme, the FA explains.

Grants for machinery and equipment are also available and easy to apply for, such as tractors, irrigation and maintenance tools, and includes new and innovative robotic mowers which help to cut the grass more regularly and save volunteer time.
i approached Grimsby Town, Lincoln City, Norwich City, Newport County, Leicester City, Blackburn Rovers, Huddersfield Town, AFC Wimbledon, Wigan Athletic, Crystal Palace and Morecambe for comment.

Damian Froggatt, director of operations at Lincoln City, said: “features high on the club’s agenda and over recent years the club has already invested significant sums into a range of environmental and infrastructure projects, all designed to help reduce our carbon footprint as part of our long term climate action strategy.

“We are also members of the Lincoln Climate Commission, are fully signed up to the EFL Green Club sustainability programme, and are committed to working with all our partners to reduce our carbon footprint.

title: The news is full of bedbug horror – here’s how worried you should really be
lead: Nobody likes their house, let alone their bed, to be the home of blood-sucking insects
author: Stuart Ritchie

body.text: City of Lights? More like City of Bites. According to reports this week, . They’ve been spotted in hotels, homes, and even on the subway.
Bedbugs , but they can ruin your sleep and fill you with anxiety – nobody likes their house, let alone their bed, to be the home of blood-sucking insects.

Bedbugs are much more common now than they were just a few decades ago. A big part of the story, as in so many epidemics and pandemics, is mobility: people travel around the world more, and take germs and pests with them.

It’s possible that it really is worse this year. But all rates of pest infestations are likely to fluctuate from year to year, due to random chance: Paris could simply be at an unlucky peak of a bedbug spike right now for no specific reason. You have to remember that bedbugs are pretty common anyway.

When people become aware of something they start to notice it everywhere: the so-called “”. Now that the word is out that there’s a bedbug problem, people’s expectations, or a higher propensity to report seeing bedbugs, might be part of it.

Much of the anxiety is due to the Olympics, which are coming to Paris next year. But since the Opening Ceremony isn’t until July 2024, it’s possible that people will have forgotten all about it before then.
As mentioned above, mobility is a big driver of bedbug infestations. This means that, yes, there is a strong risk of the .

But this isn’t like the first COVID infections arriving on our shores in early 2020: we already have a thriving population of bedbugs of our own. As Professor James Logan, an entomologist at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine , it’s just as likely that British bedbugs are hitching a ride to Paris as the other way around.
Eurostar have said that they would  to disinfect their trains: but then, what do you expect them to say?

As with so many similar problems, those with less are affected more. Way back in the 15th century, a  observed that bed bugs afflicted the poor more than the rich: “They infest both the chambers of rich and poor, but are more troublesome to the poor… For they do not breed in beds of which the linen and straw is frequently changed…”.

That’s no less the case nowadays. A  of data from Chicago found that bedbug infestations were “strongly associated with income [that is, those with lower incomes had more bed bugs], eviction rates, and overcrowding”. There’s no reason to think it’s any different in Paris, or indeed the UK.

At one point, we almost did. Up until the Second World War, bedbugs were everywhere: some estimates say a third of the population of London were affected in 1930; the advent of central heating at the beginning of the 20th Century had helped to increase their numbers.

Then came DDT. The pesticide (full name ) became available for household use in the 1940s and was much more effective against bedbugs than , which included dusting bedclothes with mercury, soaking sheets in petrol, or fumigating rooms with hydrogen cyanide.
DDT decimated the bedbug population – to the point where scientists in the 1950s  to find any of the bugs to study.

In a word: evolution. Just like viruses adapt to escape vaccines and bacteria adapt to resist antibiotics, bedbugs evolved resistance to DDT over time. It’s a  of natural selection: the bugs carrying genetic mutations that helped them survive against DDT tended to reproduce more often, and over time this left us with huge populations of DDT-resistant creatures.
It’s not just that DDT is now banned in most countries: even if we tried using it on bed bugs, it would no longer work.

There are other insecticides that still work – but experts recommend never relying on just one, because this can help spur the evolution of resistance. Many people  with bedbug pesticides. Some pest-control companies use heat treatment rather than chemicals for these reasons.
What to do:
If you’re worried about bed bugs, following well-worn behavioural advice, like above, is your best bet.

title: Record-breaking heat in September stuns scientists – the numbers explained
lead: According to the Met Office, September’s record-breaking temperatures would be ‘virtually impossible’ without climate change
author: Lucie Heath

body.text: Last month was , with global temperatures experiencing the largest annual jump ever seen.
Scientists have been astounded by the latest global temperature figures, which confirm that 2023 is on track to be the warmest year in our history.
The record-breaking September follows the hottest July and hottest August ever recorded. The extreme weather has brought  to much of the planet.
Here’s the summer of extreme heat in numbers:
Latest  has confirmed that September 2023 surpassed the previous warmest September on record (2020) by 0.5°C, the largest annual jump in temperature ever recorded.
September 2023 was 0.93°C warmer than the 1991-2020 average for the month, while the mean European temperature was 2.51°C higher than the 1991-2020 average.

The UK experienced a record-breaking heatwave in September this year with the country recording seven consecutive days of temperatures above 30°C. This surpassed the previous longest runs of five days in September 1929 and 1911.
The month was the, according to the Met Office, with the mean temperature of 15.2°C on level with 2006’s record figure.
The latest global temperature figures have alarmed scientists. Zeke Hausfather, a scientist at the Berkeley Earth climate data project, called the data “absolutely gobsmackingly bananas”.

The first global temperature data is in for the full month of September. This month was, in my professional opinion as a climate scientist – absolutely gobsmackingly bananas. JRA-55 beat the prior monthly record by over 0.5C, and was around 1.8C warmer than preindutrial levels.
Samantha Burgess, deputy director of the EU’s Copernicus Climate Change Service, said the “unprecedented temperatures” have broken records by an “extraordinary amount”.

She added: “This extreme month has pushed 2023 into the dubious honour of first place – on track to be the warmest year and around 1.4°C above preindustrial average temperatures. Two months out from COP28 – the sense of urgency for ambitious climate action has never been more critical.”

According to a Met Office study, which looks at the likelihood of temperature thresholds being reached in climates with and without human emissions of greenhouse gasses, September’s temperatures in the UK would have been “virtually impossible” without .

Global temperatures have risen around 1.1°C since the industrial revolution. As a result, the Met Office study found there is now a 3 per cent chance of mean September temperatures hitting the same level as we saw in the UK this year.

Met Office Senior Scientist Jennifer Pirret said: “While a 3 per cent chance of these September temperatures occurring in the current climate might seem like a small amount, in a pre-industrial climate these temperatures would have been nearly impossible for the UK in September. It shows how climate change is moving the dial on mean temperatures.”

She added: “As global temperatures continue to rise as a result of human greenhouse gas emissions, we expect these chances to increase over the coming decades, though the natural year-to-year variability of the UK climate will obviously continue to play a role.”
The record-breaking September follows the hottest July and August in living memory.
July 2023 currently holds the record for the hottest ever month in living memory, following a month that saw many countries hit with extreme heatwaves and wildfires.
Local temperature records ; 48°C was recorded in Sardinia, while Algeria and Tunisia reported temperatures as high as 49°C.
All-time temperature records higher than 37°C were recorded close to the Arctic Circle at two sites in the Canadian Northwest Territories, while China reported its highest ever temperature of 52.2°C.
Meanwhile, August 2023 now holds the record for the second warmest month on record.

title: Sycamore Gap: Dozens of UK’s oldest trees ‘at risk of being felled’ as vandalism hunt continues
lead: The Woodland Trust has warned that a lack of legal protections for ancient trees means many are routinely felled or at risk of destruction and safeguards similar to those applied to historic buildings are urgently needed
author: Cahal Milmo

body.text: Campaigners have warned that dozens of ancient trees across the United Kingdom are at risk of being felled as police made a new arrest in the hunt for those responsible for the “sickening” destruction of a abutting Hadrian’s Wall.

The Woodland Trust said the chopping down of the Sycamore Gap tree in Northumberland under cover of darkness on Wednesday represented an “irreplaceable loss” for both the region and the UK as a whole – but it also warned that many similarly venerable trees are being lost, often to legal felling.
Northumbria Police said a man in his 60s was arrested on Friday evening in connection with the felling of the tree and he remains in police custody assisting officers with inquiries.

A 16-year-old boy arrested on suspicion of causing criminal damage in connection with the vandalism at Sycamore Gap was released on police bail on Friday as officers appealed for further information after the tree was cut down using a chain saw, causing a wave of revulsion across the country.

Experts suggested that the sycamore, once voted Britain’s favourite tree and a decades-old  for visitors drawn to its beguiling setting in a dip along a section of Hadrian’s Wall, could yet take on a new form by . Arboriculturists said the process could nonetheless take decades and is unlikely to result in a tree of similar shape and stature to its predecessor.

Conservationists said that the attack on the Sycamore Gap tree proved the difficulties in protecting trees from single acts of violence. But they also warn that similarly ancient or veteran trees are being lost from across the British landscape because of what they argue is a failure to extend the sort of protections that exist for the UK’s built heritage to its oldest and most precious trees.

The Woodland Trust said the absence of such legal safeguards for the UK’s oldest trees – some of which may be as ancient as 3,000 years of age – means they are being routinely, and more often than not legally, felled.

The conservation body pointed to the case of the Cubbington Pear tree, a 250-year-old fruit tree in Warwickshire thought to be the second-largest in Britain, which was cut down to make way for HS2 in 2021. Other natural landmarks under threat include the Darwin Oak, a 500-year-old oak that is facing destruction along with 30 other veteran trees to allow for a relief road in Shrewsbury, Shropshire, and nine veteran trees in an area of ancient woodland standing in the way of the proposed new Lower Thames Crossing in south London.

Jack Taylor, lead campaigner for the Woodland Trust, which is campaigning for new legal protections for the oldest trees, told i: “Trees store carbon and are home to valuable wildlife, but they also hold the memories of people. The Sycamore Gap tree is a truly irreplaceable loss.

“While this sort of illegal felling is rare, legal felling is much more common. We must, as a nation, continue to fight for better legal protection for our oldest most important trees. At present they have no or little legal protection, unlike our built environment.”

Recent research suggests the number of ancient and veteran trees in Britain is grossly underestimated. While there are currently some 115,000 officially recorded across England, a study by Nottingham University last year found the true number could be as high as 2.1 million.

The Government said it has a range of policies in place to protect the country’s oldest trees, including a Tree Action Plan for England which seeks to provide safeguards for ancient woodland and forest as well as undertaking research into the “interaction between ancient woodland and new development”.

A spokesperson for the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs said:  “The felling of the iconic Sycamore Gap tree is a loss for not only the local community, but the country as a whole. We are committed to ensuring our irreplaceable ancient trees and woodlands are adequately protected and suitably managed  – and we regularly review our policy around these irreplaceable habitats.

“As part of our Keepers of Time policy, we strongly recognised the value of England’s ancient and native woodlands and ancient and veteran trees. It restates our commitment to evaluate the threats facing these habitats and sets out our updated principles and objectives to protect and improve these habitats for future generations.”

The National Trust, which looks after the Sycamore Gap site along with the Northumberland National Park Authority, said yesterday that it may prove possible to coppice the stump of the felled tree – an ancient technique allowing side shoots to grow in place of a main trunk. But the organisation said it was in the early stages of planning the future of the site.
In the meantime, police said they were continuing the investigation into the vandalism, with forensics officers taking measurements and samples from the remains and photographing the area.
One was heard saying: “In 31 years of forensics I’ve never examined a tree.”

title: When does spider season end? Why there are so many spiders in your house right now and how to stop them
lead: ‘They’re outside of the garden, they’re in garages, they’re probably wandering around the walls of homes. Our houses are just sort of part of their continuous habitat’
author: Jason Arunn Murugesu

body.text: Arachnophobes will already be well aware that the UK is already well into season – with so many of the eight-legged friends weaving webs across doorways or even .
Spider season in the UK is roughly between late summer and early autumn, , an ecologist at the University of Gloucestershire, told .

It is the time when people report seeing the most number of house spiders roaming around their homes, said Professor Hart. This period coincides with the mating season of house spiders, he said, which only occurs once a year.

“What normally happens is that male spiders are on the lookout for female spiders for mating and they get very wandering,” he said. “So they cover a lot of ground looking for females and that’s what we’re normally seeing.”
Professor Hart says we’ve got very  in the UK. “In terms of the spiders we see [in the home] – they’re harmless enough,” said Professor Hart. “They’re just looking for mates usually.”

Mating season does not last long and is usually over by mid October, said Professor Hart. “This period is generally the only time of the year that we see them [house spiders] in the house,” said Hart.
Moving spiders outdoors by trapping them in a glass using a piece of card is the most humane way to remove spiders from the house, said Professor Hart.

But the problem with this method for people who are scared of spiders is that you have to get quite close to the spider to do this. He said that there are spider “grabbers” on the market that can be used to humanely remove spiders from an arms’ length.
Spiders play a vital role in our ecosystems, he said.

Professor Hart said: “They are important predators of various other insects. If you didn’t have these predators – what normally happens is that one species kind of ends up dominating and so you have lower … so having predators around actually increases biodiversity.”
“They’re all over the place,” said Professor Hart.
He added: “They’re outside of the garden, they’re in garages, they’re probably wandering around the walls of homes. Our houses are just sort of part of their continuous habitat.”

title: Almost half of bird species at risk of extinction as worrying state of nature in UK revealed
lead: The first State of Nature report in four years has found that nearly one in six UK species is at risk of disappearing due to intensified farming and climate change
author: Daniel Capurro

body.text: Britain’s  are not “up to scratch”, environmentalists have said, after a landmark report .
Without action, they warned, the situation would only get worse, with the countryside reduced to monoculture farming and non-native species.

The State of Nature report, compiled by more than 60 environmental NGOs and charities, tracks the abundance and distribution of more than 10,000 species in the UK and the British Overseas Territories with data going back to 1970.

The latest edition, the first  found that nearly one in six species were at risk of being lost from Great Britain. On average, species had declined 19 per cent since monitoring began, with skylarks, for example, dropping 59 per cent in abundance.
The major causes behind the decline were the  from the 1950s onwards and , the report found.

Craig Bennett, chief executive of the , said it was up to politicians to turn the situation around. “This next parliament will be the most important in my lifetime for nature and climate action,” he said, adding, “Nature recovery is fundamental to tackling climate change and improving people’s lives – history will not be kind to politicians who ignore this truth.”
Groups involved in the study said that conservationists already knew what policies worked but that it was not yet being done on a big enough scale.
Beccy Speight, the RSPB’s chief executive, said of the findings: “The UK’s is better studied than in any other country in the world and what the data tell us should make us sit up and listen”.

She added: “We know that conservation works and how to restore ecosystems and save species. We need to move far faster as a society towards nature-friendly land and sea use, otherwise the UK’s nature and wider environment will continue to decline and degrade, with huge implications for our own way of life.”
Richard Gregory, head of monitoring at the RSPB, said that more needed to be done both in supposedly protected areas and on farmland across the country.
“We have huge swathes of land given over to national parks and Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty (AONBs) and so on. And we have all these protected areas, but they’re not being really protected. .”
National Parks England was approached for comment.

Twenty-six per cent of the UK’s land area is covered either by a national park or an AONB, but according to a report by the House of Lords this summer just 6.5 per cent meets the international criteria for being protected for nature.
The UK has pledged to protect 30 per cent of its land for nature by 2030.

Mr Gregory said that the sheer volume of farmland, meanwhile, meant that small tweaks to agriculture could have big impacts. “That would be relatively easy to do with the will because we have the knowledge,” he said.

Across the country, Westminster and the devolved governments have launched various subsidy schemes aimed at making farming more nature friendly. However, the report found that only a fraction of farmland was covered, ranging from 28.5 per cent in Wales, to just 4.8 per cent in Northern Ireland.

Despite the bleak overall picture, the authors of the report were keen to highlight projects that had brought species back from the brink. For example, rock lobster or crawfish was on the brink of extinction in the 70s and 80s but had increased in distribution by 576 per cent.
The report found that , with 43 per cent of species at risk of localised extinction in Britain, while 31 per cent of amphibians and reptiles were also at risk.
For terrestrial mammals, more than a quarter of species were in danger of extinction, including hedgehogs and red squirrels.
The picture was also grim for plantlife, with 54 per cent of species having decreased in distribution.

As well as plants and animals being in decline, the report found that the UK’s landscapes were in a poor condition. Just 7 per cent of broadleaved woodlands and 25 per cent of peatland were classified as in good ecological condition.
, said the Government had put into law the requirement to halt the decline in nature and pointed to the target to protect 30 per cent of land for nature.

“At the start of this year, I published our comprehensive Environmental Improvement Plan, setting out how we will create and restore at least 500,000 hectares of new wildlife habitats, starting with 70 new wildlife projects including 25 new or expanded National Nature Reserves,” she said.
“We also continue to , plant more trees and through our world-leading environmental farming schemes support farmers to produce food sustainably and profitably.”
The report is not without success stories.

Among the creatures to have done well since 1970 was the red kite, which was once extinct in England and Scotland. It now numbers more than 4,400 breeding pairs, a seven fold increase over the last five decades.
Meanwhile, the wood bristle moss has boomed thanks to a decrease in sulphur dioxide emissions, which causes acid rain. The bryophyte has increased its range by 170 square kilometres.

Other species, however, are not doing well at all. Hedgehog numbers appear to have more than halved since 1970s, while red squirrel abundance has dropped 37 per cent. Puffin populations crashed by 30 per cent in the mid-2000s and have not recovered.

title: Why the Rosebank oil field won’t bring down gas and electric prices or give the UK energy security
lead: Ministers claim that drilling for more fossil fuels in the North Sea will bring multiple benefits to the UK, but there are several reasons why these claims don’t stand up to scrutiny
author: Daniel Capurro

body.text: The Government has.
Energy Secretary  claimed that the decision would ensure Britain’s energy security by providing a domestic source of  rather than relying on hostile countries.
, because, they say, the independent Climate Change Committee (CCC) expects 25 per cent of the UK’s energy in 2050 to come from fossil fuels, with the emissions captured or offset.

And, they claim that having a domestic source of fossil fuels will help to protect Britain from soaring prices if there is a future energy supply shock like the one that followed Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
However, opponents claim that Rosebank will, in fact, not keep energy prices down, or make Britain more energy secure:
Britain’s oil and gas sector is privatised, with the companies involved paying the Exchequer royalties for the privilege of pumping oil and gas.

This means that the UK has no control over where and to whom the oil and gas is sold, or over its price.  Because oil and gas are traded globally, the price is set by international demand, regardless of whether they are being bought and sold in the same country or shipped overseas.

Britain’s total reserves of oil and natural gas account for 0.2 and 0.1 per cent of global reserves, respectively. That means that, unlike major producers such as Saudi Arabia and Qatar, the UK simply isn’t a big enough supplier to affect global supplies and therefore prices.

And, because prices are set by global markets, it doesn’t matter that the oil and gas are produced in the UK. Unless the Government is willing to force private fossil fuel companies to sell their products in Britain for less than the market value, having a domestic supply will have little to no effect on UK prices, and therefore on the cost of electricity, heating or filling a petrol tank.
This would also be true in the case of another price shock.
The best way for Britain to keep its energy prices low is to wean itself off expensive fossil fuels altogether and increase its supply of cheap, domestically produced renewable energy.

According to the Department for Energy Security and Net Zero’s own calculations, by 2025, wind and solar will cost £44 and £41 per kilowatt hour compared to £114 per kWh for natural gas, which over the last 12 months has provided 36.5 per cent of the UK’s electricity.
The Government insists that having a domestic supply of oil and gas will keep Britain energy secure by reducing its dependence on hostile states.
However, before Russia invaded Ukraine, just 4 per cent of Britain’s imports came from Russia. The vast majority of the UK’s imports are from non-hostile countries.

Of the 76 billion cubic metres (bcm) of natural gas consumed in Britain in 2021-22, 29bcm came from domestic supplies, while 32bcm came from Norway. Much of the rest was imported from Qatar, a British ally, and Peru.

Although it doesn’t affect the price, a domestic supply of natural gas does mean the UK is less reliant on imports compared to countries such as Germany. Nevertheless, private companies are free to sell to the highest bidder, meaning that, without Government intervention, UK gas could still be shipped abroad.
For oil, there is a very different picture. The UK does not have the facilities to refine the type of crude oil which comes out of the North Sea, which is generally light and high in sulphur.
Britain’s refineries mostly predate the discovery of North Sea oil and are instead designed to process Libyan oil, which is both much heavier and much lower in sulphur content.
Because of that, 80 per cent of the UK’s domestic oil is actually exported, going mostly to South East Asia where the refineries are set up to handle that type of oil.
Increasing the output of North Sea oil, therefore, would have a very limited impact on how much oil the UK imports.

As Jess Ralston, of the climate think-thank the Energy and Climate Unit, said: “Rosebank oil will mostly be exported and then sold back to us at whatever price the oil companies can get. So it won’t help one bit with energy independence or gas bills, despite the Government’s rhetoric. New renewables could help, but Treasury rules meant that .
“What does this mean for today’s young and future generations? Inheriting the huge costs of decommissioning oil and gas fields and ever more emissions that are driving .”
The Government insists that drilling at Rosebank is compatible with Britain’s pledge, claiming that CCC figures show we will still get 25 per cent of our energy from fossil fuels by 2050.
This figure, however, does not appear anywhere in CCC publications.

The CCC itself expects oil demand to have dropped 85 per cent and natural gas demand by 70 per cent by 2050. It expects most of the demand for oil to come from the airline industry, while what natural gas is still in use would mostly be in industry and some power generation, with the carbon emissions captured and stored.

Earlier this year, then chair of the CCC, Lord Deben, criticised the Government’s , saying: “I don’t understand how the Government can ask other people not to produce more oil [while supporting new oil and gas licences in the North Sea]. That’s exactly what they are doing now – asking other people not to do what they’re doing”.
In February of 2022, Lord Deben wrote to then energy secretary Kwasi Kwarteng, setting out the evidence on the compatibility of more North Sea fossil fuel extraction with net zero.

Lord Deben wrote that the CCC found insufficient evidence either way on how it would impact net zero, but that rejecting new exploration licences sent a strong diplomatic message to the rest of the world and would avoid propping up the global market.

title: ‘Truly frightening’ that water companies can’t meet investment targets, say river campaigners
lead: Ofwat found the industry had spent just 73% of the funds available, raising fears that it doesn’t have the capacity the build the much bigger projects needed in future
author: Daniel Capurro

body.text: A failure by water companies to hit investment limits is a “truly frightening” sign that they may have lost the capacity to properly invest in infrastructure and reduce pollution, campaigners have warned.

Ofwat, the water regulator, sets a level at which water companies can charge customers so as to fund so-called enhancements, including improving the security of water supply and reducing environmental impacts.

On Tuesday, showing that they spent just 73 per cent of the approximately £7bn in funding allocated for the 2020-23 period. Overall, enhancement spending should account for around one-fifth of company spending.
Across 17 companies that provide water and/or sewage services, 13 failed to spend the full amount. Only United Utilities overspent by any considerable figure.

The largest underspends were by Yorkshire Water, which had permission to invest more than £800m and spent around £300m, and Thames Water, which spent approximately £700m of its nearly £1.2bn allowance.
The industry has blamed a number of factors for the shortfall, including the lingering effects of Covid, rampant inflation and planning delays.
There have  that water companies may be unable to raise the capital needed to fund improvements, but Ofwat’s report suggests that even with money available the industry struggles to get things built.
Nick Measham, chief executive of WildFish, which  and improve drought resilience, told i that it was a worrying sign for the future.
“This is really scary that this industry doesn’t have the capacity to complete capital projects,” he told i, “it’s truly terrifying.”
He said years of underinvestment appeared to have left the industry ill-suited to the changes needed.

Under the Government’s existing infrastructure plan, the industry is expected to spend £60bn over the next 27 years to dramatically reduce storm overflows in which sewage is discharged into rivers and seas.
It also has plans to , with seven regions in England forecast to be water stressed by the end of the decade.
Industry insiders  that would push the sector’s capacity for infrastructure development to its limits.
Mr Neasham and other campaigners have been pushing for the industry and ministers to move even faster.

Ofwat itself said in the report that it was concerned by the shortfall, saying: “Customers have provided water companies with funding to deliver service improvements. We are concerned that there are companies that are underspending their enhancement allowance while not achieving their performance targets”.
The report adds: “Given the step up in investment that is likely to be required for the 2025-30 period we expect companies to improve their delivery capabilities over the next two years”.
Water UK, the industry body, said that it expected companies to catch up in the remaining two years of the current investment cycle.

A spokesperson told i: “Construction projects were severely restricted by Covid lockdowns in 2020. Today’s figures show that the industry has been catching up since then, but there is clearly more to do before the 2025 deadline. Ensuring the security of our water supply in the future while protecting the environment will take significant investment. That’s why water companies in England and Wales are proposing record levels of spend over the rest of this decade, with detailed plans set to be published next week.”

Following the publication of the performance report, which showed 12 companies failing to hit their targets, Ofwat announced that £114m would be returned to customers through lower bills. Five companies have been permitted to charge more as a reward for exceeding targets, with the rest paying penalties.
Ofwat said in its performance assessment that not a single company reached its highest grade of performance, “leading”.
Thames, Anglian, Bristol, South East, Welsh Water, Southern and Yorkshire Water all fell into the lowest category,  “lagging”, while the remaining 10 were rated “average”.

Environment Secretary Thérèse Coffey said: “While I acknowledge there is good work ongoing in some companies – cleaning up waterways and investing in vital infrastructure – there is simply not enough of it. The fact that not a single water company is classified as ‘leading’ is unacceptable. Our water and sewerage systems are highly complex and under increasing pressure – but that is no excuse”.
Ofwat was approached for comment.

title: Victoria Starmer to stay out of the limelight despite conference appearance with husband Keir
lead: Lady Starmer was pictured taking breakfast with her husband but as so far kept out of the limelight
author: Chloe Chaplain

body.text: Lady Victoria Starmer is not expected to play a central role in the upcoming election campaign despite an appearance on stage with her husband after his
often refers to his wife in speeches and she joined him, to applause, at the end of his address to the conference in Liverpool.

But she has remained largely away from the public limelight and is expected to continue doing so – meaning that in the main she would steer clear of interviews during the campaigning before the general election.
Sir Keir and Lady Starmer posed for pre-speech photos ahead of his conference address on Tuesday, with the couple pictured walking along the Liverpool docks and having breakfast together.
She also joined him on stage after his speech dressed in the Labour Party red.
But unlike Rishi Sunak’s wife, Akshata Murthy, Lady Starmer did not make an introductory speech welcoming Sir Keir to the stage.
The Labour leader references his wife, who works in occupational health in the NHS, when he talks about the need for healthcare reform and recently told .
But she has never spoken publically to the press and, other than the odd photo, remains largely out of the limelight.
Unlike the partners of some other political leaders, Lady Starmer also does not have a formal role in Labour.
Philip May, Theresa May’s husband, and Carrie Johnson both held formal roles in the Conservative Party.
And Sir Ed Davey, the Lib Dem leader, is married to a councillor who represents the party, Emily Gasson.
The Starmers have also been determined to keep their children out of the limelight since he became Labour leader and their names are not public.

Sir Keir told the Mirror that his wife “had her own life and protects it vigorously” and that they were both focused on preparing for the potential impact an election campaign, and possible win, would have on their two children.”

title: Starmer targets ‘grey belt’ to deliver highest level of new housing since 1970s
lead: Sir Keir Starmer says he will ‘bulldoze’ planning restrictions to deliver new housing
author: Richard Vaughan

body.text: believes it will deliver the highest level of  since the early 70s within five years if it comes to power.
Sir Keir Starmer promised to build 1.5m homes, some of which will be in newly created towns, within his first term in parliament should he succeed in becoming elected.
, the Labour leader pledged to “bulldoze” through restrictions to housebuilding by setting out wide-ranging reforms to the planning system.

Sir Keir said the system was “a blockage that stops this country building roads, grid connections, laboratories, trainlines, warehouses, windfarms, power stations” and “an obstacle to the aspirations of millions”.
The plan to “get Britain building again” would “fight the blockers who hold a veto over British aspiration”, he added.
The 1.5 million homes promised would also involve new development corporations with powers to cut through red tape and the creation of the “next generation of Labour new towns”.

Speaking after the speech, Labour sources refused to state how many houses the party would build every year, but one senior source added: “It will definitely ramp up over time because we’ll be bumping along the bottom for a bit if we inherit the mess we will inherit.”
Another source said the housing plans would have “an exponential curve” to them, meaning a future Labour government will have to deliver well over 300,000 houses a year by the end of the parliament.
The last time the UK built more than 300,000 homes was back in the early 70s, with the peak of 425,000 houses delivered in 1968.
Under the plans, Labour will devolve more decision making over planning to local mayors, while also creating a new “planning passport” that will fast-track development on urban brownfield land.
Sir Keir also pledged to protect the green belt, but said areas such as car parks and wasteland, which he dubbed the ‘grey belt’ would be built on.

The party will also give first time buyers “first dibs” on small portions of new housing developments and offer them a new state-backed mortgage insurance scheme, based on models used in Australia and Canada.
The announcement comes after  unveiled plans this week to provide 300 extra planning officers and to force local authorities to quickly draw up local plans to deliver more housing.

But industry sources raised doubts that the measures would have the impact Labour have claimed, with one source telling i: “It is difficult to see how one planning officer per local authority would accelerate the local plan process which is famously difficult to do.”
The proposals were widely welcomed by the sector, however.

Kate Henderson, Chief Executive of the National Housing Federation, said: “Building new towns provides the opportunity to create high quality places with ambitious sustainability standards, much-needed affordable homes and better use of infrastructure. The post-war New Towns Programme has shown that building new communities can be good for the economy as well as society.”

Martin McTague, National Chair of the Federation of Small Businesses added: “Proposals to build the next generation of new towns will help the UK on its path to global competitiveness. This level of ambition can only be achieved by unleashing the potential of small housebuilding firms.”

title: Flying the Palestinian flag could be illegal in some circumstances, Braverman tells police chiefs
lead: The minister said that while there were legitimate circumstances for demonstrating support for Palestinians, some behaviour crossed over into breaches of the Terrorism Act and the Public Order Act
author: Jane Merrick

body.text: Home Secretary  has written to all chief constables in England and Wales asking them to consider chants such as “from the river to the sea, Palestine will be free” and waving Palestinian flags in Jewish areas as criminal offences.
The minister said that while there were legitimate circumstances for demonstrating support for Palestinians, some behaviour crossed over into breaches of the Terrorism Act and the Public Order Act.
Police forces should use the “full force of the law” to prevent harassment of the UK’s Jewish community in the wake of the , Ms Braverman said.
Her letter follows a protest by pro-Palestinian supporters outside the Israeli embassy in Kensington on Monday evening, at which the chant “from the river to the sea” was heard.

Mrs Braverman said this phrase “should be understood as an expression of violent desire to see Israel erased”. The slogan is routinely used to refer to a unified Palestine state from the River Jordan to the Mediterranean Sea.

In her letter, the Home Secretary referred to offences under the Terrorism Act relating to organisations proscribed in the UK such as militant group Hamas, including their amplification and glorification.

Police should not only consider pro-Hamas symbols and chants as cause for concern, but possible offences under section 5 of the 1986 Public Order Act, which prohibit causing harassment, alarm or distress, if protesters were specifically targeting Jewish communities.

While the waving of a Palestinian flag on its own would not be considered a crime, doing so in a way that targets Jewish people, or “aggressively chant or wave pro-Palestinian symbols at” could be considered by police as harassment, the minister said.

The Home Secretary wrote: “I would encourage police to consider whether chants such as ‘From the river to the sea, Palestine will be free’ should be understood as an expression of a violent desire to see Israel erased from the world, and whether its use in certain contexts may amount to a racially aggravated Section 5 public order offence.
“I would encourage police to give similar consideration to the presence of symbols such as swastikas at anti-Israel demonstrations. Context is crucial.
“Behaviours that are legitimate in some circumstances, for example the waving of a Palestinian flag, may not be legitimate such as when intended to glorify acts of terrorism.

“Nor is it acceptable to drive through Jewish neighbourhoods, or single out Jewish members of the public, to aggressively chant or wave pro-Palestinian symbols at. Where harassment is identified, I would encourage the police to take swift and appropriate enforcement action.”

All senior officers should ensure that any protests which could “exacerbate community tensions by way of offensive placards, chants or behaviours that could be construed as incitement or harassment, have a strong police presence to ensure perpetrators are appropriately dealt with, and that communities feel protected”.

Ms Braverman said decisions on arrests are “rightly an operational matter for the police, in line with the duty to keep the peace, to protect communities, and to prevent the commission of offences”, but she added: “However I would urge you to ensure your forces use all available powers to prevent disorder and distress to our communities, and that your officers will act if there are any incidents that stray into criminality.”

It is not known whether the use of flags in a provocative manner have been previously prosecuted under the Public Order Act. However there are other circumstances where people have been arrested or prosecuted under this legislation for using symbols or images to deliberately cause harassment or distress.

Earlier this month a Sheffield Wednesday fan was charged under the Public Order Act for mocking the death of six-year-old Sunderland supporter and cancer sufferer Bradley Lowery, in a photo posted on social media.

And this summer a Manchester United fan was arrested on suspicion of public order offences for wearing a shirt with “97 Not Enough” on the back, in reference to the number of people killed in the Hillsborough disaster.

A spokesperson for the Community Security Trust said: “There is a growing problem of people harassing and intimidating Jewish people by shouting ‘Free Palestine’ at them or driving through Jewish community areas waving Palestinian flags in a deliberately hostile way.

“This is a new form of hate crime that causes immense anger and fear in Jewish communities and we welcome the fact that the Home Secretary is encouraging police forces to look at exactly where the threshold lies between freedom of expression and hate crimes, and to prosecute wherever someone steps across that line. It is what our community expects and deserves.”

title: Labour are partying like it’s 1996, but  Starmer is warned the UK economy is very different
lead: Conference is heaving, everything is fine, so what’s the but…?
author: Marie Le Conte

body.text: Hello and welcome to Conference Confidential!
I’m  and I’m reaching the stage where, like a sailor who has been at sea for months, I am beginning to wonder if “home” was ever anything but a distant dream.
No, really, I’m fine, don’t worry about me.
If you read, you can essentially skip this section. The Labour Party is high up in the polls, everyone’s very happy, the weather’s good, nothing bad is happening, and so on, and so forth.

I’ve started running up to people and bellowing “vibe check!” in their faces, both as a jovial way to do journalism and because I’m beginning to lose my mind, and the words I got back yesterday were: “happy” and “good”. So there you have it.

A pithy line I did enjoy was from someone from a think-tank, who remarked that conference this year was “a lot of people who are very excited about the possibility of a quango”. Cynics might argue that people who fit that description do in fact go to conference every year, but he had a point. There is a lot of enthusiasm here but, so far, few big flashy policies have been announced, which creates a slightly odd mismatch.

There are endless queues everywhere in the centre and they’re all for especially wonkish fringe events. I had to fight against a sea of people to get somewhere else on Monday afternoon and it turned out they were all waiting for Torsten Bell. I mean no offence to the chief executive of  but I mean. You know.

One unforeseen consequence of every room, corridor and crevasse being heaving is that, in the words of an alarmed lobbyist, “you just can’t crash events any more! I’d never had that before! The era of crashing is over!”.
Again, I must ask you to refrain from feeling too unbearably sorry for us.

The Conference Confidential Award For Clunkiest Line In The Speech At A Drinks Reception – CCAFCLITSAADR for short – goes to shadow Culture Secretary Peter Kyle. Addressing the crowd at the YouTube party, he mentioned online influencers, before adding “all of us in the party are influencers, because we’re trying to get into government”, thus becoming “the ultimate influencers”. Boo, Peter, boo.

Can we really compare this to 1996? It’s the question on everyone’s lips, and a few “but…” are floating around. One veteran Labour MP, who was there last time round, told me that the atmosphere was similar, but we aren’t quite there yet. The party needs to be clearer about what it wants to do in government, he said, and, crucially, we must remember that the country’s economic health isn’t what it was in the late 90s.

There are some difficult choices New Labour got to opt out of making, but Starmer’s Labour won’t be able to wriggle out of them. This was, as some moles reported, apparent at the business day gathering.

While surrounded by corporates,went on and on about how much she and the party loved business. The only trouble was that attendees had – amazingly – , where she’d promised, among other things, a higher living wage and a range of new taxes on tech and energy giants.

How to reconcile the two? According to several people in the room, she looked visibly uncomfortable when asked about it. The questions really shouldn’t have been unexpected, and the people in the room weren’t stupid, and knew they were speaking to a Labour party politician. Still, Reeves’s attempt at having her cake and eating made the session needlessly awkward.
This should be a lesson for them: some tough decisions will have to be made, especially as the party gets closer to government. You can’t please everyone all the time.

Is there such a thing as being too professional? Apparently so. Another grumble that kept coming up on Monday concerned shadow frontbenchers, and their inability to stay still. Many of them have, it appears, turned up to panels, read out the one short speech they were cleared to give (and which they had often already read out elsewhere), then left again before the discussion and Q&A could begin.

It may well be that a number of them bit off more than they could chew, schedule-wise, but both fringe organisers and attendees have been left feeling short-changed. It really isn’t the end of the world, but may come to be seen as symptomatic of a party trying too hard to keep it tight.

Everything’s fine. As things stand, this conference is going as well as it possibly could, which is annoying for me but tremendous for them. As one candidate put it, “the more bored Marie is at your party conference, the closer you are to government”. Harsh, but not necessarily unfair.
See you tomorrow.

title: Full cost of Bibby Stockholm barge to remain secret as it is not in public interest, Home Office says
lead: Home Office has been paying £300,000 a week while the controversial barge stands empty, but won’t reveal total cost
author: Arj Singh

body.text: The Home Office is refusing to reveal the cost of the controversial  asylum barge because it would “not be in the public interest” to publish the information now.

The department has refused to disclose the cost of buying and running the barge, as well as associated costs, in response to a freedom of information (FOI) request, despite holding the information in its files.
It comes after it emerged that .

The total price of the unoccupied barge may be even higher, with additional costs including berthing and dispersal payments to Dorset Council totalling £3,500 per occupied bed space, though it is not clear how much of this has been paid already.

The Liberal Democrats, who made the FOI request, said the refusal to publish the information “adds insult to injury” after two months of the barge standing empty at a cost of £300,000 a week after being evacuated in its opening week .
Letters are now being sent to asylum seekers  after the completion of all necessary tests, although no date has yet been given for their re-embarkation.
Bibby Stockholm is the first vessel procured by the Government as part of plans to reduce the £8m-a-day cost of hiring hotel rooms for asylum seekers while their claims are processed.

But the Home Office has not stated how much the barge will cost and refused to answer the Lib Dems’ request for the final purchase cost as well as the “estimated total operational running and associated costs of the vessel the Bibby Stockholm over the next 12 months”.

The department argued that “it would not be in the public interest” to release the information before meeting the standards and requirements for the publication of Government statistics, which it will do at an unspecified future date.
Lib Dem home affairs spokesman Alistair Carmichael said: “The Home Secretary has squandered far too much time on her Bibby Stockholm pet project.
“Refusing to tell the public the full amount of taxpayers’ money that has been wasted in the process just adds insult to injury.
“This whole ordeal is yet more evidence that the Conservative Government is utterly failing when it comes to asylum – and they have no one to blame but themselves.
“The Home Secretary must finally get serious, starting with tackling the backlog and creating safe and legal routes. Not chasing yet another headline.”
It came as asylum seekers were told they would be returning to the barge.

A Home Office spokesperson said: “The Home Office has started to send letters to asylum seekers to confirm the re-embarkation of the Bibby Stockholm and notify them that they will be accommodated on board, following the vessel completing all necessary tests.
“The letters confirm the next steps for asylum seekers and reiterate that all asylum accommodation continues to be offered on a no-choice basis.

“Delivering alternative accommodation sites, such as the vessel, is more affordable for taxpayers and more manageable for communities, due to healthcare and catering facilities on site, 24/7 security and the purpose-built safe accommodation they provide.”
The update comes as a Dorset resident is bringing legal action against the Home Office over the use of the barge, which is docked at Portland Port.

title: So voters think Keir Starmer stands for ‘nothing’? He won’t care
lead: Labour is riding far ahead in national opinion polls and has just pulled off a stunning victory over the SNP in Scotland
author: Adam Boulton

body.text: A new word cloud appeared on Sunday, answering the question “What does stand for?” The largest word was “nothing”. There was an awkward moment when the leader was shown the graphic on TV – but he won’t be truly bothered.

That “nothing” seems to be working with the voters and with his party. Labour is riding far ahead in national opinion polls and has just  over the SNP in Scotland. Success and the prospect of further success – winning the general election – are enough to keep the party calm as it gathers for its .

Nobody here wants to be the one who spoils it, and that means supporting the leadership’s meagre roster of promises to the electorate. Labour has tasked itself this week with answering the question, “if not them, why us?”. The emerging answer is “because we will do it better”, even if that sounds dull.

If Labour’s election campaign team have their way there will only be two important speeches from now until Wednesday: Sir Keir Starmer’s leader’s address after lunch on Tuesday and shadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves’s 25 minutes before the lunch break on Monday (shadowing the spot traditionally taken by Conservative chancellors of the exchequer).

As ever these two most important people in Labour will be disciplined. They are taking deliberate steps to avoid the rivalry which corroded the last Labour duopoly of Blair and Brown. Starmer and Reeves are more likely to under-promise than pledge dramatic change to the voters.

Reeves will use her conference speech to detail the iron discipline she will impose on her government’s spending. The amounts of extra money to be raised from extra taxes – ; and from non-doms for the NHS – are paltry in comparison to the national budget.

From to immigration control, Labour is not promising dramatic U-turns on the current Government’s policies or transformative increases in spending. The most popular figure on the fringe is shadow Health Secretary West Streeting, who is proposing that re-thinking and reform, and a mere dash of £1.6bn cash, can save the NHS in spite of the “chaos” wrought by the changing cast of “clowns” who have been running the country.
Foreign affairs, so often a matter of angry debate at Labour conferences in the past, seem unlikely to cause a row at this one, as the leadership’s conventional views prevail.

When presided at the Labour conference in Liverpool a few years ago, there were many more Palestinian flags flying than Union Jacks. This year the ubiquitous conference branding consists of “Labour” and the slogan “Britain’s future” stamped on the national flag.

Starmer will benefit from . Corbyn will be in the city for fringe meetings but far outside the official conference. Inside the secure zone there has been no hint of protest as the leadership supported Israel and slapped down Corbyn’s equivocating tweet that “ending the occupation is the only means of achieving a just and lasting peace”.

Nor are the rank and file in the mood to cut up rough about Starmer’s . It was not voted for as one of 12 subjects for topical debate. Activists agree with doing as little as possible to alienate the Brexiteers in  seats. The leader will come under more pressure in private from the Europhile business leaders, who are packing out dinners and receptions with the Labour elite, having given the Tories in Manchester a miss.

Activists may have been heard singing “Things can only get better” after Labour’s stunning victory over the SNP last week in Rutherglen, but the order of the day in Liverpool is “take nothing for granted”. Last week Tories were asking plaintively “can we still win?”; this week, Labour’s rank and file are eager to tell reporters that “No, we are not sure that we are going to win”.

Still, grounds for optimism cannot be completely ignored. , the ebulliently outspoken deputy leader, allowed herself to complain “I am sick of being in opposition”. Super sober, “boring, snoring” Rachel Reeves went one better, conceding on the record that “there is a serious prospect of a Labour government”. In her case that will be a very, very serious prospect indeed and certainly not “nothing”.
Adam Boulton presents Sunday Morning on Times Radio

title: This is Israel’s 9/11 and the impact will be global
lead: As I write, more than 32 hours after the start of this chilling attack, Israeli forces are still fighting to take back control of their own land
author: Ian Birrell

body.text: The symbolism could not be starker: young people at a rave for peace in the desert, their happiness and spirit of unity shattered by the rumble of rockets and arrival of gunmen intent on kidnap and killing. Joy turned instantly to panic, sounds of trance music replaced by screams of terror as dancers fled in fear.

Two women survived by playing dead beside the bloodied corpse of their driver. A wounded man watched his friend slowly die, trapped in a bullet-ridden car for three hours. A German tourist, unconscious and semi-naked, was displayed on a truck. Scores more, including two Britons, are missing. “Dad, I love you if I don’t see you again,” one woman texted her distraught father.

This was the day that stunned Israel as Hamas attackers . It is a grotesque horror story of historic importance fused with epic failure of leadership. A country that prides itself on the ability of its security apparatus to protect its people was surprised by a terror group bursting out of its prison-like fiefdom. Jerusalem’s intelligence machinery, supposed to be so slick,  involving thousands of missiles and hundreds of men that one expert said must have been at least a year in the making.
The result was the sickening slaughter of people in their own homes and streets, kidnap of innocent civilians, attacks on kibbutzim and even infiltration of Israel’s military bases.

Many noted the significance of these events occurring almost 50 years to the day of the start of the Yom Kippur War, which began with a surprise assault by Syrian tank columns and Egyptian army brigades. The shock to the national psyche is similar, although thankfully Israel does not face an existential fight to survive this time.

Yet the intelligence failures seem even worse, given the intensity of their grip on Gaza that includes “unbreachable” barriers, motion sensors, control of communications, undercover agents and informants, cameras and spy drones. As one senior Israeli diplomat said, this is really their 9/11 – and like that shocking attack on the United States, the impact will be felt far beyond Israel’s own borders.

Whatever happens over the next few days and weeks, Hamas and its allies in Iran humiliated Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s longest-serving prime minister. Supporters  but after returning to power nine months ago in tandem with the far-right, he is left indelibly stained as the leader who failed to perform his most basic duty to protect citizens.

As I write, more than 32 hours after the start of this chilling attack, Israeli forces are still fighting to take back control of their own land and there seems growing anger over their sluggish response as more heartbreaking footage emerges of dead bodies in streets and terrified women being kidnapped.

Probably the nation will come together as it confronts the immense challenge of trying to free captives taken to Gaza, who reportedly include senior military officers alongside civilians such as those partygoers. Bear in mind it took five years and the handover of 1,027 Palestinian prisoners to secure the release of Gilad Shalit, a teenage soldier taken by Hamas in 2006. One jubilant Hamas official crowed that they might now free all their jailed militants. Certainly, Israel would be reluctant to send its forces back into densely-populated Gaza with the risk of heavy casualties on both sides, let alone take back control of the shattered enclave it gave up in 2005. There are, however, no easy options on the turbulent road ahead.

But was Hamas emboldened by the turmoil unleashed by a prime minister battling corruption charges who sparked bitter divisions over  while allowing extremists in government to stoke tensions in the occupied territories?

Let us hope that if any good can emerge from this nightmare it shocks Israel back into sense with a government of national unity that drops the far-right, dumps the judicial overhaul, ditches the expansion of settlements in occupied territories and reins in the settlers. Then, later, to reflect on how they reached this dark point – and reform their democracy to weaken the hold of religious and political fanatics while dropping any delusion that peace can be rooted on repression.

The failure of peace talks at the start of this century, followed by the Second Intifada, led Israel to try to contain the Palestinians, then exploit its economic and technological clout to disempower them though normalising relationships with Arab states.

These atrocities deliberately crush the concept of containment since Israel must respond. The savagery comes as Saudi Arabia shifts towards recognition of the Jewish state. Frustration and fury has grown in the West Bank, often stirred by Hamas. There is fear Hezbollah, the well-armed militia that controls southern Lebanon, might join the attack – as it did after Gilad was grabbed 17 years ago. Iran backs both groups – and is jostling for regional supremacy with Riyadh while the war in Ukraine led it closer to Moscow in opposition to a shared enemy in Washington.

Yet do not fall for the risible claim that Hamas represents the two million people trapped in Gaza, one of the poorest parts of the planet. The lack of hope and jobs makes it easier to find “martyrs” for its cause, but this is a gang that terrorises its own people as well as foes.

Few dare criticise them openly in Gaza. One man told me of seeing them execute members of their rivals Fatah near his house when I last visited. Another resident, beaten and tortured by their security thugs, asked in despair how they could ever shake off the shackles of their Islamist overlords?

The only certainty from these terrible events is that the Hamas gangsters will make life even worse for Palestinians. Meanwhile  devoid of decent leadership as the blood of innocent Jews and Arabs stains the soil once again.

title: The real Calvin Robinson, the GB News cleric who treated me outrageously
lead: Even other conservative Christians were shocked
author: Michael Coren

body.text: So, Calvin Robinson has been fired from GB News. Which rather brings to mind GK Chesterton’s comment that, “Journalism largely consists in saying ‘Lord Jones is dead’ to people who never knew Lord Jones was alive”.

The cleric and journalist is hardly a household name, but on the hard right he’s something of a hero and a darling. Now a martyr too, as he was apparently fired after defending his friend , the eccentric former actor who wasfrom GB News for making outrageous and sexist comments about journalist Ava Evans.

Where Robinson will go now is unknown, but there are a number of ultra-conservative media platforms in North America always anxious to hire what they like to think of as a “victim of the establishment”. He’s also ordained, even though as a deacon rather than a priest, and in a small and fringe denomination called The Free Church of England.

He originally trained with the official Church of England, but claims he was refused ordination because of his outspoken political views, and while that’s been officially denied, it wouldn’t surprise me if it were the case. And quite right too, in that even before his television career he was extremely harsh and provocative on social media, and that would have made life in a parish almost impossible. Ironically, he  female ordination yet wanted to serve in the diocese of London, where the Bishop is a woman.

Robinson ended up on GB News, which is where I first encountered him. He hosted something called Calvin’s Common Sense Crusade, where he argued against same-sex marriage, women’s reproductive rights, and generally advocated harsh social conservatism. The show often seemed like some sort of parody, but it had a dedicated and significant audience.

I was asked to appear, and did so three times. I suppose I was the token lefty, always outnumbered but not treated especially badly. But that all changed on the fourth occasion when I was asked to , after an activist had been arrested for praying too close to a clinic. She had arranged for her actions, and her arrest, to be filmed. Frankly, they always do.

I argued that women have a right to access legal medical services without harassment, that prayer was vital – good Lord, I’m a priest and pray constantly – but that prayer was about sincerity rather than proximity, and that this was quite clearly a political and intimidating act. I continued that I’d like abortion rates to drop but that this could be achieved by progressive social policies and not by controlling women.
