Within an hour of my appearance, Robinson had written on X (then Twitter) to his 235,000 followers that, “for a Christian to be pro-abortion and anti-prayer is bad enough; for a priest it is unfathomable”. And, “Twisting scripture like that is wicked… judgment awaits. I pray he repents”. It was an outrageous misrepresentation.

Predictably, I faced 48 hours of abuse, libel, and threats. To such an extent that Britain’s largest evangelical magazine contacted me and expressed outrage at what had been written, and asked me to write about it. In other words, even other conservative Christians were shocked.

Robinson blocked me on social media after that, and I certainly wasn’t invited back, and nor would I have agreed to appear on his show again. But it does go to character. As, I suppose, does his condemnation of Black Lives Matter as “a neo-Marxist, anti-British, anti-family organisation”, and his promotion of Enoch Powell’s ideas, writing a Substack post titled, “Why Enoch was right”, and even changing his X/Twitter banner to a picture of Powell himself.

With the greatest of charity, I find it difficult see the message of the Gospels in this man’s behaviour and statements. I happen to be a Christian socialist but have deep respect for those in the church who hold an informed, compassionate, conservative position. That’s not what I’ve seen and heard from Calvin Robinson.

I take no pleasure in anybody’s discomfort, but I’ve a feeling that fair debate, and the case for Christianity, will be just a little healthier now. Then again, as I say, I suspect that we haven’t heard the last of Deacon Calvin.
Michael Coren is an Anglican priest and author. His latest book,  (Canterbury Press, £12.99), is out now

title: In playing it safe, Labour is allowing Rishi Sunak to be the candidate for change
lead: The party that has been in power for 13 years is now promising bigger and more bolder policy changes than the Opposition
author: Ben Kentish

body.text: When Keir Starmer reshuffled his Shadow Cabinet recently, it was the , that got most tongues wagging in Westminster. In Labour circles, though, it was another, less high-profile move that many saw as much more significant.

Starmer’s decision to appoint Pat McFadden, a veteran of the Blair governments and a popular figure on the right of the party, as election campaign co-ordinator was one of the surest signs yet of how Labour will approach the general election.

McFadden had previously served as shadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves’ deputy – the man responsible for telling other shadow ministers that all the money they wanted to spend wasn’t available and wouldn’t be any time soon. Placing him at the heart of campaign planning was a clear indication that Labour’s pitch for power will continue to have caution and spending restraint at its very heart. As one Labour source put it: “If anyone was expecting us to begin to be bolder, to start spending more and announcing more ambitious policies, then putting Pat in that job will put a stop to that.”

For a long time, Starmer and Reeves’ . High on the long list of reasons why people turned their backs on Labour in 2019 was the fact that voters simply didn’t trust Jeremy Corbyn and John McDonnell with their money. For Labour to ever win again, party strategists knew that had to change. And so out went the tax-and-spend policies and in came a. A charm  was matched with a promise that all policies would be fully funded and, more recently, even a pledge to stick to the Tories’ tax and spending plans.

This reassurance drive, aided by the damage that Liz Truss’s disaster class in economic management did to trust in the Tories’ handling of public finances, has been spectacularly successful: Labour now leads the Conservatives in poll after poll on competency on the economy and on tax. Starmer is even more trusted than Rishi Sunak to deliver on the Prime Minister’s own economic pledges: growing the economy, cutting inflation and reducing debt.

The battle to convince voters to trust Labour with their money has largely been won. People don’t look at Starmer and see someone likely to gamble their pensions away. They don’t listen to Reeves and hear an economic firebrand. The electorate has been moved on.

So why is Labour continuing to prioritise a battle that it has already won? Having secured voters’ trust on the economy, Starmer can now afford to take some risks in spelling out how he will actually transform the country. Yet there is no sign of this happening. So anxious is Labour about losing its hard-won advantage on the economy, the party is now at real risk of focusing so much on what it lost at the last election that it risks throwing away the next one.

Far more than in 2019, . Speak to any pollster and they will tell you the same thing: the public is sick of the status quo, wants things to be different and is desperate for someone to put things right.

There is an overwhelming belief that the country is moving in the wrong direction and that nothing works as it should – including our Westminster system. Any leader able to convince the electorate that they can do things differently, that they can stop the decline and put the country on a better path, will have a very good chance of electoral success.

Downing Street . They know they need to convince voters that Rishi Sunak is not just the fifth iteration in a Dr Who-style metamorphosis of Tory leaders that has lasted for well over a decade, but rather that he offers something new and different. In No 10, “change” is the word of the day. Rishi Sunak used it 30 times during. If anyone still wasn’t sure of the message, he spelt it out at the end: “Is time for a change, and we are it.”

This is just the start. A senior No 10 source tells me: “We are going to make announcement after announcement on all sorts of issues – really big stuff – to show how we are going to change the country. It’s going to brutally expose that Keir Starmer is offering nothing new.”

In many ways, Rishi Sunak’s claim to represent change is an incredible, outlandish one. This is a man who has already been Prime Minister for a year, a senior Cabinet minister for almost four, a minister for six, and who leads a party that has been in power for 13. It is just as audacious to depict Keir Starmer, who has never held a position in government, as representing the political status quo.

And yet the Tories have only been able to seize the change agenda because Labour has so spectacularly failed to do so. Despite poll after poll showing that voters do not know what he stands for, Starmer and his team are still struggling to spell out what change, if any, they represent. His “missions” for government are vague and woolly. The policies that have been announced as part of them are modest and moderate.

It says a lot about Labour’s timidity that, in many areas, it is the party that has been in power for 13 years that is now promising bigger and more bolder policy changes than the Opposition. Just look at the areas that Sunak focused on in his speech. His plan to  Labour has said on education, while the phased ban on  than most Opposition policies on health. Labour has been toying with “consulting” on the same idea. Sunak has just gone for it. Then there is the £36bn investment in roads and buses. And that was just in one speech.

With voters crying out for change, Labour instead seems desperate to emphasise what it would continue. Starmer and his team have spent the last year publicly admitting that they won’t be able to change much if they do win power, that they won’t reverse major Tory laws that they disagree with, that they won’t raise any taxes and even that they will follow Conservative spending plans. Rather than offering something different, Labour seems to be desperate to emphasise what it would continue. While Sunak is talking about transformation, Starmer is talking about tinkering.

There is still a good chance that the Tories’ new approach will fail. It is not just a change in policy that many people want but something more fundamental: a real change in leadership and an end to the chaos of recent years. The Tory brand is still badly damaged. But the fact that No 10 has been swifter than Labour to latch onto the desire – the desperation – for things to be different is giving Tory MPs some hope. Even a demoralised Labour source admits: “It may not be enough, but it gives them a fighting chance.”

If Labour falls short at , it won’t be because it still isn’t trusted to manage the economy but because it spent so long making that argument – long after it was already won – that it failed to hear the country crying out for real change.

Rishi Sunak has started to spell out his government will do things very differently. If Keir Starmer wants to win the next election rather than just the battles of the last one, he urgently needs to do the same.
Ben Kentish is an LBC presenter

title: My message to Keir Starmer: slogans will only go so far
lead: This was the opportunity to show Labour’s vision of the society
author: John McDonnell

body.text: The common feature of the  conference this week has been their very obvious professional crafting.
Phrases that have obviously been focus group tested to the “nth” degree litter each speech and are repeated time and time again in the hope that they are bedded into the popular consciousness.
In her speech Rachel Reeves told us repeatedly that . Keir Starmer’s repeated slogan was “decade of renewal.”

As a political artisan I can appreciate a well turned phrase and crafted slogan. They may stir the audience of party members in the conference hall but they have to be backed up with serious policy making.

In US politics the question asked about political speeches is always “Where’s the beef?” It’s the question that the opinion polls are showing people are asking – what does Labour stand for?  It’s the question that Labour has to answer fast as no party can sit back and

An incoming Labour government will face the toughest inheritance any government has faced for generations. Thirteen years of austerity inflicted on our country by the Conservatives has resulted in a huge funding gap for our public services.

In a detailed report drafted by Andrew Fisher and myself we estimated that just to address some of the crises in our public services an incoming Labour government will need to raise £78bn each year.  There was no evidence in either Rachel Reeves or Keir Starmer’s speech that either of them fully appreciate  when they go into government. There continues to be no acknowledgment of the scale of the resources that would need to be raised.

More worryingly the Labour leadership may have decided to limit their ambitions of what Labour can achieve. The leader’s speech roved , the need for an industrial strategy and its role in tackling climate change but there was insufficient detail for people to appreciate how this would respond to their needs.
There were a limited number of specific announcements.

On the NHS Sir Keir Starmer announced there would be more appointments for patients. He had previously said that this would be achieved by . They would be paid out of tackling tax avoidance. He was more specific at the weekend that this would come from abolishing non-dom tax status. Some are concerned that this seems to have been spent a number of times.
Keir Starmer promised to build a new generation of towns and to . The location of these new towns was not identified and where the funds for building the new homes is coming from is unclear.

Recent statements have suggested that the new homes would be secured by forcing developers to build them but no answer to the question what happens if a developer says no. Much emphasis has also been placed upon reform of the planning system to overcome green belt objections but the concern is that this could only be achieved by taking decision-making out of local community hands and by centralising it.

The opening of a new generation of colleges was announced to provide the skills training needed for a modern growing economy. This will be welcomed across the education sector and by business but those managing the budgets of existing cash strapped colleges will be understandably asking the question “what about us?”

This will almost certainly be the last conference speech by Keir Starmer before the next election. It was a significant moment but the lesson of all these speeches is that securing the applause of the conference hall is not enough.

This was the opportunity to show Labour’s vision of the society it wants to shape but that needs to be shown to be based upon a credible policy programme. The people will soon have the chance to give their verdict in the election.

title: What Labour’s housing policies could mean for the UK, and why they’re so similar to the Tories’
lead: Many of Labour’s housing policies sound similar to ideas that Michael Gove has discussed with me and other journalists
author: Vicky Spratt

body.text: This is Home Front with Vicky Spratt, a subscriber-only newsletter from i. If you’d like to get this direct to your inbox, every single week,

This week’s Home Front is brought to you from Liverpool, where I have just finished writing in front of Sir Keir Starmer as he gives his Labour Party conference speech after being attacked with glitter by a protestor.
There are many differences between Labour’s conference and the one I attended for the Conservatives last week in Manchester, but let’s focus on one: housing has dominated all the key speeches here.

In Manchester, housing was conspicuous by its absence from the Prime Minister’s speech, and even the Housing Secretary Michael Gove somehow managed to barely mention it, despite being a champion for ending the housing crisis since he took on the role.

In Liverpool, Labour deputy leader  put social housing at the top of Labour’s agenda. She vowed to once again make it the second-largest tenure and promised to “deliver the biggest boost in affordable and social housing for a generation”, including “council housing”.
To do this, Labour plan to keep Section 106 – the mechanism through which private developers contribute social homes – and also strengthen it while giving local councils more power to enforce it.

This will be welcome news to the local authority housing leads up and down the country, who regularly tell me that they spend much of their time trying to stop private builders from wriggling out of their obligations.
Rayner said Labour will give first-time buyers “first dibs” on homes in their area and introduce a mortgage guarantee scheme for those without family wealth.
Something like this is definitely needed to keep the housing market moving, but to avoid Help to Buy-style inflation, demand-side support has to come with a serious housing supply increase.

Rayner said that if elected, Labour would “unlock government grants to deliver new homes by making the Affordable Homes Programme more flexible so that every penny gets out the door to build the homes people need”.
Labour have been careful not to announce new funding for building truly affordable homes, and instead made arguments for repurposing existing funding and making sure it is used properly.
Whether that existing funding would be enough to get the 90,000 social homes that experts like Shelter and Crisis say Britain needs built is up for debate.
Meanwhile, the key themes in Starmer’s speech were reform and renewal. Housing, he said, would be a big part of Labour’s vision of “renewal”.
People “deserve the security of homeownership”, he said, before adding that the future was being “hidden” by a “restrictive planning system” that Labour would “bulldoze through”.

I am still waiting for detail on how exactly how they plan to do this, but it looks as though it will involve the creation of government-backed development corporations, which are similar to those of the post-war era.
Through these bodies, they hope to build “a generation of new towns”. Development corporations were very successful and resulted in huge numbers of homes being built between the 1940s and 1970s.
As with Rayner’s promises, the funding for these new towns will be key.

However, given that the unfolding situation in the Middle East could well be the ‘Black Swan’ event that global markets had feared after the war in Ukraine, Labour’s strategy of blaming Liz Truss for higher mortgage rates (which is only partly the case) could come back to bite them if they are elected and find themselves presiding over an economic crisis that is even worse than the one we face right now.
Many of Labour’s housing policies sound similar to ideas that Michael Gove has discussed with me and other journalists.

This is perhaps less about Labour “copying” the Conservatives and more about the fact that there is consensus among experts – with whom Gove has also met – about how to end the housing crisis: regulate renting, build social housing, sort out planning, and make housing a priority.
Next up, I want to talk about an aspect of the housing crisis that didn’t receive as much attention at Labour Conference as it ought to have done: the affordability crisis in private renting.

Last week, the , an industry group representing companies that build for private sale, warned that England is now “the most difficult place to find a home in the developed world”, and said their research also showed that a greater proportion of people in England live in substandard properties than the European Union average.

The same report warned that about a quarter of private renters in the UK are also “overburdened” by housing costs – spending more than 40 per cent of income – compared with only  9 per cent in France and 5 per cent in Germany, according to OECD data.
I put this to the shadow minister Matthew Pennycook at a Labour List panel.

He noted that Labour can’t do everything at conference, but committed to private renting reform. He also said – with a wry smile – that the Conservatives could have Labour votes to pass their delayed Renters’ Reform Bill before the King’s Speech next month.

However, the elephant in the room remains discussing the cost of renting, which – without increasing the Local Housing Allowance, used by state support to calculate for low-income renters, or some form of rent control or regulation – cannot really be addressed.

Speaking about the plight of private renters, Ben Twomey, chief executive of Generation Rent, told me after Starmer’s speech: “It was really encouraging to hear Keir Starmer mention the cost of renting in his conference speech, and his plans to get building. The housing crisis has been the talk of all the conferences, so we are hopeful that every party will go into the next election with a clear pitch to renters.”

Polly Neate, chief executive of the homelessness charity Shelter, said: “The drastic decline in social homes is at the root of this country’s housing emergency. It has pushed ever-more people into wildly expensive and under-regulated private renting and forced hundreds of thousands into homelessness. In order the end this crisis, any plans for new towns must have social housing in their DNA.

“Housing will be a critical issue as we head into the next general election. Voters want real solutions, not piecemeal promises. All political parties need to commit to building 90,000 genuinely affordable social homes each year, which this country desperately needs.”
Labour has not committed to the 90,000 figure.
This week, another conference special.
I have been asked by an anonymous conference attendee whether I think Labour can really end the housing crisis.
It’s a good question.

They absolutely can, as could the Conservatives, but it will take continued determination, more of the commitment to housing seen at this conference, and ultimately, I think, more funding than is currently available through the Affordable Homes Programme for social housing.

With the economic challenges of inflation and global geopolitical instability I mentioned above, this could be difficult for them. I think they know that, which is why Starmer focused so heavily on what he called “the new age of insecurity” in his speech.
I’ll level (up) with you – I haven’t had time for much beyond housing and politics in the last two weeks.
Tiny violins at the ready. I know.

So instead, I’ll give you a little insight into the best party I attended at Labour Conference. It was hosted by the Communications Workers’ Union, with former shadow housing secretary Lisa Nandy briefly behind the decks. The dance floor was full.
This is Home Front with Vicky Spratt, a subscriber-only newsletter from i. If you’d like to get this direct to your inbox, every single week,

title: Ed Davey wants to reverse ‘trauma’ of 18 years of Lib Dem failure by beating Tories in 30 winnable seats
lead: Lib Dem officials signalled they will limit ambitions for the next election – four years after Jo Swinson’s plan to ‘become prime minister’ led to her losing her seat
author: Hugo Gye

body.text: The are planning to limit their ambitions at as they battle to regain their place as the third-largest party in parliament after nearly 20 years of disappointing poll results.

Meeting in Bournemouth this week, the mood in the Lib Dems was buoyant after a string of wins in the past two years – but also haunted by memories of the party’s last full-blown conference, in the same venue in 2019, when MPs believed they were on the brink of  but ended up with .

There are currently just 15 Lib Dem MPs even after the four by-election victories which have boosted the party under  and attracted an influx of cash from donors. Since the 2015 election which almost wiped out the party, it has been smaller than the SNP in the House of Commons.

“2005 was the last successful election we had,” a senior Lib Dem insider told i. “Even in 2010 we were losing MPs.” Asked why the party is ditching both policies and strategy used in previous years, another source said bluntly: “Well, we won 11 MPs at the last election.”

The party has played down the importance of winning support from the country as a whole and is targeting a small minority of seats, perhaps 30 in total, where it came second to the Conservatives in 2019 – mostly in South East England, but some in the South West and a handful on the outskirts of cities in the North.
“It’s useless for us to be amassing votes all around the country in places we’re not going to win,” one strategist said. “We need to amass votes where we will win.”

The campaigns team, led by party veteran Dave McCobb, bases its  on which seats have the most active local teams which are making progress in winning over voters and the number of targets is constantly shifting – although most insiders agree that doubling the cohort of MPs to 30 or more, and overtaking the SNP, would be a strong result.

Not even every sitting MP will receive the resources needed to defend their seat if the party determines that it is unwinnable. “We’re going to be ruthless,” a source said. “Every candidate needs to show they are on track to win, and that includes the by-election winners.”

One MP admitted: “We can’t put a number on our seats because we just don’t know – and we’ve been burned before.” In all recent general elections, the party ended up pouring resources into constituencies where it ended up badly beaten, while missing narrowly missing out elsewhere.

Those who were involved with the 2019 campaign, and the Bournemouth conference which proceeded it, are obsessed with avoiding the mistakes of that disastrous period when the Lib Dems  a wave of anti-Brexit sentiment to win as many as 100 seats. “Last time it felt like a lot of Kool-Aid had been drunk,” one campaigner said. “To be honest, it was like a cult.” Another joked: “This seems like the conclusion of a long process of therapy. Coming back to the scene of the trauma.”

The party as the core of its campaign message – although Lib Dem activists remain as passionate about the topic as ever. MPs told i healthcare and the cost of living were the two most common issues brought up on the doorstep by voters in the target “Blue Wall” seats the party is trying to win.

They privately insist that the party has to be pragmatic in its approach to its European policy – despite demands from activists to take a more strident position. “Realistically we can’t run an election campaign based on rejoining the EU,” one MP said. “There just isn’t the bandwidth or the appetite for it right now.”

The most public row at the conference was over whether the Lib Dems should endorse national housebuilding targets, which the leadership was eager to drop as they seek to compete with the Tories in suburban and rural seats where development is unpopular. Sir Ed experienced a “rite of passage” for leaders when he lost a crunch vote on the issue, forced by the party’s youth wing.

The heated nature of the debate – on both sides – exposed how much of a divisive issue the policy could be. During the discussion on the conference floor, speakers took swipes at one another and members of the audience heckled those with opposing views. Activists warned Sir Ed, who sat in the front row of the audience, that the party was at risk of “letting down younger voters and losing the youth vote, again”.

Others opposing the targets said they would produce an “attack line that will be on every Tory leaflet”. One party insider said: “The Lib Dem conference is not usually like this, it shows the strength of feeling on both sides.”

The other question that loomed over this conference – likely to be the last before the next election – was on , unofficial or otherwise. The Lib Dems did not want to discuss it and Sir Ed and his aides dodged repeated questions from journalists on the possibility of a deal with Labour.

The ever-closer alignment of policies, however, told a different story. Sir Ed’s keynote speech centred around “broken Britain” and how this can be repaired: building a stable economy, focusing on NHS reform with the use of tougher targets, forming a closer relationship with the EU without raising the issue of rejoining – all of which closely mirror ‘s key policies.

The question of whether the Lib Dems could support  in a hung parliament is premature, according to party officials who fear discussing it in public would appear arrogant. “We have had leaders who were more focussed on what happens the day after the general election,” one said. “We’re not going to do that.”

title: How infighting over Nadine Dorries’ seat could cost Labour and Lib Dems a chance of victory
lead: Both parties have refused to pull back in the seat – raising the prospect the Tories might hold on even if their share of the vote collapses
author: Hugo Gye

body.text: The ambition of an anti-Tory “progressive alliance” is at risk from bitter divisions between and the  in a key upcoming by-election, the parties have been warned.
, the former constituency of Nadine Dorries, both main opposition parties are fighting to take the seat off the Conservatives.
The , who have won a string of recent by-elections, were initially the bookies’ favourites, but Labour has been ahead in both published opinion polls on the contest.

Both parties have refused to pull back in the seat – raising the prospect that the Tories might hold on even if their share of the vote collapses compared with the 60 per cent they won in the last general election.

The Lib Dems are adamant that Labour cannot win in the largely rural constituency because they will struggle to exceed about 30 per cent of the vote. They have urged Sir Keir Starmer’s party to focus on the by-election in Tamworth, which takes place on the same day, 19 October.

“Labour have not governed without Tamworth for 100 years,” a Lib Dem source said. “Blair managed to win it back from the Conservatives, but could never win Mid Beds.  We are very curious why they are constantly talking up Mid Beds but seem very shy on Tamworth. There is no doubt these being held on the same day is causing Labour a major headache.”

The party has emphasised the local roots of its candidate, Emma Holland-Lindsay – claiming that Labour’s Alistair Strathern, who is a councillor in London, is unable to stand for the area. “We aren’t making personal attacks,” the source said. “People are telling us on the doorstep they want a local Bedfordshire councillor after the Nadine Dorries fallout.”

Peter Kyle, Labour’s shadow Science Secretary, who is running the Mid Bedfordshire campaign, insisted his party could win over village residents. He told i: “We have more data than any other party there, we have granular data on every village and Flitwick as well. The Lib Dems – where are they getting that data from? They don’t have the teams out or the polling research that we have – it’s categorically wrong.”

He said the Lib Dems were trying to “play the person and not the ball”, adding: “There is barely a Labour MP who hasn’t experienced how the Lib Dems do this… If they say they care about the Tories losing so much more than anything else, why are they putting so much money into destroying the character of the Labour candidate?”

Mr Kyle added: “This is going to leave a bad taste in lots of mouths if they carry on with this, it’s not about one constituency but about how Labour views its relationships going forward. There’s lots of goodwill that’s being squandered completely unnecessarily.”
Robert Hayward, a Conservative peer and elections expert, said the two opposition parties were “knocking hell out of each other”.

He added: “There will be a lot of soul searching if the Tories hold the seat. But there is this supposition that votes are automatically transferable from one party to the other, and there’s a lot of electoral evidence that that isn’t actually the case. But there will be a very large call for what people describe as the progressive alliance.”
A Lib Dem insider said: “It works for us either way – if we win then we’re dancing, if we lose then it shows how important tactical voting is.”

Patrick English of YouGov told i that the race for Mid Beds will “inevitably create pressure for a progressive alliance”, but that such three-way fights are less likely in general elections when parties look to focus scant resources on winnable targets.
But he said the Lib Dems would be “nowhere near interested” in the seat in a general election as they look to concentrate on Tory-held seats in the so-called Blue Wall.

“It must be super annoying for Labour as they want to show how they are ready for Government but they are fighting a three-way battle which on the face of it should be a two-way one, because of how effective the Lib Dem by-election machine is.
“So it will lead to conversations about a progressive alliance but when it comes to a general election we are not going to see many of these cases where there is a big three-way fight.”

title: Keir Starmer’s defiant speech after glitter protest revealed the kind of leader he is under pressure
lead: His aides could not have wished for a better way to kick off
author: Paul Waugh

body.text: Keir Starmer’s team have long believed that he will sprinkle some electoral stardust over a Labour party that has been out of power for 13 long years.
After , a publicity stunt that allowed him to literally roll up his sleeves and show what he’s made of, he looked more than ever like
Although the protest was a shock and prompt serious questions about his security, the Labour leader’s aides could not have wished for a better or more

Mr Starmer’s calmly defiant reaction, removing his jacket and declaring “If he thinks that bothers me, he doesn’t know me … Protest or power, that’s why we changed our party!”, let him show the voters just what kind of leader he is under pressure.

And this was a “show, don’t tell” leader’s speech, which worked precisely because it repeatedly strove to paint a picture of a Britain where the people keep calm and carry on despite, not because of, their Government.

The examples of businesses still trading despite the pandemic and soaring inflation, volunteers fighting against sewage, teachers coping with crumbling schools, a world where ordinary people say “fine we’ll get on with it ourselves”, allowed him to say how a Government could step in with a helping hand.
Politicians are often asked “whose side are you on?” and Starmer’s list of those who have suffered over the past decade – from business to individuals – was finely crafted.

From firms being told “Brexit would only bring benefits to your business” to “cleaners mocked, as they scrub mess off the walls of illegal parties in Westminster”, the aim was to show how the Tories had indeed united the nation – in disgust at their caravan of failure and contempt for the rules others have to abide by.

The jibes at Sunak being an out-of-touch millionaire worked because they widened the attack on the Conservatives more broadly as a party that “cannot see the country before them”. “They have no way to understand what you’ve been through.”
Tory MPs privately admit that hard-working constituents often complain that the cost of living crisis means they have no “fun money” at the end of the week any more.

And one of Starmer’s most affecting passages came when he described a young mum in a café in Worthing (a Labour target seat coincidentally) telling him she couldn’t afford to go on holiday and was in “survival mode”: “I can’t think, ‘oh let’s do something nice’.”
Mr Starmer also managed to leverage his own backstory as a boy from a working-class family, whose rise to run the Crown Prosecution Service embodies the aspiration he wants to see spread to all.

Perhaps his longest ovation came when he vowed to unlock the public’s potential, adding that the “hardest class ceiling of all” came when working-class people had a nagging voice in their head saying: “you don’t belong here.”

The reason that had so much power was because it was personal. At times, he’s struggled to explain just why his own aspirational journey drives his politics. But given the Tories are gearing up for a “presidential” general election (because Sunak is more popular than his party), this was a preview of the kind of exchanges we may see more of.

The best passage of all had real conviction because it countered his image as a slick metropolitan knight of the realm (there’s a reason Tories constantly call him ‘Sir Keir’): “I grew up working class. I’ve been fighting all my life. And I won’t stop now. I’ve felt the anxiety of a cost-of-living crisis before. And until your family can see the way out, I will fight for you.”

Yet this speech (which was still too long, but he’s getting better) was Starmer’s most interesting to date because it finally began to move beyond criticism of the Tories and Sunak into a prospectus for change.

The warnings that a Labour government will “reject the hope of the easy answer” and instead offer “the hope of the hard road” were a signal that it will take time to rebuild the ragged fabric of our public realm, from the NHS to schools and policing.

His line about “a reforming state, not a chequebook state” will worry some who want an injection of emergency spending before the cavalry of higher economic growth arrives. But Starmer and Rachel Reeves are convinced they’re hemmed in by Liz Truss’s borrowing binge and the “economic shrapnel” she inflicted on homeowners and renters.

The five “missions” of his government, for once shrunk down into voter-friendly phrases including “higher growth, safer streets, cheap British power in your home, the NHS off its knees”, offer long-term policies on skills, bills and an industrial strategy.

The speech was deliberately light on any new detailed policies (Labour has too many already), other than new Technical Excellence Colleges, because it needed to address the bigger picture of what kind of hope Starmer can bring to a jaded populace.

The theme of “a Britain that’s built to last” was the classic national renewal stuff that all Oppositions talk about, but the difference is that Tory Nimbyism and failure to streamline planning gives Labour a chance to pitch themselves as the real builders.

The promise to build a new generation of “new towns” was a deliberate reference to the 1945 government’s own programme of housebuilding. Combining both Blair’s New Labour with Attlee’s New Town Labour, it was also a reminder that the party only wins general elections when it wins the skilled working-class voters in areas such as Stevenage, Crawley, Warrington Harlow and Hemel Hempstead.

Lawyer that he is, Starmer began by asking a question of himself, and answering it. His long-awaited response to the question “Why Labour?” is now “because we will serve your interests, because we will grow every corner of the country, because we have a plan.”
In keeping with his reputation for methodically building a case in court and the Commons, his pledge to methodically build his way to growth in Britain feels authentically him.

Voters will still have plenty of questions and the next manifesto will have to fill in more blanks. But thanks to a quirk of timing, Starmer has had the last word of the party leaders in this conference season.

At least the voters are now starting to see the two main party leaders more clearly. After the “real Rishi” last week, this was an unbuttoned Starmer finally swapping his reserved resolve with some gut passion.

Sunak’s decision to trash his own party and ditch HS2 gifted Starmer the chance to portray the PM as an unreliable “inaction man”. Today’s speech protest gifted him the opportunity to show his quiet authority as a PM-in-waiting. And if more voters see him now as a fighter on their behalf, as a grafter not a grifter, that’s the most glittering prize in politics.

title: In Rachel Reeves’ Labour conference speech, we glimpsed the party’s first female leader
lead: Echoes of Gordon Brown from the ‘iron’ Shadow Chancellor, as she targets her old foe Rishi Sunak
author: Paul Waugh

body.text: “Follow the money”. In politics, as in business, that mantra is often sound advice on where real power lies.
With , Rachel Reeves delivered the mix of pro-growth, pro-business, deregulatory message they find so reassuring.
But the Shadow Chancellor’s keynote speech and the repeated standing ovations from a delighted party audience showed how well she landed each of her attack lines on the Tory government.

The trickiest task is to please both business and political audiences at the same time, especially when Labour’s biggest fear is being. Reeves’s clear answer to that charge is to highlight “Tory waste”, turning a mission to “follow the money” lost during Covid into a personal moral crusade.

That sense of righteous indignation at money lost in Covid fraud loans and PPE contracts (plans for a Covid Corruption Commissioner to expose the “carnival of waste” got one of the biggest cheers), as well as HS2’s, certainly had strong echoes of Gordon Brown’s “prudence with a purpose” mantras of the 90s and 2000s.

And there were plenty of other Brownian touches to this performance. Methodist preacher-style passion against injustice one minute, new powers for the independent Office for Budget Responsibility the next. Wanting “taxes to be lower” for most people, cutting spending on private consultants, chanting the names of marginal constituencies that will benefit from your plans (Keighley, Rochester, Warrington), all were worthy of the great clunking fist of old.

Similarly, the planned and the stamp duty rise for rich overseas property owners are populist flourishes that may not raise much cash but do create clear dividing lines with the Conservatives. The coup-de-theatre of  from George Osborne’s former Governor of the Bank of England Mark Carney was another device worthy of New Labour.

And just like Brown, political cross-dressing is central to Reeves’ approach. Whereas he outfoxed the Tories by creating an independent Bank of England, she is now the darling of the business community thanks to promises to streamline Britain’s sclerotic planning processes that delay electricity grid infrastructure, housing and transport projects.

It’s more than three years since Boris Johnson, a shameless pilferer of his opponents policies, promised to “Build, Build Build”. But like many of his promises, his plans for “the most radical reforms to our planning system since the Second World War”, with a “positively Rooseveltian” drive to expand the state, failed to materialise.

Although Rishi Sunak is trying to use the Uxbridge  as a pivot point for his premiership, the most consequential by-election of the last Parliament was actually the Chesham and Amersham by-election that prompted Johnson to cave to backbench Nimbys.

One of the few positives of Liz Truss’s disastrous reign was her realisation that economic growth was being held back by a lack of courage on planning reform. While buried under the sheer lack of credibility she has on public policy, Truss’s supply side reforms don’t look that different from the kind of thing Reeves and Keir Starmer are now using to woo business.

Yet the impact of the former PM’s borrowing binge is still burned into the public’s memory, and the Shadow Chancellor’s line about “the devastation inflicted on family finances” by her 49-day reign was among her most effective.

Just as powerful has been the way Truss’s spooking of the money markets made it much harder for Labour to borrow their way to growth, with Reeves watering down  to borrow a massive £140bn to fund low carbon industries.

One of the few lines that conspicuously didn’t win any applause was that “you cannot tax and spend your way to growth”. Some in her party worry that her “iron-clad fiscal rules” (including debt as a share of the economy should fall by the end of the next Parliament) leave them with too little wriggle room, as would any bid to rule out any more tax rises.

Jim O’Neill, the former Treasury minister, said this summer that governments should “focus on the net public assets of the country” and not just the fiscal position. He wants the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) to be given powers to work out which borrowing-fuelled public investments would have a “multiplier effect”.
Right now, Labour is only interested , mainly as a counterpoint to the fiscal carelessness and chaos of the Tories.

Not for nothing did Reeves announce a crackdown on the use of private jets by ministers, saying Sunak was often up in the clouds to avoid meeting voters. Her line about going through the bills with her mum as a child, because “every penny mattered”, felt like a deliberate contrast to Sunak’s billionaire lifestyle and wealth.

As Sunak’s Treasury shadow for more than a year, she knows his weaknesses – having bounced him into a windfall tax and criticised his wasteful spending  – better than most. Her “iron” fist was aimed squarely at what she clearly sees as the PM’s glass jaw.

And it’s perhaps an indication of the threat Reeves personally poses to the Conservatives that Rishi Sunak himself broke with the convention that party leaders refrain from doing big events or interviews during each others’ conferences. In what Starmer has privately said was a “desperate” attempt to take the limelight, Sunak did a PM Connect event and a Radio 2 interview.

Unfortunately for his party, the Prime Minister further gaffed in his Jeremy Vine grilling on Radio 2, admitting that his long list of “Network North” transport announcements last week were only “illustrative” rather than real.
While Sunak likes to talk of “spades in the ground”, some of his MPs think he’s the one digging his own political grave. And Reeves is more than willing to  help.

When she declared “we are ready to serve, we are ready to lead,” some in the conference hall may have felt they’d glimpsed the future: not just of the first female Chancellor, but of the first female Labour leader.

title: Keir Starmer’s stunning success in Scotland has shortened Labour’s long road back to No 10
lead: After all the ‘Panda parity’ jokes, this was a victory years in the making
author: Paul Waugh

body.text: It was fun while it lasted, but the old joke no longer applies. The gag that there are more pandas in Scotland (two) than Labour MPs (one) was finally buried by Michael Shanks’

As it happens, after 12 years on loan to Edinburgh Zoo, Yang Guang and Tian Tian will be sent back to China this winter. Keir Starmer will be hoping there is a similar sense of the  following this seismic result, scored more than 12 long years since the party last dominated the country’s Westminster seats.

Labour insiders are often irritated by the way electoral expert Sir John Curtice is wheeled out on the media to give his verdict, not least as they believe  have told a more positive story than they’re given credit for.

Yet, even Professor Curtice, dubbed “the undertaker” by some Labour figures for his ability to find a cloud in every silver lining for the party, said he was “absolutely” surprised by the Rutherglen result.

With a huge 20 per cent swing, and a vote share nearly as high as when Labour won the constituency in 2010, the University of Strathclyde academic said that opposition parties that won on this scale were historically “on course for victory in a general election”.

Starmer has long argued that his path to No 10 relies on a roadmap through Scotland, knowing that for every extra 12 seats he wins north of the border he needs two per cent less in the UK national vote to secure a majority. Curtice said that if last night’s result were repeated, Labour could win 40 seats in Scotland – which would reduce by more than six per cent its vote share threshold needed for a majority of one in Westminster.

Starmer has been careful not to make similar predictions, but he agrees with the party’s deputy leader in Scotland, Jackie Baillie, who said for the first time that Labour could win “a majority” of Scotland’s 57 Westminster seats. If she’s saying that publicly, you can.
Many of Starmer’s most trusted inner circle are from or live in Scotland, with key shadow Cabinet ally Pat McFadden and campaigns director Morgan McSweeney central to his worldview.

And it was in Scotland that the Labour leader quietly but ruthlessly began his rebuild. I’m told it was his personal intervention that led to the ousting in 2021 of former Scottish Labour leader, a Corbyn-era politician who failed to connect with voters. In Leonard’s place came Anas Sarwar,  as well as totally revamped party machine at the grassroots.

Just as crucial was a strong message from Starmer that he would never, ever do any deals with the SNP in Westminster, as well as backing off the Corbyn regime’s flirtation with a second independence referendum – a signal to unionist Tories and others that Labour was safe to vote for.

Nicola Sturgeon’s demise allowed an attack line against both Holyrood and London’s “two failing, chaotic governments”. Labour finally being able to sell to Scots some concrete, progressive UK-wide policies – like the state-owned Great British Energy and Angela Rayner’s workers’ rights – was another key factor.

Most important, however, was Starmer opening up a huge UK-wide polling lead after the Liz Truss implosion, a phenomenon that for the first time in more than a decade sent a message to Scots that an end to Tory rule from London was likely.

“People thought they were sending MPs to resist the UK Government rather than replace the UK Government. We’ve changed that totally,” one senior Starmer ally tells me. In 2015, 2017, and 2019 “people would laugh at us on the doorstep when we said we could form a government”, another said. “They’re not laughing now. They’re listening.”
Labour also thinks that while Starmer’s long-term strategic bets have paid off, SNP leader Humza Yousaf made a big strategic error in declaring .

If the SNP haemorrhages seats, the dream of separation will look more distant than ever. The “referendum” gambit simply fuels the kind of anti-SNP tactical voting among Tories and Lib Dems that leads to the kind of swings seen in Rutherglen.

“Over the past 10 years, the Tories have used English nationalism to fuel Scottish nationalism and vice versa,” says one of those closely involved in the by-election.“That was Cameron’s original sin, importing this populist right politics into his party and it led to Brexit.”
That’s why Labour’s Rutherglen campaign slogan was “a fresh start” from both the SNP and Tory governments, with an emphasis on rebuilt public services.

“It was quite an emotional by-election. A lot of this was about Labour, people saying ‘I’m coming back to Labour’. It shows we’re winning back trust, even though we still have to work hard on that,” one senior party figure told me.

Insiders hope the domino effect of Rutherglen could have a considerable impact on public and media perceptions of the next election too. “It means it’s no longer a theoretical argument that we can win more than 20 seats. We now have real proof that we can win quite a lot of seats in Scotland.”

Although support for independence is still historically high (46 per cent in the latest poll), Labour believes “Yes” voters’ desire to boot the Conservatives out of office in the short term will trump their long-held desire for national separation.

Starmer’s team know their biggest enemy is complacency and don’t want to repeat Rishi Sunak’s error in misreading one by-election result (Uxbridge) as a signal of national renewal. “This is not a general election, we cannot mistake this as job done,” one ally says. Tactical voting could fall apart if the anti-Tory vote splits in the Mid Beds and Tamworth by-elections later this month.

But for now, Labour is delighted to have its own answer to SNP-backing band The Proclaimers, whose mantra was that “I would walk 500 miles and I would walk 500 more” for independence. Its victorious candidate Shanks once ran more than that – 1,400 miles – as he pounded every one of Glasgow’s 6,000 streets in lockdown. Starmer still faces a tough road back to power, but Rutherglen may have shortened it significantly.

title: Rishi Sunak’s dreadful smoking ban is his most dangerous policy yet
lead: It’s authoritarian, legally muddled, pointless and potentially self-harming
author: Ian Dunt

body.text: just banned smoking. He didn’t say that and it will not initially feel like it, but it’s what he has done.

During his  today he pledged to , in such a way that someone who is 14 years old today will never be able to legally buy a cigarette. In other words, it is a phased-in ban which will eventually encompass everyone, of the sort recently passed in New Zealand.
The policy will be popular. People in this country hate cigarettes and they are very fond of banning things. But it is also wrong, both practically and on point of principle.

It is a policy in search of a problem. Over the course of several decades, teen smoking has gone into terminal decline to the point where it is on the verge of ceasing to exist. In , the proportion of school pupils who regularly smoked had dropped to just 1 per cent. The decline is happening at speed. It was double that – 2 per cent – in 2018.
Back in 1996, 30 per cent of 15-year-olds regularly smoked. That figure fell to 5 per cent in 2018 and had hit just 3 per cent in 2021.

This is not the pattern we see in other forms of drug use, where a ban is in place. Britain’s Misuse of Drugs Act has now been in place for over half a century. In 1971, when it was passed, fewer than 10,000 people in the UK took heroin. Now 250,000 do. Under half a million took cannabis, whereas now 2.5 million do. Around 1 per cent of adults had tried drugs in the 1960s, compared to a third today.

There is a profound disconnect in many progressive circles about the notion of banning things. If you talk about the , there is a progressive consensus that it has failed. Any liberal minded person worth their salt likes to stress what a catastrophic policy it has been. And yet when you talk about draconian policies on tobacco, the realisation seems to fall away.

I suspect it’s about categories. “The war on drugs” conjures up an image of a policeman with a truncheon arresting a harmless teenager. “Cigarettes” conjure up the image of big tobacco – huge multinational companies putting their profits above people’s health. It inverts the assumed power dynamic in people’s minds, turning it from a social justice issue to an anti-corporate one.

But when you put those mental categories aside, the basic principle is exactly the same. Bans are ineffective when they are applied to things that people often want to do. And drugs, in whatever form they take, are things that people often want to do. We have taken drugs for so long, and in so many cultures, that they must be considered effectively inseparable from the human experience.

Sunak has therefore done the worst thing at the worst time. He has taken youth smoking decline, an area of supreme national accomplishment, and applied a policy which represents a supreme national failure. It would be one thing if he had instigated this ban when teen smoking rates were sky high. But to do it when they are on the verge of extinction is irresponsible in the extreme.

The ban will not function like any other law we know of. When we ban drugs – as  – we simply slap it on the existing schedule. It’s banned for everyone, regardless of age. But Sunak’s ban will be age dependent.

Previously, we’ve only needed cards to show we are over 18 years old, an easy and well-understood threshold. What happens when today’s 14 year old is 41? How can they be distinguished from someone who is 43? Will we be carrying identity cards throughout our lives to demonstrate our exact age? What happens when someone comes from overseas? Will tourists need them too?

These are not insurmountable problems. But they are significant ones, with fairly wide personal and commercial implications. And they are being introduced to solve a problem which is anyway disappearing if the Prime Minister would just leave it alone.
For all that, the point is not simply practical. It is also about a principle – with all drugs and with this drug in particular.

It is not the state’s job to tell you what you can and cannot consume. That’s the case for cannabis in the UK today, or for alcohol in the US during prohibition, or for cigarettes in the UK tomorrow. is a very dangerous thing to do. But people have the right to make up their own minds about the level of risk and pleasure they want in their lives. Eating burgers and chips every day is also a dangerous thing to do, as is driving, or having unprotected sex, or playing rugby. But you can make your own choices about how to live life. It is not the state’s job to do so for you.
Sunak’s cigarette ban is authoritarian, legally muddled, pointless and potentially self-harming. It will be popular. But it is wrong.

title: The Tories are lost to lunatic conspiracy and moral obsolescence (not that Rishi Sunak cares)
lead: There is really no depth to which they will not sink
author: Ian Dunt

body.text: The Conservative Party conference is a circus of idiocy, conspiracy theory, vacuity and mendacity.

It’s like watching the death of a living brain. You can barely assimilate one act of egregious political irresponsibility before another one comes along to distract you. It comes from junior politicians and senior ones, from those who always had a wide-eyed kamikaze look about them and those who should damn well know better.

Take , Secretary of State for the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs. She’s been in government, on and off, for over a decade. And yet in her conference speech on Monday she started wittering away like a bona fide maniac.

“There are some green zealots who think our farmers should stop rearing livestock and instead we should eat fake meat,” she said. “Fake meat may be OK for astronauts, but when people think of a meat feast I want them to be thinking of our great Welsh lamb.”

What was she talking about? No one knows. What would come next from her mouth? No one could possibly guess. She was lost in a deranged fantasy land of meat products, fighting against imaginary enemies on an invented soil.

Something has happened here. Through some bizarre twist in the normal political narrative, senior Conservatives are spending their time imagining political assaults on the concept of meat. And it has been left to them, the last redoubtable defenders of sausages and burgers, to wield the shield against this .

“It’s no wonder Labour seem so relaxed about taxing meat,” Claire Coutinho, Secretary of State for Energy, said in her speech. “Sir Keir Starmer doesn’t eat it and Ed Miliband is .” This is what passes for knee-slapping, choke-on-a-canape humour in the conference circuit. The only problem is: there is no proposal for a meat tax. Starmer has never advocated it.

Sky’s Sophy Ridge put that point directly to Coutinho 10 times during a subsequent interview. The Energy Secretary didn’t blink an eye. It was as if the concept of objective truth, of a world that exists outside the senses, simply did not exist to her.

Over at the event organised by the IEA and Taxpayers’ Alliance “think-tanks” – at this point we have to use that designation with heavy quotation marks –was expanding the conspiracist world view into previously unimagined domains. The political world he described was more akin to a G.I. Joe cartoon than something you’d expect from a parliamentarian.

Why had the Conservatives achieved so little in government? He had a ready answer to that. “The penny is dropping among people in Westminster that the Government doesn’t run the Government,” he said. Utter gibberish.

“There’s a huge movement going on globally to create essentially a world government that will have power to dictate to national governments what they should do in anticipation of another pandemic,” he went on.
On the main stage, Mark Harper, Secretary of State for Transport, was pursuing his own invented battles. The Conservatives, he said, would stop the “misuse of 15-minute cities”.

These are plans to create communities in which work, shopping, healthcare and leisure are reachable in a short walk or cycle ride. This is to improve the environment, boost public health and create elegant urban centres. In the dread lunacy of the post-Covid internet sewer, about governments stopping people from leaving their homes.

Instead of refuting that conspiracy theory, he actively encouraged it. “What is sinister, and what we shouldn’t tolerate,” Harper told delegates, “is the idea that local councils can decide how often you go to the shops.” He had taken the worst elements of the deranged sections of the anti-lockdown movement and fully ingested it into departmental policy. He had successfully closed the gap between himself and a madman writing all-caps lunacy on an online forum.

Over at the Conservative Friends of Israel event,, went one better. “I know how frightened some of the community is because of the divisive attitude of Sadiq Khan,” she said of Jewish people. “We need to defeat him, particularly for our Jewish community.”

There is not one single record of Khan ever saying anything remotely antisemitic. He has been a proud defender of Jewish people for his entire time as London mayor. “Throughout his tenure as mayor, Sadiq Khan has treated our community with friendship and respect,” the Board of Deputies of British Jews said. “There is no fear present at all.”

There is really no depth to which they will not sink. The conference is awash with the basest instincts of political life: lies, fictions, conspiracy theories and the perpetual stoking of invented division. There’s no sense that ministers might propose a useful idea to improve people’s lives. There’s no hint that they might grapple with the problems which actually affect the country. Instead, they are lost in some mad world of dimwittery and moral obsolescence.

Once upon a time, not so long ago, any one of these comments would have drawn censure from the leadership – a forced resignation, or a slap on the wrist, or at least some distancing from No 10. But we’re way past that point now. In certain cases, such as the meat tax and the 15-minute city nonsense, the material comes directly from government.

The age in which Tory politicians felt shame, or believed that they must at least pay lip-service to the truth, or in which they might have felt embarrassed to associate themselves with the furthest extremes of the anti-lockdown movement, are over. They’ll say anything. They’ll make up any old nonsense. And when called on it, they’ll just press on ahead with what they’re saying, as if none of it had ever happened.
And surely it must be that way. Because if they could feel shame, if they could genuinely recognise what it is they have become, they wouldn’t be able to live with themselves.

title: Laurence Fox’s women-hating bile on GB News has to be the final straw for this dangerous channel
lead: Ofcom and the politicians who go on GB News are making the same mistake
author: Ian Dunt

body.text: Every day, proves itself to be a poison in our political life. And every day, respectable politicians get up, put on a suit, and appear on it, as if it were just like any other outlet. They are willing accomplices to the radicalisation of our discourse.

Last night provided an example of the kind of coverage the channel offers and the type of culture it has fostered. Host Dan Wootton was interviewing another host, , when the subject of political correspondent Ava Evans came up. Fox started churning out the kind of deranged woman-hating bile that you would find in the muckiest corners of the internet.

“Show me a single self-respecting man who would like to climb into bed with that woman, who wasn’t a cucked little incel,” he said. Cucks are men who watch their wives have sex with other men in online pornography– typically young alienated men burning with rage at their perceived lack of sexual success. These are the kinds of terms which are commonly used in misogynist online circles. It’s the languages of places like 4Chan, inserted into the mainstream.
“Who’d want to shag that?” Fox continued. Wootton chuckled away.

For once, the channel seems to have realised the trouble it was getting into. This morning it suspended Fox, launched an investigation and said it would apologise to Evans. “What he said does not reflect our values and we apologise unreservedly for the comments and the offence they have caused,” it said in a statement. Wooton took to X (formerly Twitter) to insist that “I was in no way amused by the comments”.

This appears a desperate last-minute scramble to escape censure and attention. Many would argue Fox’s comments were entirely in line with the channel’s values. They knew who he was and they knew what he stood for. Here is a man who  the conspiracy theory that immigration is an attempt to replace Western culture and demands people break lockdown rules during . What did they do with him? They gave him his own show where he “tackles the issues of the day with his unique and outgoing style”.

Wootton himself is currently  from his freelance column for MailOnline while he is investigated for allegations about inappropriate behaviour, which he denies. He was suspended from GB News this afternoon.

It’s not just the hosts. It’s the format and the subject matter. The entire segment was dedicated to an offhand comment Evans had made about men on a different TV channel. It’s not the kind of thing which is worthy of comment, let alone an entire segment, but it’s good culture war fodder, so they made a big deal out of it.

It was presented with the banner “SMIRKING FACE OF DISDAIN” and described her erroneously as a “hard left commentator”, which she is not. Was the framing designed to produce a respectful discussion of meaningful political debate? Obviously not. It was intended to stoke division and encourage hatred, which is precisely what it did. The channel incentivises this behaviour and then holds up its hands in mock innocence when it leads to its logical conclusion.

You can see the same thing happening across its output. GB News host Bev Turner recently responded to rape allegations against Russell Brand by  that he was a “hero” and was “welcome on my GB News show anytime”. In a since-deleted tweet she has  Covid as a “bioweapon to destroy the West”, while insisting that Jews and east Asians are less affected – a deranged antisemitic conspiracy theory.

Host Neil Oliver talks regularly of “a global elite controlling world politics” – another conspiracy theory with strong antisemitic overtones. This is the standard narrative frame, from talk of a globalist elite to the “replacement” of British culture through migration. Hatred, division and conspiracy theory all the way down.
Once upon a time, these views were restricted to the most extreme parts of the internet. But GB News functions as a mechanism for mainstreaming them.
Among its hosts are former leader of the House of Commons Jacob Rees-Mogg, current Conservative Party vice-chairman Lee Anderson, and husband and wife Tory MP team Esther McVey and Philip Davies.

On Tuesday morning, just hours before Fox made his comments, Home Office minister Chris Philp appeared on the channel, followed by Labour’s shadow Women and Equalities Secretary Anneliese Dodds, followed by deputy leader of the Liberal Democrats Daisy Cooper. Just a standard day in British politics – and senior members of the three main UK parties are appearing on a conspiracy theory-promoting TV channel which gives a platform to hatred.

Ofcom occasionally barks, but rarely bites. It censured the channel for having Chancellor Jeremy Hunt appearing with McVey and Davies because it broke its rules on “due impartiality”. It has said that it will assess complaints against the Fox interview. But each case is conducted slowly and results in a slap on the wrist.

Its rules state that “factual programmes or items or portrayals of factual matters must not materially mislead the audience”. And yet it seemingly has no response to the argument that the channel’s entire output is dedicated to misleading its audience.

Ofcom and the politicians who go on GB News are making the same mistake. They are treating it like a normal news channel, but it is nothing of the sort. In my view, it is a transmission agent for conspiracy theory and hatred. It takes the worst political muck, gives it a respectable sheen and broadcasts it into the mainstream. This process is entirely reliant on the collusion of mainstream politicians and the intellectual anaemia of the regulator.

What will it take for them to change course? How much more do we need to see before we understand what this channel is? Under any reasonable assessment, it is surely a poison in our political debate. And it spreads because people who should know better collude in its existence.
This post has been updated to reflect Dan Wootton’s suspension

title: The Tory conference is just like New Labour’s end days – funereal, chaotic and out of time
lead: There’s a distinct stench of quiet, inexorable political decay. I remember it well when I was a special adviser for Labour in 2009
author: Ayesha Hazarika

body.text: “Go on… Is it as mad as it looks from the outside?” That’s the same message I’ve had from my political friends not as lucky as me to make it to the . The answer is a disappointing no.

Last year, with the mayhem of Liz Truss and the mini-Budget, Tory conference was like a political zoo in an exhilarating kind of way. It was genuinely extraordinary to see normally quite sensible Tories marauding around all the late-night parties desperate to sound off about how the lunatics have taken over the asylum. Except this year, they are the ones in charge and it’s not going so well.

The atmosphere isn’t frantic or charged (apart from a brief drive-by from Truss) – it’s “funereal”, a word which was used several times to me by several political observers. There’s a stench of quiet, inexorable political decay.

It felt like there were far fewer people there than in previous years. A colleague was shocked to be able to get a seat in the normally bustling Midland hotel bar on the Sunday afternoon. But that’s what happens when you lose 1,000 local councillors – important foot-soldiers who would have often brought their families along. There just wasn’t any crackle in the air.

I recall a few years back when Theresa May was prime minister but Boris Johnson was very much on manoeuvres. Everywhere he went there was a media scrum and phones being whipped out for selfies. This year on two occasions we were told to stop and wait as someone important was coming and only afterwards did we even realise it was Rishi Sunak.

This is his first conference as Prime Minister and is probably the last one for the party in power. Last night, someone was frantically looking for a phone charger in the bar saying “I’m losing power…”
“Aren’t we all love”, quipped a jaded local party member.

You can tell when a party is coming to the end of its time in government. I remember it well when I was a special adviser for the Labour Party back in 2009. You feel out of time, out of ideas and out of control.

. The spectacular mishandling of the Prime Minister’s announcement over its fate says it all. That the news is still dribbling out painfully while the party gathers in a former railway station in Manchester with a strapline about taking long-term decisions is beyond farcical. Watching the West Midlands Tory Mayor, , host an impromptu press conference to launch a personal mission to save the Manchester leg with private money added to the chaos.

Labour, by the way, should work with Street on this. I wouldn’t be surprised if he ended up leaving the party or even defecting over this fiasco. Every Tory is mortified by HS2 now. The most charitable explanation I heard was that Sunak wants to get it off the books to clear the way for some tax cuts, but even that feels like a stretch.

And what about the big ideas for the country? A pick-and-mix of random ideas that don’t just fail to weave any coherent narrative, but actively contradict each other.  to protect kids (nanny state), but adults are free to run kids over outside schools because we need to . I’m hoping Sunak’s big policy announcement will be fitting all schoolchildren with airbags.

It was also notable to see how the role of the chancellor has been so reduced. Back in the day, George Osborne’s speech would be agenda-setting both in terms of policy and politics. Now we have Jeremy Hunt reduced to rehashing  like going after benefits and the Civil Service and making sure Nigel Farage has a bank account.

It was ironic that Hunt made Barbie and Ken gags, because he’s clearly a man with no political balls right now. Word is that Prime Minister Sunak is also very much still chancellor and rules the roost. I guess old habits die hard and he is technically First Lord of the Treasury.

This conference isn’t about Sunak. He looks like this is the last place on Earth he wants to be. He dashes in and out of events as quickly as possible leaving no trace. He pulled out of drinks with political editors. He basically hates it and the party faithful can tell. After all, they didn’t vote for him.

One of the under-reported aspects of the conference is that not all members are weird terrible caricatures. I was struck by how many activists old and young alike are deeply frustrated by the party’s lack of offer to a new generation and want to have sensible conversations about issues like housing. But that’s not what this conference is about.

It’s not even about losing the next election with dignity. It’s about what and who comes next. Everyone is jostling for position although some more crassly than others. One senior figure told me, “Suella has basically been pre-loading her leadership bid which has made her look desperate.”

Others may be doing it with a touch more subtlety, but be under no illusions. The next Tory leadership race is almost upon us. As a weary grandee observed: “This feels like the calm before the storm.”

title: No matter our achievements, men like Laurence Fox will always judge us on how ‘shaggable’ we are
lead: It’s not just ‘locker-room boy talk’, it’s out and proud and on national television
author: Ayesha Hazarika

body.text: There was a piercing clarity as Laurence Fox and Dan Wootton sniggered, smirked and giggled about not wanting to shag journalist Ava Evans which laid out so many things. One, that  really is the blocked toilet of British broadcasting, platforming some of the nastiest voices on the right. There are big, meaty, ideological discussions from right wing thinkers challenging the personal, political and indeed the philosophical which do deserve a hearing. “Maaate… I wouldn’t even wanna shag ‘er” is not one of them.

But that moment also reminded women that no matter how old or young you are, whatever your background, your professional accomplishments or your lived experiences or stories – it will always boil down to whether some bloke wants to have sex with you. That is your sole worth.

Let me explain. Not being shaggable is your first sin. But it can get worse. If they deem you to be shaggable but you don’t want to shag them back – ooof, well, you’re in some trouble now. At this stage, they’ll either U-turn faster than Rishi Sunak round a heat pump and suddenly reclassify you as an old boiler (combi presumably) who they wouldn’t touch with a barge pole, or if you believe those pesky “feminist” statistics, they could attack and kill you. No cute punchline line there. It often goes back to the maxim – men are scared that women are going to laugh at them, women are scared they’ll get killed.

Women being reduced to what some man would like to do to them is not just about sex or violence. It’s also about male power structures. If your boss or the men in charge think you’re hot, you’re more likely to get the job, promotion, gig, role, or show. That’s why so many women panic about growing older and hitting 40 because that’s when they commit the cardinal sin of being “unf***able” in the eyes of the architects of society who are still mainly men (apart from some very brutal female-hating women’s magazine editors).

And there’s no escape. Even if you’re a serious older woman in, let’s say the world of politics, who has never sought to use her looks or sexuality to make a point, you’re still fair game. My former boss Harriet Harman was and is a fierce feminist politician who has campaigned for a range of issues to help women from childcare provision to tougher sentences for domestic violence and rape. Here’s what Rod Liddle  in The Spectator in 2009 “Harriet Harman then. Would you? I mean after a few beers obviously, not while you were sober.”

I was recently at a briefing about American politics where someone quipped: “Hilary reminded men of their first wife, and why they left her for a much younger, hotter one.” Cue much mirth from the mainly male audience. And who could forget the blistering speech which former Australian Prime Minister Julia Gillard made in 2012, triggered by the misogyny she had experienced, much of it centred on her body including a menu which offered “Julia Gillard Kentucky Fried Quail – small breasts, huge thighs and a big red box.”

Some of you may be thinking this is all about looks and attractiveness, and if only that were true. The most mind-blowing case of “I wouldn’t shag her” was deployed earlier this year on social media (so hard to believe I know) against… wait for it… Margot Robbie. Yes. You read that correctly. Margot Robbie is a woman so blessed with the highest level of Hollywood (Caucasian) beauty that she was allowed to play friggin Barbie. And yet, she was told by some dude on the internet in his mum’s basement that she was a “mid” and that there were “hotter” babes about than her and that they “could do better.” If Barbie is now “unshaggable” what hope do the rest of us have with these most kind noblemen?

So maybe we ladies/rabid feminazis should grudgingly thank the sewer that was the  for something. It’s now clear for all to see in glorious technicolour – everyday sexism is alive and well. We aren’t imagining it. It’s not in our pretty, stupid heads. We’re not even being gaslit anymore. It’s no longer “locker-room boy talk”, it’s out and proud and on national television. Although is it any surprise really? Look who they put in the Whitehouse a few years ago and may soon make his comeback.

title: Keir Starmer’s immigration plans are not about undoing Brexit. What a shame
lead: The Labour leader has been clear there will be no ‘going back in’ to the EU, no matter what the Tories’ attack line is. Meanwhile, Britain’s migration policy is a mess
author: Ayesha Hazarika

body.text: Immigration has haunted Labour for many years. The party is either accused by the right vof being bleeding-heart liberals who advocate open borders, or accused by the left of being vicious, heartless racist thugs. It’s a lose-lose. Which is why the party’s default position for a long time has been to say very little.

But that isn’t an option right now because the entire system is out of control, and this time, it isn’t the fault of the Labour Party. The numbers – both legal and illegal – have shot up under the twitching eye of one of the most right-wing Tory governments in recent history, one which has consistently made bringing numbers down its absolute priority (and which has failed spectacularly).

The chumps who brought us Brexit promised the people control of the borders. Instead, chaos reigns supreme. More and more people crossing the Channel. Hotels and B&Bs, often in deprived areas, stuffed full of. Soaring accommodation bills. Local tensions. And no end of Wacky Races-type madcap ideas that manage to blend extreme cruelty with dark comedy thanks to the incompetence and idiocy involved.

The Rwanda scheme is costing vast sums of money, yet no planes can take off. A woeful immigration minister talks tough, but the only people he can really take it out on are the. Take that, Mickey Mouse. A  was even floated as a solution to the small boats crisis at one point. The idea that this Government could have the competence to harness tidal power and command the sea to stop those pesky boats is hilarious.

All they have is rhetoric. And the harder and more insane it gets, the higher the numbers go. I genuinely believe that their constant cycle of going big on immigration, then failing to curb Channel crossings, has only telegraphed to the traffickers how broken the system is, and probably encouraged them.

And yet the Tories’ biggest attack line on Labour (apart from economic mismanagement) is still immigration. Despite their appalling record, they are going to come for Keir Starmer on this, so it makes sense for Labour to not only be ready for it, but to try and get on the front foot and shape the debate, which is what we are seeing this week.

Starmer and shadow Home Secretary Yvette Cooper have been waiting for the right moment to set out their stall. Cooper has been covering this brief for a long time – as shadow Home Secretary back in 2015 when the migrant crisis and the camps in France were hitting the headlines, and then as chair of the Home Affairs Select Committee. She knows the policy details and the difficult politics of immigration almost better than anyone.
