Cooper is cautious of going out too far on a limb, and she and Starmer have been planning an intervention that is as credible, robust and safe as possible. They want to get out on this, but they don’t want to scare the horses. Whether they succeed remains to be seen.

The overall plan looks pretty common-sense, although is not actually that new. It brings together ideas which have been floated before, like the pledge to scrap the Rwanda scheme, plans to expedite the backlog of cases, better intelligence sharing with crime agencies, more co-operation, and an EU-wide returns agreement for asylum seekers.

On better co-operation, no one can really criticise that, as it’s something the Government themselves have been working on. Indeed, better relations with Albania shows that co-operation can work. It also shows why a returns agreement is so important, something which we don’t have now post leaving the EU and the Dublin Agreement.
But this is what the Tories and the right-wing press will zone in on. We have already seen Tory MPs claim that a returns agreement would mean the UK taking an extra 100,000 asylum seekers.

There are also accusations that any deal would somehow be a precursor to Britain rejoining the EU. If only, sighs this Remainer and many others. Starmer was clear in his media rounds that there would be no return to freedom of movement, the single market or the customs union, and no “going back in”.

Remember, he has been pretty tough with businesses by saying that they have to wean themselves off “cheap EU imported” labour, to much annoyance. I personally think this stance will make life harder for him on the growth front but it’s clear he is signalling very aggressively that he wants to bring overall immigration down, despite our skills shortages.

The reality is that if we want an effective returns policy, which is crucial, that will involve taking a fair share of people. Why would other EU countries bend over to help us when they are having their own set of issues on this front along with other shared woes like inflation and housing? We must realise that a deal means compromise (I know, I know).

The level of naivety around what other countries owe us from some right-wing figures is astonishing. Many countries already think we have an unfair advantage from migration because of our geography as an island, and they are right. At some point, people were going to try and use the Channel to get here. Necessity is the mother of invention and a great deal of tragedy.

Labour’s plans are a good start. They are serious, sensible, and rooted in reality, as opposed to cruel, ideological fantasy. They also demonstrate a political confidence – no no-go areas. But the truth is that stopping small boats (or the next form of travel to get here) is still going to be incredibly difficult even with a better, less calamitous government.
Mass migration will only increase due to poverty, conflict, the climate crisis, extreme weather, and natural disaster –  – and the desire to seek safety and a better life.

Men and women have always moved across the globe. We were the masters of it back in the day, ruling the waves and all that. You can set up agreements, treaties and have a stronger criminal justice response and that is all very important, but it is very hard to stop innate human nature. Especially when people are desperate and have nothing to lose.

title: Labour conference: Rachel Reeves’s plan is full of populist promises which won’t fix our public services
lead: Reeves’s speech lacked any commitment to spend more on day-to-day spending on public services
author: Andrew Fisher

body.text: The eye-catching moment of Shadow Chancellor  speech was popular in the conference hall:  announcing she would stop ministers from flying on private jets when they could fly with the public.

It was also uncharacteristically populist for Reeves, who has built her image as the iron-clad ex-Bank of England economist who you can trust with public money. “Who do you think you are, Rishi?”, she might have added.

Equally popular with delegates was her commitment that as Chancellor she would appoint an anti-corruption commissioner to recoup Reeves estimated the losses at £7.2bn – all of which would have been signed off by the Treasury under then Chancellor, now Prime Minister,.

The new anti-corruption commissioner would bring together HM Revenue & Customs, the Serious Fraud Office and the National Crime Agency to go after fraudsters. Reeves told conference: “That money belongs in our NHS, it belongs in our schools, it belongs in our police and conference – we want that money back.” Conference responded with a standing ovation.
Indeed we do, but that money is a one-off, and even if partially reclaimed (aides quoted £2.7bn as a feasible figure) it may still take years to recover.

What Reeves’s speech lacked was any commitment to more day-to-day spending on public services. With NHS waiting lists at record levels, social care lacking 165,000 staff, teacher recruitment targets missed year after year, councils collapsing around the country, and , there is a huge and urgent need to fund our public services.

On the eve of conference, the former shadow chancellor John McDonnell and I published a What’s in the in-tray of an incoming Labour government? setting out the scale of the challenge facing Britain’s battered public services. We conservatively estimate £70bn extra a year is needed just to meet existing need, clear backlogs and plug gaps. So far, Labour has committed around £5bn in tax rises – made up of ending non-dom status, closing the private equity loophole and ending some tax perks for private schools.
Labour’s response, as set out by  to the BBC’s Victoria Derbyshire on Sunday, and articulated forcefully by Reeves in her speech, is “growth”.
Getting the UK economy growing at a higher level is essential: in the 15 years since the banking crash, it has managed just a 1.05 per cent increase in average annual growth.

The only good news about such low growth is that there is plenty of scope for increasing it. The bad news is that the UK’s growth has been sluggish and its productivity poor for deeply ingrained reasons – a major part of which is underinvestment. Analysis by the IPPR shows that since 1995, UK public investment has never even reached the average level of other G7 countries or the OECD club of developed economies. Reeves is right to focus on that.

But even if Labour can boost UK growth by one per cent above current forecasts (no mean feat), the Institute for Fiscal Studies cautiously estimates that will only bring in another £12.5bn a year in revenues – far short of what it needed. And it is not clear how Labour could achieve even that until its investment is fully on stream and has taken effect.
Reeves recognises this, euphemistically warning conference that there would be “tough decisions … [we] can’t push through programmes divorced from our current economic situation”.
Growth was emphasised again and again, with Reeves telling rather more subdued delegates: “You cannot tax and spend your way to growth.”

That is arguable, but what you definitely can do is tax and spend your way to better public services until growth kicks in. A few at the top and several big businesses have done very nicely while most Britons have faced stagnant wages and falling living standards. Immense wealth has amassed in too few pockets. The case has never been stronger for redistributive taxation.

Any shock to the economy, from pandemics to wars and natural disasters, could impede growth and even limit Labour’s borrowing under their fiscal rules. The £28bn commitment made by Labour in 2021 was no arbitrary figure, but calculated on the independent Climate Change Committee’s estimate that the UK needed to spend between one per cent and two per cent of GDP until 2050 to get to net zero. Based on figures at the time, that equated to between £19bn and £39bn a year.

By the time Labour gets into government next year those figures will be in the region of £25bn to £50bn, so £28bn will really be at the lower end – and since then the Climate Change Committee has warned that the Government is off-target (and therefore needs to do more).

In her closing remarks, Reeves mentioned “rescuing public services”, but her speech offered nothing in terms of delivering that rescue. With public services crumbling across the country, Labour delegates departed without a credible answer to how the crises in our public services will be resolved.
Andrew Fisher is the former executive director of policy for the Labour Party

title: Labour’s by-election win in Scotland is nothing to do with Keir Starmer
lead: This morning Labour feels a step closer to government
author: Andrew Fisher

body.text: The result in  seemed like a foregone conclusion. The SNP is racked by in-fighting and scandal, their popular leader resigned and their former MP was ousted through scandal. This was a seat regained by Labour under Jeremy Corbyn in 2017 too, but lost in 2019.

The margin of the result, however, was not expected by all. One Labour MSP I spoke to earlier this week said “We will win … but not with a massive majority”. Another counselled greater optimism, saying they would be “shocked if we didn’t win well”.

In the end the latter proved right – Labour won with a 20 per cent swing from the SNP – but the tales from the doorstep were remarkably similar. “Not a lot of enthusiasm for anyone” (reflected in the low turnout), “exasperation with incumbents” (the SNP in Holyrood and the Tories in Westminster). Labour is winning in Scotland, as in England, simply by being less disliked than their opponents. And that is.
A Labour swing on this scale across Scotland at the next general election could yield 30-plus seats for Labour, with each gain taking the pressure off the party in England.

The collapse of the Conservative vote in this by-election (from 15 per cent to under 4 per cent – the party lost its deposit) also bodes well for Labour. In Scotland, and especially in and around Glasgow, the Tory vote is a unionist vote: less aligned with economics, and therefore can transfer to .

When New Labour was racking up successive election victories in 1997, 2001 and 2005 – it was virtually weighing on the vote in Scotland: winning 56 out of 72 seats in 1997 and 41 seats out of 59 in 2005. Even in 2010, when Labour’s vote collapsed to just 29 per cent nationally (lower than in any post-war election except 1983), the party held its 41 seats.

The tables had begun to tip in 2007 when the SNP narrowly won the Scottish Parliamentary elections for the first time. England paid little attention until the earthquake of the 2015 general election – when the SNP swept the board with 56 MPs. Labour was reduced from 41 MPs to just one. But 16 years of SNP Government in Scotland later and it feels like Friday’s result is not just a blip, but a sustained downward trajectory.

Earlier this year, former . She was a popular, iconic and charismatic leader – and a good media performer to boot. There was no natural successor and the race to fill her shoes was uninspiring and fractious; revealing just what a broad coalition – from social conservatives to social democrats – the independence banner had held together.

In his first electoral test – a tough one to be fair – Humza Yousaf has failed. Labour canvassers tell me words like “hapless” and “not a leader” came up. The problem for the SNP is that Yousaf was the best of the bunch.

If that’s the big national picture, then the local picture was no better for the SNP. In 2020 Margaret Ferrer, the then SNP MP for Rutherglen & Hamilton West, . The SNP suspended the whip and eventually called for her to stand down. Instead, she clung on as an independent until a recall petition forced this week’s by-election.

Winning a by-election caused your own party’s scandal is difficult. I recall the supreme effort it took for Labour to narrowly hold Peterborough in 2019 after the , but Labour lost Hartlepool in 2021 after .
“The SNP membership are pretty pissed off and don’t seem to be out campaigning in Rutherglen in big numbers”, a Labour MSP said.

The independence movement has lost its mojo. Labour activists smell blood, and all wings of Labour report their campaign in Rutherglen and Hamilton West was well-organised with hundreds of activists flocking to the south Lanarkshire constituency. This is in contrast to reports of campaign dysfunction in Hartlepool in 2021 and in Uxbridge and West Ruislip earlier this year.

However, there still are nagging doubts among Labour activists. The SNP are in a lull, the Tories in a deep fug, and in by-elections Labour can mobilise activists across constituency boundaries and borders (dozens of English MPs and activists campaigned in Rutherglen). But in a general election the task will be left to local activists, the SNP may be in a better place, and their attacks on Labour being too indistinct from the Tories may begin to hit home.

But this morning Labour feels a step closer to government. Their opponents are in disarray of both sides of the border. Labour may not be inspiring, they may not be loved, but the feeling is – as one voter told a Labour canvasser – “we’ll give you a go, but don’t mess it up.”
Andrew Fisher is the former executive director of policy for the Labour Party

title: Jeremy Hunt is wrong about people on benefits – but cruelty is the point
lead: The Chancellor follows a long tradition of vindictive, divisive politicians who use scapegoats to distract from their own abject failings
author: Andrew Fisher

body.text: Unemployment is rising: up by 159,000 over the last three months, and up 240,000 on a year ago. Youth unemployment is  and by 154,000 on a year ago.

And like clockwork, a Conservative minister is today scapegoating . Chancellor Jeremy Hunt will tell party conference in Manchester today: “Whilst companies struggle to find workers, around 100,000 people are leaving the labour force every year for a life on benefits.”

The Conservative Party has historically found a section of the working class to isolate and demonise: it can be trade unionists going on strike, single mothers, disabled people or the unemployed. It ; the point is to divide working class people so they blame each other rather than realise their common enemy is a Conservative Party making a mess of the economy and our public services.

When unemployment was rising in the 1980s, Norman Tebbit told the unemployed to “get on your bike”. Margaret Thatcher and Peter Lilley through the 1980s and 1990s demonised single mothers. They portrayed unionised workers defending their jobs and pay as “the enemy within”.

In the 2010s, the toxic combination of George Osborne and Iain Duncan Smith – cheered on by their Liberal Democrat coalition partners (Nick Clegg chimed in with his own speech about “alarm clock Britain”) – attacked people on benefits again, making the sanctions regime more punitive, while counterposing

Hunt’s claims about companies struggling to find workers and people leaving the labour force are not even remotely true – but when has this Conservative Government of inveterate liars ever worried about that? Far from companies struggling to find workers, they are cutting the number of vacancies in the economy and increasing lay-offs; they are not struggling for workers at all. The number of vacancies in the UK economy has fallen for 15 consecutive months.

The former chief economist at the Department for Work and Pensions, Jonathan Portes, : “This is deliberately dishonest from Jeremy Hunt. 100,000 people are not ‘leaving the labour force for a life on benefits’. The increase in caseloads since the pandemic has been driven by an increase in the number certified – by DWP – as unable to work because of disability.”

A large number of those will be among the 7.7 million stuck on NHS waiting lists for treatment. Jeremy Hunt should know this. The latest Labour Market Statistics show over 2.6 million are economically inactive because  – that’s up from 2.1 million pre-pandemic. Over the same period, NHS waiting lists have increased by more than 60 per cent. Many of us will know of friends, neighbours or relatives that are precisely in this situation: stuck on benefits because they’re waiting for an operation.

If Hunt genuinely wanted to reduce the number of people on out of work benefits, he would be announcing significant investment in the NHS to reduce waiting times; free skills training for people on benefits; and increasing investment in job-creating projects like HS2 and housebuilding, rather than cutting them back.

Besides, if any country was going to have people giving up work and living on benefits, the UK would be the last one where it would happen: we have the least generous welfare system in Western Europe.

In 1967, UK unemployment benefit was worth 28 per cent of average earnings. Today it is worth less than half that. If unemployment benefit was paid at 28 per cent of average earnings today it would be worth over £180.00 per week instead of the miserly rate of £84.80.

That may sound generous, but let me take you across the Irish Sea where unemployment benefit is  (or £190.66 per week). And the Irish benefits system is less generous than that in Germany or France. The UK has abnormally low benefit rates that make a mockery of the phrase “social security”.

Hunt will also claim today that Labour has “pledged to end sanctions, removing the incentive to look for a job”. The incentive to look for a job is about personal dignity and fulfilment, to escape the poverty of Britain’s benefit system and harassment of the conditionality regime. More sanctions are not the answer.

Sanctions should end. They don’t work. If they did, the UK would have the most vibrant labour market in the world, but we don’t: we have high levels of economic inactivity (in large part because the Tories have made a mess of the NHS) and are bang average in the G7 for unemployment.
Most importantly of all: the Department for Work and Pensions knows that sanctions don’t work. Earlier this year, they suppressed the publication of internal research that showed exactly that, .

Dr David Webster is an academic at Glasgow University specialising in social security who helped force the release of the DWP study, and said at the time: “The internal study shows that for the average claimant, sanctions damage both work prospects and earnings. You can see why ministers wanted to keep the report quiet.”

Hunt will today attack people out of work and advocate something his Government knows to be counterproductive. In doing so he follows a long tradition of vindictive, divisive politicians who use scapegoats to distract from their own abject failings.
Why help people when you can demonise them? That’s the Conservative way.
Andrew Fisher is the former executive director of policy at the Labour Party

title: The highest tax burden since 1948 is the Tories’ biggest identity crisis yet
lead: The identity crisis is giving Suella Braverman and other MPs an opportunity to make their case
author: Isabel Hardman

body.text: Rishi Sunak wants to use the , which starts this weekend in Manchester, to give his party and the country some “hard truths”. But here’s one hard truth that you probably won’t hear the Prime Minister dwelling on when he takes to the stage on Wednesday: the Tories have ended up being the party of high taxes.

Yes, that’s the pre-conference assessment of the Institute for Fiscal Studies, which on Thursday warned that by the end of this parliament, . This isn’t a blip, either, according IFS Director Paul Johnson, who says “in my view this is almost certainly a permanent increase in taxes”. Yikes. Not something you’ll hear Sunak reciting in a list of Tory achievements.

But it’s a problem that Conservative MPs and ministers have been talking noisily about for months. They see the high tax burden as the most acute expression of a wider party identity crisis, and some are dismissive of the argument from Sunak and his chancellor Jeremy Hunt that it is “virtually impossible” to cut taxes at the moment when the government’s priority has to be fighting inflation.

will be at the conference making the argument for lower taxes, and while activists might dismiss her as the woman who people still shout about on the doorstep, her points remain potent in the party and will be repeated in other fringe meetings by MPs who never thought she was suitable to be Prime Minister.
“We need at least an indication from Jeremy and Rishi that they don’t think high taxes are something Conservatives can be relaxed about,” says one former minister.
They said: “Fine, we’re not going to get any commitments at conference but what we still need and have been asking for for well over a year now is a sense of urgency.”

It’s not simple. Growth is sluggish, which makes it hard to find the cash. So does high public spending, and while Sunak regularly complains that people, including his own MPs, have come to think the Government has a role in everything, he also knows that there are huge spending areas that he simply cannot touch, such as the NHS.

Sunak and Hunt are similar Conservatives in many ways: they are both technocrats without a particular political mission. Hunt is very loyal to his boss and doesn’t have the same agenda that many ambitious chancellors (including Sunak when he held the role) have.

He also tends to defer to the PM more than other chancellors (including, once again, Sunak) have done in the past. To a certain extent, their political philosophy can be defined as “getting things done properly”, which in fairness is a pretty ambitious goal at the moment. But it also means that beyond the hard truths, we are unlikely to get a speech or an overall conference that gives us much of an idea of what kind of Conservatism this current party represents, other than a confused one.

It’s not just tax. Part of the Prime Minister’s vision for this autumn is of him as a slayer of monsters that other politicians have allowed to grow far beyond their original size. Changing the way Britain meets its net zero commitments was one example, while Sunak’s desire to prune HS2 in some way is another.

Neither are straightforward, either – they reflect the identity crisis in a party which for a few years had a green tree as its logo and which is still claiming to be levelling up the UK, including the city where it is holding its conference. Does it still care about giving the north of England the same infrastructure as the south-east and London, or is it retreating to a defensive crouch over the Home Counties come the next election? Do you vote blue to go green, or is green the colour of the left?

The identity crisis gives other leading figures such as  an opportunity to make their case. The One Nation group of Tories doesn’t have many red lines, but leaving the European Convention on Human Rights is one of them, and the  horrified its members, including ministers who she has to work with. She is more interested in the soul-searching that might come after an election, but the Prime Minister’s lack of authority means Braverman can get her campaign started now, rather than waiting for a defeat and another leadership contest.

Boris Johnson, who bears a big responsibility for the huge tax burden, had his own approach to Tory identity. In the run-up to the 2019 general election, he booted out MPs who disagreed with him on Brexit, and ensured that the candidates who stood for the party all agreed with his “get Brexit done” pledge.

But Sunak isn’t that kind of politician, and none of the issues, not even net zero, are sufficiently visceral to enable that kind of purge. Not only that, but Johnson was removing people he saw as a barrier to Brexit. The barrier to lower taxes is, in the eyes of many Conservative MPs, the leader himself.

title: Rishi Sunak is trying to do what Nick Clegg did in 2010 – but he’s forgetting one vital point
lead: It’s a bold move
author: Isabel Hardman

body.text: Was  onto something really important in his  this week? No, not the changes the Prime Minister announced to measures tackling climate change, but something else he seemed equally agitated about.

He spent a fair bit of his hastily-rearranged address to the nation complaining about the state of politics, about short-termism, and about the way in which measures to tackle climate change had barely been scrutinised by MPs, let alone the public at large. He said: “I know that they dislike Westminster game-playing, the short-termism and the lack of accountability.”

Parts of the speech sounded a bit like  in the 2010 leaders’ TV debates, where he decried the state of two-party politics and charmed voters by  “the more they attack each other, the more they sound exactly the same”.
This was opposition, anti-politics Clegg, rather than responsible in-government Clegg, or indeed the new tech bro Clegg who Sunak would probably quite enjoy hanging out with.
Either way, Sunak is in government, whereas Clegg wasn’t at the time, so it was much easier for a Lib Dem leader few had really heard of to attack the state of politics.

Like Clegg, Sunak wants to posit himself as the change candidate in the looming general election, with Labour representing lazy consensus and a failure to be honest with the electorate, a status quo in the form of disruptive strike action, and so on. It’s a bold move.

Voters do dislike all the things Sunak listed, but so far he has shown no real inclination to make the fundamental changes that would answer that yearning for change. Why is there such a lack of accountability in politics?

Part of the reason is ambitious backbenchers stay loyal to the Government, even when they know there is a problem with a Bill because they understandably want to progress their career and have greater influence by joining the Government.

The conflict of interest in legislators wanting to join the executive they are supposed to be holding to account is something one of his closest aides and my former colleague James Forsyth was very alive to when he was at The Spectator.

He often wrote about the need for a formal separation of powers, or at least for experienced politicians who had been ministers to see the value in staying in the Commons after high office so they could help their successors avoid making mistakes. The chances of his conviction making it into reality are pretty slim, though.

Sunak complained this week that the last carbon budget process was “debated in the House of Commons for just 17 minutes and voted through with barely any consideration given to the hard choices needed to fulfil it”. He said he wanted Parliament to consider the plans to meet the carbon budget at the same time in any future votes.

Fine, but is he really also proposing making more time available for MPs to examine government policies? The current conduct of the Government suggests not. Even though he was rushed into unveiling his net zero changes a day early, he had always been planning to make that announcement when Parliament was in recess, meaning MPs didn’t have the chance to debate it at all. The Speaker of the House of Commons was furious, issuing an unusually forthright statement in which he said that if he had the power, he would recall the House.

The Prime Minister would never offend his colleagues by saying this, but the public are anyway quite aware that the calibre of politicians isn’t what it should be. There are lots of reasons for this, not least that many talented people wouldn’t want the weird, often dysfunctional life of an MP.

But it is also the case that even the talented folk who do make it into the Palace of Westminster are ill used by a culture  performing what should be one of the primary functions of their job: scrutiny.

Keir Starmer likes to complain about “sticking plaster politics” too, which is less of a surprise coming from the Leader of the Opposition than it is from the man in power. But even he only wants to talk about reforming the House of Lords rather than any proposals to make the House of Commons work better.

That’s because suits the people in power, at least in the short term. In the long term, of course, the problems that might have been raised earlier by a stronger legislature end up biting the government that introduced them.

At this autumn’s conference, Sunak wants to tell his party he is the one prepared to speak hard truths. But a hard truth he doesn’t seem to be prepared to confront himself is that all the things he complains about will just keep happening unless he is prepared to make himself less powerful.
Isabel Hardman is assistant editor of The Spectator magazine

title: Abuse of Power by Theresa May review: Ex-PM leaves no stone unturned, except when it comes to her own failings
lead: In this crisply written book, Theresa May accepts her premiership will be remembered for her failure to deliver Brexit. But we are all only self-aware up to a point
author: Isabel Hardman

body.text: Theresa May’s first speech as Prime Minister promised to tackle the of society, so perhaps it’s no surprise that her book, Abuse of Power, returns to that topic after her premiership was .

Like all ex-prime ministers, she has a few scores to settle, and a few points she wants to make for the record. Unlike her immediate predecessor David Cameron, who actually gave his memoirs the title , she doesn’t seem that interested in recording the day-to-day experience of being in power.

In fairness, not many people would want to recollect in great detail the trauma of that hamstrung parliament, the indicative votes, the weird fairground atmosphere of a Westminster filled with screaming pro- and anti-Brexit protesters. Instead, May has written about the cases of abuse of power she encountered in office. Some are well-understood: , sexual harassment, , Russia’s illegal invasion of Ukraine and so on.

Others are more surprising: as well as arguing that there was an abuse of power from a number of figures, including , while she attempted to lead the country through Brexit, she accuses the US of an abuse of power in its  “by acting in its own interests”.

She finds several themes. One was that people in power rode roughshod over bereaved, injured and traumatised people “because they could”. Many of the chapters finish with that refrain. Another is the desire of public sector institutions to protect their reputations rather than the people they purport to serve.

May tries to be as reflective as possible, accepting that her premiership will largely be remembered for her failure to deliver Brexit, and that the  in which she lost the Conservative majority was her mistake. But of course we are all only self-aware up to a point, and I wonder whether she might also reflect that some might see an attempt at abuse of power in the very act of calling the election.

The Daily Mail wrote this up as “crush the saboteurs”, and those around May boasted at the time of a huge majority that would allow them to do as they pleased. Anyway, the British public clearly thought she didn’t deserve as much power as she already had.

Her travails after losing that majority were also not blameless. The reinstatement of the Conservative whip to two men accused at the time of serious sexual impropriety (since proven in court) – – represented an abuse of power: it was given back to them so they could back her in the vote of no confidence in 2019.

But that’s human nature: even the most self-reflective among us misses things others spot. May’s book is fascinating and crisply written, but it does also suffer from a narrow view of human nature itself: her diagnosis of the problems we have is strong and detailed, her analysis of why they have happened quite good, but her prescription for how to stop abuses of power in the future is weak because it relies too heavily on an assumption that more people could develop the commitment to service she clearly sees as a core part of her identity.

Her concluding chapter is entitled The Answer Is Service, and while it is very good on how too many politicians are careerists and how Parliament doesn’t work to improve the skills or behaviour of its occupants, she is possibly too idealistic about what motivates most people.

Not everyone has the quiet and serious vicarage upbringing May recalls fondly in this book. Indeed, most have a more complex mix of altruism and a desire to be praised and paid well, motivating us to do all kinds of jobs, whether it be MPs, doctors or other public servants.

That May has more seriousness and commitment than the average politician is one of the reasons she hasn’t bustled out of Parliament to earn money elsewhere, like some of her fellow ex-PMs. It also means she has a better chance to fix some of those burning injustices this book shows she is clearly still worried about.

title: Victoria Starmer to stay out of the limelight despite conference appearance with husband Keir
lead: Lady Starmer was pictured taking breakfast with her husband but as so far kept out of the limelight
author: Chloe Chaplain

body.text: Lady Victoria Starmer is not expected to play a central role in the upcoming election campaign despite an appearance on stage with her husband after his
often refers to his wife in speeches and she joined him, to applause, at the end of his address to the conference in Liverpool.

But she has remained largely away from the public limelight and is expected to continue doing so – meaning that in the main she would steer clear of interviews during the campaigning before the general election.
Sir Keir and Lady Starmer posed for pre-speech photos ahead of his conference address on Tuesday, with the couple pictured walking along the Liverpool docks and having breakfast together.
She also joined him on stage after his speech dressed in the Labour Party red.
But unlike Rishi Sunak’s wife, Akshata Murthy, Lady Starmer did not make an introductory speech welcoming Sir Keir to the stage.
The Labour leader references his wife, who works in occupational health in the NHS, when he talks about the need for healthcare reform and recently told .
But she has never spoken publically to the press and, other than the odd photo, remains largely out of the limelight.
Unlike the partners of some other political leaders, Lady Starmer also does not have a formal role in Labour.
Philip May, Theresa May’s husband, and Carrie Johnson both held formal roles in the Conservative Party.
And Sir Ed Davey, the Lib Dem leader, is married to a councillor who represents the party, Emily Gasson.
The Starmers have also been determined to keep their children out of the limelight since he became Labour leader and their names are not public.

Sir Keir told the Mirror that his wife “had her own life and protects it vigorously” and that they were both focused on preparing for the potential impact an election campaign, and possible win, would have on their two children.”

title: ‘Goosebumps’: Labour big beasts say Sir Keir Starmer ready for a decade in power after conference speech
lead: Lord Mandelson says Labour now has enough policy to take into the election and ‘two terms’ of government
author: Arj Singh

body.text: The mood on Tuesday evening at conference stood in stark contrast to the scenes at the Conservatives exactly a week ago.
There in Manchester, Home Secretary Suella Braverman had provoked a major backlash from her own party which saw ministers briefing against their own Government in the conference’s bars and corridors.
A week later and 35 miles away in Liverpool, there was no backbiting as Labour big beast after big beast lined up to lavish praise on .

Blairite grandee , who earlier in the week said the party “needs more than policy tweaks”, told i the Labour leader’s speech included enough concrete proposals “to fill two-terms of a mission driven government”, eyeing a decade in power for Sir Keir.
Shadow Health Secretary  said the speech, which included multiple standing ovations, gave him “goosebumps”, while another senior source said the speech had made them “quite emotional”.

Another insider declared it was “the best I’ve ever seen him” while those close to Sir Keir were pleased to see the leader again turn a protest to his advantage with his cool, sleeves-up response to being , having successfully faced down hecklers in Brighton two years ago during a “wobbly” moment in his leadership.
A backbench Labour MP meanwhile said Sir Keir’s new towns announcement had given them something to “sell on the doorstep” in a city characterised by overcrowded housing.
But while Labour was united, with the prospect of election victory looming ever closer, others sounded a note of caution.
Shadow Science and Technology Secretary Peter Kyle suggested the party was now in an election campaign and it would be tough.

After Sir Keir’s speech, he said: “I’m excited. I’m hopeful. I’m daunted by the prospect that lies ahead because it’s going to be a tough year but I am absolutely hopeful that it can be done, it will be done and there are better days ahead for Britain because of this conference and the agenda set out by Keir Starmer.”

It was a message echoed by the leader: “As for the Tories, I have to warn you, a party that has so completely severed its relationship with the future, that is prepared to scorch the earth just to get at us. They will be dangerous.

“Trust me. Wherever you think the line is, they’ve already got plans to cross it. They will be up for the fight. They’re always up for the fight to save their own skin. And this isn’t over. In fact, it’s barely begun.
“So we have to be disciplined. Focused. Ready to fight back. And confident, conference, because we have come so far, already.”

title: ‘We don’t have time for their student politics’: How Keir Starmer forced Labour’s hard left underground
lead: ‘The left haven’t gone away.’ Starmer’s internal critics are keeping quiet ahead of an election. But they fear his caution will backfire
author: Chloe Chaplain

body.text: A stroll around the  Party conference this year feels very different to those of the recent past.

Activists with flags and protest badges are dramatically reduced in numbers. In their place are serious-looking suited, briefcase-carrying, operators. Any demonstrations that do take place are much quieter and more contained.
They are outward signs that point towards success in the deeper change the party’s leadership has been aiming for.
made promises of “professionalising” Labour – seen by many as code for pushing the left wing of the party to the sidelines – and he has succeeded in a more ruthless manner than many expected.
Labour left MPs have been forced underground by the current leadership’s zero tolerance for anyone dissenting from the party line.

Insiders note that, under Sir Keir, the bar is so low for the party whip to be withdrawn that there is little scope for MPs to make any kind of criticism of the party without finding themselves falling foul of the rules.
And ask those close to the leader and they will tell you they have no interest in engaging with the left-wing faction associated with the former leader
One Labour HQ source told i: “We just don’t have time for them. It’s proper student politics stuff.”
But some suggest that the only thing keeping potential dissenters quiet at the moment is the carrot of an election win and a Labour government.
“The focus is on getting the  out and that is what’s leading to party unity at the moment,” one left wing figure said.

“But as soon as the election is over that will splinter. MPs in marginal seats will start looking around to see what voters in their areas want, and when they are not getting this from the leadership, sparks will fly.”
However it is doubtful that the left will have anything like the power and influence it had under Mr Corbyn, with groups like the grassroots Momentum campaign effectively sidelined.
The group’s co-chair, Hilary Schan, also fears that if Labour does not implement more transformative policies it risks “backlash” and “public anger”.
“What we are getting from Labour is this ‘fiscal responsibility’ but it is a sort of austerity – or conservatism – dressed up as something else,” she told i.

“A lot of people on the left are actually now starting to see that actually, we need to be ready for the inevitable that comes when [Labour] come into government. These policies just aren’t going to cut it. There is going to be backlash and real public anger because they voted for change and the perception will be that nothing is changing.”
She said that many of the issues Momentum campaigns for were actually supported by a broader section of the party, suggesting the push for these issues would not die down as a result.

“When the two-child benefit cap saga unfolded we saw a real cross section across the party opposing it – we were not a lone voice. I think we expect the same whether it’s free school meals, real living wages, and climate.”
But the lack of formal engagement between left-wing voices and the leadership has ultimately extinguished much of their influence.

“It’s just so hard to cut through when you’re not on the front bench,” one Labour left source lamented. But Starmer’s critics are concerned that, in its eagerness to castrate the left, the leadership is confining itself to policies that are too cautious.

“There are the Red Wall-type seats in the south that we have not yet sealed, and the danger for me is that I think we will win the [next] election, but in areas of health, education and industrial action, people want to see significant change, and if they don’t, they will be frustrated,” one MP said.

“This is not a time for the left to be chucking bricks back – but it is critical that we address this. I desperately want Labour to win but with the fiscal restraint we have set out I struggle to see how we will actually do those things voters want.”

The MP said that they had been approached by some on the Tory benches who had not only resigned to losing the election but were also not interested in fighting it because of the considerable challenges ahead for the incoming government to tackle.

“My sense is that there’s a growing group of Conservatives who think it’s the election to lose given how much of a mess everything is – that makes things very unstable and it is a dangerous place for us.”
Another left figure said: “I am worried that we are not offering enough. And there is concern it’s going to be a one-term Labour government.”
But caution prevails. One MP pushed back against the suggestion that left-wingers are waiting for a Labour government, but will then be ready to launch into a row with the leadership over policy.

“People have concerns about some issues, but we don’t want to have those discussions in public – we don’t think it’s the right thing to do,” they said. “I don’t think it is a case of wanting to burst out into the open with a big argument.”
The left is using this time for a sort of “changing of the guard” in the movement, preparing the next generation of left wing leaders to take the helm, one MP said.
The likes of Mr Corbyn and his allies, John McDonnell and the currently suspended Diane Abbott, are long-established veterans of the movement.
Some suggest newer parliamentarians, such as Zarah Sultana, the 29-year-old MP for Coventry South, and Bell Ribeiro-Addy, the 38-year-old member for Streatham, are among those who could step up.
“The left haven’t gone away,” an MP noted. “They’re nearly all standing again, they just need to make sure they don’t get suspended first.”

title: Labour’s maths plan to teach primary pupils about bank accounts and football results
lead: Bridget Phillipson, the shadow Education Secretary, will unveil plans to rival Rishi Sunak’s maths to 18, making the subject an electoral battleground
author: Poppy Wood

body.text: Primary school children will be taught to manage their household budgets, exchange currencies and rank their favourite football teams under Labour’s plans to roll out “real world” maths teaching if it wins the election.
Bridget Phillipson, the shadow Education Secretary, will unveil Labour’s plans to “bring maths to life” in her keynote speech at the party’s annual conference on Wednesday.
She will pitch it as Labour’s alternative to the , which is focused on sixth form pupils and will require all students to take maths until they leave school.
The shadow Education Secretary will say that Labour’s rival scheme would “tackle our chronic cultural problem with maths by making sure it’s better taught at 6, never mind 16”.
Under the plans, Labour would draw up a new curriculum for primary schools in England focused on teaching children “how numeracy is used in the world around them”.

It would see primary school pupils given maths lessons on things like “household budgeting, currency exchange rates when going on holiday, sports league tables and cookery recipes,” Ms Phillipson will announce.
Labour said it would also include bringing elements of , such as using bank accounts and Individual Savings Accounts (ISAs) to teach children about percentages.

Under the current national curriculum in England, children are taught skills such as multiplication and division as early as Year 1, plus measures to describe and compare different quantities including length, mass, volume, time and money.

Teachers are also advised to use pounds and pence to help children calculate different measures, but there is no requirement to teach financial literacy beyond that – though some schools already choose to do so.
Labour said it would overhaul Rishi Sunak’s existing Expert Advisory Group on  to instead focus on primary school maths as a “first priority” if it wins the next general election.
i revealed in August that the group had , in a bid to ensure maths lessons become more “practical” for pupils.
Labour’s maths plans would hinge on “upskilling” non-specialist primary school teachers with the “right skills and knowledge to deliver high class maths teaching”.
It would fund the scheme through its , the party hopes will raise £1.7bn to spend on the state school sector.
Ms Phillipson will say: “In every part of our system, in every year of children’s lives, in every corner of our country, we will be the party of high and rising standards.

“I am determined that Labour will bring maths to life for the next generation. I want the numeracy all our young people need – for life and for work, to earn and to spend, to understand and to challenge. I want that to be part of their learning right from the start.”
It comes as both Labour and the Conservatives gear up to make education a key political battleground in the run up to the next general election, expected in autumn 2024.
Mr Sunak announced  last week as part of his vision for overhauling the education system in England.
In a , the Prime Minister said he would combine A-levels with T-levels, the recently-introduced technical qualifications, into a new post-16 education model.

All students in England would be required to take the new Advanced British Standard at 18 under the scheme, which would see students sit exams for five subjects on average, up from the current average of three.
The Government admitted the scheme would require “long-term reform,” and could take around a decade to deliver “in full”.

Experts said both Labour and the Conservatives’ plans would require a significant boost to teacher recruitment and retention, after 39,930 teachers left the sector last year for reasons other than retirement.

Paul Whiteman, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers (NAHT), said it was important teachers were given the right time and training to implement Labour’s plans for “real world” maths if the party wins the election.
“While this is already a feature of the maths curriculum in many primary schools, we look forward to discussing how this could be developed further,” he said.
“Such a policy must be done with teachers, not to them.”

title: Keir Starmer channels Tony Blair in bid for the centre ground during Labour conference speech
lead: The Labour leader made repeated references to the government of his predecessor and hit out at the legacy of Jeremy Corbyn
author: Hugo Gye

body.text: cast himself as the heir to Sir Tony Blair in a Labour conference speech in which he sought to occupy the middle ground and convince Conservative voters that his party is now better placed to uphold their values.
The Leader of the Opposition repeatedly hit out at the legacy of Jeremy Corbyn as he pledged to support Israel’s right to self-defence and promised to “get Britain building again” by .

The speech in Liverpool was initially  who broke through the security cordon around Sir Keir to throw glitter on him, but the leader claimed the incident only underlined the choice between “protest or power”.

During the , Sir Keir made multiple references to the last Labour government under Sir Tony. He listed its achievements and contrasted them with the current Conservative administration, saying it showed “13 years of ‘things can only get better’ versus 13 years of ‘things have only got worse’.”

The Labour leader defended his predecessor’s policy of pushing for half of all young people to attend university, and warned that the party’s next government would need to combine the attributes of those elected in 1945, 1964 and 1997 by recovering from national trauma, harnessing new technology and rebuilding public services.

A senior party source confirmed that Sir Keir was deliberately drawing parallels with Sir Tony, saying: “The circumstances are different to 1997 but we still believe that the foundations of sound money and public service reform are the key.”
The Leader of the Opposition also used his speech to make a direct appeal to disaffected Tories.

He said: “If you are a Conservative voter who despairs of this, if you look in horror at the descent of your party into the murky waters of populism and conspiracy, with no argument for economic change, if you feel our country needs a party that conserves – that fights for our Union, our environment, the rule of law, family life, the careful bond between this generation and the next – then let me tell you: Britain already has one. And you can join it. It’s this Labour Party.”

But he warned his own side against complacency, saying that the Conservatives are “a party that has so completely severed its relationship with the future, that is prepared to scorch the earth just to get at us. They will be dangerous.”
Sir Keir’s spokesman said after the speech: “The Labour party is in the centre-ground of British politics.
“We are appealing to people from across the political spectrum to look at the agenda we are setting out, the way we want to turn the page on 13 years of decline that we’ve had under the Tories.”
, compared the address to those given by Sir Tony and Gordon Brown when they first took power.
And New Labour grandee Peter Mandelson praised Sir Keir for his “passion and conviction and content and just hard-nosed policy work”.
But Tory chairman Greg Hands said: “Once again, Sir Keir Starmer showed he would take the easy way out on Britain’s long-term challenges.

” On two of the biggest issues facing our country, Labour has nothing to say. Just as Rachel Reeves failed to mention inflation once in her speech, Sir Keir failed to say anything about how he would tackle illegal immigration.”

title: Fourteen policies announced at Labour conference so far
lead: Sir Keir Starmer delivered his leader’s speech on the third day of the Labour Party conference in Liverpool
author: Eleanor Langford

body.text: The highlight of the third day of  was  speech, where he pledged to unlock a “decade of national renewal” if he wins the next election.
His speech, however, was interrupted when a .
The protester was removed by security, and Sir Keir went on to deliver his 55-minute speech as planned, but he was forced to remove his jacket.
One of the key pledges in Sir Keir speech was that he would “tear down” the barriers to homebuilding and would deliver 1.5 million homes in his first five years in power.

The Labour leader also pledged that he would host new, large-scale housing settlements which he dubbed “Labour new towns”, reminiscent of the so-called new towns built after the Second World War under then-Labour PM Clement Attlee.
This pledge was previously discussed by Sir Keir .
i revealed over the weekend that Labour would as part of its plan to tackle the .
He confirmed the party would build on green-belt land, but insisted this would be done responsibly and his party was not “tearing up the green belt”.
Sir Keir said that the NHS would be brought “off its knees” and pledged that Labour would be the party that “finally transforms” the health service.
Labour had , but Sir Keir pledged that the money raised would be funneled back into the NHS.
He also said his party would “guarantee” mental health treatment and consign “dangerous waits” for cancer treatment to history using new technologies like AI.
A Labour government would create new technical excellence colleges to boost skills among young people and create growth in the economy, Sir Keir said.
He said that the generation that sacrificed so much during the pandemic – their potential must be backed”.
Under the plans, existing further education colleges would be updated to form “stronger links to their local economies, planted firmly in the ground of young peoples’ aspirations”.
He also reiterated his plans to , and that the money raised would be used to fund other school services.
Shadow home secretary  pledged during her conference speech that Labour was the “true party of law and order”.
She said that, across a 10-year programme, a Labour government would establish 90 youth hubs with both mental health workers and community workers “to tackle the crisis of youth mental crisis”
Dubbed the Young Futures programme, it would be rolled out in communities that currently face youth crime and violence.
Ms Cooper also said she wanted to “put police back on the beat” and “restore respect for the rule of law”
Another pledge from the Shadow Home Secretary was to put domestic abuse experts in 999 call centres.
“We cannot stand by and let our daughters face the same abuse as our grandmothers,” Ms Cooper said.

“We will require police to use tactics normally reserved for organised crime or terrorism to identify and go after the most dangerous repeat abusers and rapists and get them off our streets,” she said.
Shadow Attorney General  used her speech to talk about “the most widespread, most historic and most entrenched injustice of all – our society’s treatment of women”.
She pledged that a Labour government would bring in new protections for those who reported sexual harassment in the workplace, giving them the same status as whistleblowers.

Ms Thornberry said her party would also bring in new laws to protect women in cohabiting relationships when they left their partner, and strengthen protections for women from stalkers both online and in person.
Shadow Transport Secretary Louise Haigh used her party conference speech to promise a review of the failures of the HS2 rail project and claimed that the Conservative Party “has gone off the rails”.

This was also pledged by shadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves, who pledged on Monday that she would commission an independent expert inquiry into HS2 “to learn the lessons for the future” about how it was managed.
Ms Reeves said a Labour government would keep tabs on the speed and cost of major infrastructure projects by setting up a new, central, cross-departmental infrastructure acceleration unit.

Ms Haigh also pledged to return the ownership of Britain’s buses and trains to the public, claiming that a Labour government would “run a transport system that finally runs with the interests of the public”.
Speaking at a fringe event at the conference on Monday, Ms Haigh also said a Labour government would “bring our railways back into public ownership where they have always belonged”.
Other policies already announced at Labour Party conference include:

Labour will pump £1.1bn into the  to pay doctors and nurses more to work overtime in an attempt to bring down waiting lists.  will rely on staff voluntarily covering extra shifts, but the leadership admitted the payments would be less than can be earnt in the private sector.

The party has announced plans to “build a clean energy grid” to speed up the development of . Labour unveiled plans to speed up National Grid connections as part of plans to use green energy to ease delays in the transition.

It would use its proposed publicly owned energy company – GB Energy – to help secure the supply chains the grid needs to expand, opening the door to future competition to build the grid at the same time.
Labour would introduce a ban on gay conversion therapy that would include protections for people, the party announced.
Shadow Women and Equalities Minister  said the party would bring forward a “no loopholes” ban on the practice – which is when people attempt to supress someone’s sexuality or gender identity.
to toughen up workers’ rights within the first 100 days of taking office.
She said that plans to boost protections for gig workers and enshrine basic employment rights from the first day of starting a job had not been watered down.

Ms Rayner said Labour would close the , make work more family-friendly, and tackle sexual harassment. “And we won’t stop there. We’ll ensure that unions can stand up for their members. We will boost collective bargaining, to improve workers’ pay, terms and conditions,” she added.
Labour announced a sector deal for the automotive industry which promised to secure supply chains and bolster a skilled workforce to supporting British manufacturing.

The party said it would “remove the barriers for consumers to transition and increase demand for electric vehicles”. The deal would generate two million electric cars and create 80,000 jobs, delivering new battery factories and boosting technical courses in colleges around building electric vehicles, Labour says.

Labour announced it would empower the water regulator to ban company bosses from getting their bonus unless they . It would give Ofwat the ability to ban payment of bonuses to water bosses who are found to pump significant levels of raw sewage into rivers, lakes and seas.

title: Starmer targets ‘grey belt’ to deliver highest level of new housing since 1970s
lead: Sir Keir Starmer says he will ‘bulldoze’ planning restrictions to deliver new housing
author: Richard Vaughan

body.text: believes it will deliver the highest level of  since the early 70s within five years if it comes to power.
Sir Keir Starmer promised to build 1.5m homes, some of which will be in newly created towns, within his first term in parliament should he succeed in becoming elected.
, the Labour leader pledged to “bulldoze” through restrictions to housebuilding by setting out wide-ranging reforms to the planning system.

Sir Keir said the system was “a blockage that stops this country building roads, grid connections, laboratories, trainlines, warehouses, windfarms, power stations” and “an obstacle to the aspirations of millions”.
The plan to “get Britain building again” would “fight the blockers who hold a veto over British aspiration”, he added.
The 1.5 million homes promised would also involve new development corporations with powers to cut through red tape and the creation of the “next generation of Labour new towns”.

Speaking after the speech, Labour sources refused to state how many houses the party would build every year, but one senior source added: “It will definitely ramp up over time because we’ll be bumping along the bottom for a bit if we inherit the mess we will inherit.”
Another source said the housing plans would have “an exponential curve” to them, meaning a future Labour government will have to deliver well over 300,000 houses a year by the end of the parliament.
The last time the UK built more than 300,000 homes was back in the early 70s, with the peak of 425,000 houses delivered in 1968.
Under the plans, Labour will devolve more decision making over planning to local mayors, while also creating a new “planning passport” that will fast-track development on urban brownfield land.
Sir Keir also pledged to protect the green belt, but said areas such as car parks and wasteland, which he dubbed the ‘grey belt’ would be built on.

The party will also give first time buyers “first dibs” on small portions of new housing developments and offer them a new state-backed mortgage insurance scheme, based on models used in Australia and Canada.
The announcement comes after  unveiled plans this week to provide 300 extra planning officers and to force local authorities to quickly draw up local plans to deliver more housing.

But industry sources raised doubts that the measures would have the impact Labour have claimed, with one source telling i: “It is difficult to see how one planning officer per local authority would accelerate the local plan process which is famously difficult to do.”
The proposals were widely welcomed by the sector, however.

Kate Henderson, Chief Executive of the National Housing Federation, said: “Building new towns provides the opportunity to create high quality places with ambitious sustainability standards, much-needed affordable homes and better use of infrastructure. The post-war New Towns Programme has shown that building new communities can be good for the economy as well as society.”

Martin McTague, National Chair of the Federation of Small Businesses added: “Proposals to build the next generation of new towns will help the UK on its path to global competitiveness. This level of ambition can only be achieved by unleashing the potential of small housebuilding firms.”

title: Keir Starmer is the master of all he surveys in Labour, but his hold on the public is still fragile
lead: The Labour leader was acclaimed by his party’s activists in a sign they believe he will take them into power
author: Hugo Gye

body.text: Few party conference speeches of recent years have had a  than Sir Keir Starmer’s.
He was treated to  – including when he repeatedly denounced the record of Labour under the leadership of Jeremy Corbyn.
Sir Keir has stepped up his rhetorical game. He is less wooden than when he , more accomplished at riding waves of applause to display the passion that he has previously struggled to project.

And he has fleshed out his broad vision with more policy specifics than ever before,as the big issue which can put clear dividing lines between Labour and the Conservatives at the next election without retreating to hoary old left v right debates.

But he can’t get carried away. The rousing reception for Sir Keir was not because he has suddenly ascended to Obama levels of speechifying, but because the party faithful are simply desperate to win – and , they think they will.

Contrast. It was just as substantial, with major policy announcements and a new philosophical direction for the Conservatives. And Mr Sunak’s own rhetorical skills are about the same as Sir Keir’s. But the sheer political reality means that Tory activists were nowhere near as fired up as Labour’s are now.

The challenge for Sir Keir now is to keep it up for another year or more, until the next election. Conservative strategists are already crawling all over every single Labour policy announcement looking for flaws and the scrutiny will only increase.

Labour still has some fundamental weaknesses in the eyes of the public – even though millions of voters have turned away from the Tories, many still fear that Labour cannot be trusted to look after the economy. Sir Keir and Rachel Reeves, the shadow Chancellor, hammer home their message of fiscal responsibility at every opportunity and have trimmed their policy ambitions to reduce the chances of tripping up.

After more than a decade of bitter civil war within the Labour party, it is now the Tories tearing themselves apart. In Liverpool, Sir Keir is the undisputed master of all he surveys within Labour. Mr Corbyn, who does not have a pass to attend conference, seems a distant memory.
This is a remarkable achievement – but the Labour leader still has a long way to go before he finally seals the deal with the public and returns his party to government at last.

title: Flying the Palestinian flag could be illegal in some circumstances, Braverman tells police chiefs
lead: The minister said that while there were legitimate circumstances for demonstrating support for Palestinians, some behaviour crossed over into breaches of the Terrorism Act and the Public Order Act
author: Jane Merrick

body.text: Home Secretary  has written to all chief constables in England and Wales asking them to consider chants such as “from the river to the sea, Palestine will be free” and waving Palestinian flags in Jewish areas as criminal offences.
The minister said that while there were legitimate circumstances for demonstrating support for Palestinians, some behaviour crossed over into breaches of the Terrorism Act and the Public Order Act.
Police forces should use the “full force of the law” to prevent harassment of the UK’s Jewish community in the wake of the , Ms Braverman said.
Her letter follows a protest by pro-Palestinian supporters outside the Israeli embassy in Kensington on Monday evening, at which the chant “from the river to the sea” was heard.

Mrs Braverman said this phrase “should be understood as an expression of violent desire to see Israel erased”. The slogan is routinely used to refer to a unified Palestine state from the River Jordan to the Mediterranean Sea.

In her letter, the Home Secretary referred to offences under the Terrorism Act relating to organisations proscribed in the UK such as militant group Hamas, including their amplification and glorification.

Police should not only consider pro-Hamas symbols and chants as cause for concern, but possible offences under section 5 of the 1986 Public Order Act, which prohibit causing harassment, alarm or distress, if protesters were specifically targeting Jewish communities.

While the waving of a Palestinian flag on its own would not be considered a crime, doing so in a way that targets Jewish people, or “aggressively chant or wave pro-Palestinian symbols at” could be considered by police as harassment, the minister said.

The Home Secretary wrote: “I would encourage police to consider whether chants such as ‘From the river to the sea, Palestine will be free’ should be understood as an expression of a violent desire to see Israel erased from the world, and whether its use in certain contexts may amount to a racially aggravated Section 5 public order offence.
“I would encourage police to give similar consideration to the presence of symbols such as swastikas at anti-Israel demonstrations. Context is crucial.
“Behaviours that are legitimate in some circumstances, for example the waving of a Palestinian flag, may not be legitimate such as when intended to glorify acts of terrorism.

“Nor is it acceptable to drive through Jewish neighbourhoods, or single out Jewish members of the public, to aggressively chant or wave pro-Palestinian symbols at. Where harassment is identified, I would encourage the police to take swift and appropriate enforcement action.”

All senior officers should ensure that any protests which could “exacerbate community tensions by way of offensive placards, chants or behaviours that could be construed as incitement or harassment, have a strong police presence to ensure perpetrators are appropriately dealt with, and that communities feel protected”.

Ms Braverman said decisions on arrests are “rightly an operational matter for the police, in line with the duty to keep the peace, to protect communities, and to prevent the commission of offences”, but she added: “However I would urge you to ensure your forces use all available powers to prevent disorder and distress to our communities, and that your officers will act if there are any incidents that stray into criminality.”

It is not known whether the use of flags in a provocative manner have been previously prosecuted under the Public Order Act. However there are other circumstances where people have been arrested or prosecuted under this legislation for using symbols or images to deliberately cause harassment or distress.

Earlier this month a Sheffield Wednesday fan was charged under the Public Order Act for mocking the death of six-year-old Sunderland supporter and cancer sufferer Bradley Lowery, in a photo posted on social media.

And this summer a Manchester United fan was arrested on suspicion of public order offences for wearing a shirt with “97 Not Enough” on the back, in reference to the number of people killed in the Hillsborough disaster.

A spokesperson for the Community Security Trust said: “There is a growing problem of people harassing and intimidating Jewish people by shouting ‘Free Palestine’ at them or driving through Jewish community areas waving Palestinian flags in a deliberately hostile way.

“This is a new form of hate crime that causes immense anger and fear in Jewish communities and we welcome the fact that the Home Secretary is encouraging police forces to look at exactly where the threshold lies between freedom of expression and hate crimes, and to prosecute wherever someone steps across that line. It is what our community expects and deserves.”

title: Chelsea will never see another Eden Hazard, the last of the elite unprofessionals
lead: Hazard played football because it was fun, not for money or glory – that’s why he had to retire at 32
author: George Simms

body.text: We are gathered here today to talk about joy. We are gathered here to talk about involuntary grinning and gasping, about the unfathomable, ineffable beauty of short, sharp lateral movements, about whether talent can ever be truly natural.

We are gathered here today to talk about , the premier exponent and bringer of joy of his footballing era. Without a club since leaving  in the summer, his early retirement became a tragic inevitability.
He confirmed it on Tuesday aged 32, saying: “You must listen to yourself and say stop at the right time. I was able to realise my dream, I have played and had fun on many pitches around the world.”

Of course, the pitch on which Hazard had the most fun, brought the most joy, was Stamford Bridge, that Garden of Eden. It’s easy to reel off the facts and figures – 110 goals, 92 assists, two Premier Leagues, two Europa Leagues, one of each domestic cup trophy.

He earned 126 Belgium caps, 33 international goals, and one  Silver Ball. He led Lille to their first French title since 1954 and won Ligue 1 player of the season twice. The numbers are indomitably impressive, yet still do this gluteally-gifted house of fun a gross disservice.

At his best, Hazard toyed with your conception of the possible. He ran with the ball as if he had a mental switch which allowed him to manipulate time at will, accelerate it for himself and halt it for others, as though he could flick through a flipbook of potential outcomes quicker than anyone else on earth, and invariably choose the right one.

He joined a Roberto Di Matteo side that had just won the   and was simply, instantly, better than everyone else. He would go on to prove himself the most talented footballer ever to represent Chelsea. He was also perhaps the last truly great yet truly unprofessional professional.

Chelsea teammate John Obi Mikel called Hazard the laziest footballer he had ever encountered, and said “he never trained”. He called Chelsea’s training ground the “Cobham Cabana”. Filipe Luis said he “didn’t run to defend much, didn’t train well and five minutes before games he’d be playing Mario Kart in the dressing room”. , his coach from 2013-15, said “He is not from these times. He’s from the old times.”

There’s this lingering regret that had Hazard trained harder, wanted it more, not enjoyed hamburgers and holidays and happiness quite so much, he would have been a superior player. Yet you couldn’t have the freedom, the grand spontaneity, the unbearable lightness of being Eden Hazard, if you suddenly transformed him into a Cristiano Ronaldo-esque mentality monster. He was utterly unique exactly because he was so unashamedly himself.

Despite his non-conformist tendencies, he was no bad boy. He wasn’t a diver on the pitch, which could have been excused for the most-fouled player during his time in the Premier League, nor was he was an agitator off it.

Maurizio Sarri, under whom Hazard played some of his best football, said: “It is easy to stimulate him, as long as you let him have fun. He doesn’t get influenced by the media and what happens around him.”
Time under a tactical autocrat like Pep Guardiola may well have quashed his spirit, as his four-year Real Madrid stint did.

As he said upon signing, he wasn’t a Galactico, he was just a very good footballer. If you wanted Hazard to be anything other than what he was, if you loved the idea more than the man, flaws and all, you couldn’t truly benefit from the positives.

And what positives they were. No-one stopped quite like Hazard, spring-load started quite so cleanly and abruptly, simply thought and functioned quite as quickly and quirkily. His greatest goals, greatest moments, jinking past whole teams or rocket-launching from 30 yards, are all connected by a mutual brilliance.

He excelled when he could bend the boundaries of the extraordinary, when the lights were brightest and the opponents toughest. Watching Hazard at his best made you breathe faster, then forget to breathe altogether. With his feet, his mind and his ample bum, he could induce eerie silence or euphoric pandemonium.

Hazard’s career wasn’t about money, but neither was it about glory. He played football with the sole aim of maximising both his potential joy and the joy of others, and has retired for the same reason.

As elite football becomes increasingly homogenised towards professionalism and perfection, there may never be another quite like Hazard, the on-pitch heir of Ronaldinho, of Maradona, of Mane Garrincha.

Mourinho once called him better than Ronaldo but inferior to Messi. Yet really, he was just Eden, an accessible god, a relatable deity, both human and superhuman. He played football just because it was fun. Now the fun’s stopped, he’s stopped with it. He’ll find it somewhere else.

title: Olympics set to feature ‘Ninja Warrior’ obstacle course and laser guns as updated modern pentathlon survives
lead: The modern pentathlon has responded to criticism in Tokyo by working to remove showjumping and air pistols from its format
author: James Gray

body.text: The  is set to feature a Ninja Warrior-style obstacle course and laser guns from 2028 in a revamped modern pentathlon.
Pentathlon had  from the Olympics after a coach punched a horse at Tokyo 2020 but i understands it has been given a stay of execution after dropping showjumping and pistol shooting.
It is expected to be given the go-ahead at an International Olympic Committee (IOC) board meeting this week before receiving the formal green light from a wider IOC session in Mumbai.

The new-look event will still feature swimming, fencing and running, but has replaced showjumping with an obstacle course and instead of firing air pistols, athletes will use laser guns to hit targets.
The sport was forced into considering changes after controversy erupted at the delayed Games in Tokyo two years ago when for punching a horse in frustration.
The showjumping element of competition traditionally allots athletes a randomly assigned horse, often with disastrous results due to the unfamiliarity between rider and mount.

Germany’s Annika Schleu was in tears during her riding segment in Tokyo after her horse Saint Boy crashed into the fifth fence and then repeatedly refused to jump. Schleu’s coach Kim Raisner was caught on camera striking the horse with her fist and was thrown out of the Games, but the impact of the incident was far-reaching.
For the 2024 Paris Olympics, modern pentathlon will remain in its current form, before the revamp ahead of the 2028 Los Angeles Games.

It prompted soul-searching within the sport’s governing body, the Union Internationale de Pentathlon Moderne (UIPM), which feared it could be removed from the Olympics altogether. Its executive board voted to replace the riding element of the event just three months after the Games in Tokyo.

The modern pentathlon will remain in its original format at the Olympics next year, the last time that showjumping will be included going forward. Instead, the changes to the sport have seen the UIPM introduce an obstacle course that was tested last year and will be fully included after Paris 2024.

At a test event in Ankara last year, the course shared many elements with the Ninja Warrior TV show, including monkey bars, spinning wheels, large hurdles, balance beams and a warped wall to run up at the end.

The laser gun element will be combined with the run at the end of the event, with athletes required to shoot at targets 10 metres away with a specially designed laser pistol, which is safer and allows children to compete in the grass-roots events.

The format has already been through the rigour of the Olympic programme commission, a 24-strong committee responsible for analysing sports and upholding “the fundamental core of the Olympic Games” and it is expected that the executive board and IOC sessions will concur with their decision to green-light the new-look sport, which has evolved since but was in fact part of the ancient Olympics in Greece.

Boxing and weightlifting have also had to go through the same process after being stripped of Olympic status since Tokyo 2020 due to governance and doping issues respectively. i understands both sports have been told to expect a positive outcome at the session.

The IOC will also rubber-stamp the acceptance of cricket, squash, lacrosse, flag football and baseball/softball for the 2028 Los Angeles Games this weekend, all put forward by the American organisers, but there appears to be no room for breakdancing, one of the new sports at the Paris Olympics.
The event is part of the ongoing effort to modernise the Olympic movement and was well-received at the European Games this summer in Poland, where more than 3,000 people turned out for the final.

But it appears to have lost out in negotiations between LA bosses and the IOC, who are already having to balance the difficulties of 36 sports at one Games, which may mean several core sports being asked to trim their numbers.

title: Dawid Malan gets England’s Cricket World Cup back on track and proves dropping Jason Roy was right call
lead: Powered by Dawid Malan’s highest ODI score of 140, England cruised to victory after setting Bangladesh a record World Cup run chase of 365
author: Chris Stocks

body.text: DHARAMSHALA — This was just what  needed after  in Ahmedabad last Thursday.
Efficient, with flashes of occasional brilliance would be the best summary of a performance  off the foot of the points table.
It was built on the foundation of a fine career-best ODI century  that helped the defending champions set Bangladesh a record World Cup run chase of 365.

Reece Topley, overlooked for the first game, then fully justified his recall with a haul of four for 43 with the ball to ensure a stress-free finish to a match against underrated but dangerous opponents.
