Earlier this year, the British Secretary of State for Northern Ireland Chris Heaton-Harris suggested the UK government would also assist, but any details on that contribution have not yet been confirmed. i has approached the UK’s Northern Ireland Office for comment.
The development of Casement Park has become politically charged.

Until its amendment in 2005, the GAA’s “Rule 42” prohibited the playing of non-Gaelic sports in its stadia. Casement Park is situated in the predominantly nationalist area of Anderstown. Windsor Park, which hosts Northern Ireland’s home matches, is in a unionist area of the city. Even the name “Casement Park” is taken from the Irish revolutionary Roger Casement.

The new Casement Park will have to cross sectarian divides – but the situation has been further complicated by Stormont’s latest collapse. The has been  in protest at post-Brexit trade agreements and under the terms of the , power-sharing cannot function without one or the other of its major parties.
Stormont has therefore struggled to commit to more costs, with no Minister to lead the way. In the meantime, it will fall to the civil servants who are holding the fort.

There had previously been plans to build a new multi-purpose stadium on the site of the old Maze prison. Those proved controversial, given the facility was mainly used to hold paramilitary prisoners during the Troubles.

Casement Park’s renovation has also been met with opposition from Northern Ireland’s main supporters’ group, who released a statement saying that “football tournaments should be hosted by football stadia”.  In response, Northern Ireland manger Michael O’Neill has described hosting Euro 2028 there as a “fantastic opportunity”.

The hope was that the saga would be resolved by the summer of 2023 – and yet work has not even begun. In August, one of the lead contractors behind the project, the Buckingham Group, brought in administrators due to financial difficulties.
i has been told the new aim is to have it completed by 2026, two years before Euro 2028.

title: ‘I’m not going to university because of the cost – why start your adult life in debt?’
lead: Jake Gibbs, 19, opted to set up his own business instead of going to university and starting his working life in debt
author: Callum Mason

body.text: Jake Gibbs is “definitely not” going to university, and says one of the main reasons is the cost.
The 19-year-old budding entrepreneur, from Chichester, West Sussex, says he “simply can’t understand why you should start the beginning of your adult life in debt”.

Those going to university this year are facing paying their  and additional living  due to to changes to student loan rules. And Jake says that financially speaking, he doesn’t think hemorrhaging a chunk of his pay packet every month for decades to come is worth it.
After leaving school last year, he founded his own business – J and J Marketing – which helps other businesses sell products through social media videos.

“I calculated where my business could be in five years and where I would be in five years with a university degree in business. I’m one and a half years in and I know for sure I have made the right decision and calculated everything down to a tee.
“I don’t think starting my business three years later with more than £27,000 in debt would have been a good decision for me,” he says.

Research from Gen Z financial literacy platform  has found that more than a third (34 per cent) of young people across the country have considered not going to university because of the cost of living crisis and high fees.

Although student debt is not like traditional debt – in that you only have to pay it back if you earn a certain amount and it discharges after a fixed period of time – it can still be a financial burden.
Those going to university in England this year will repay 9 per cent of their salary over £25,000 towards their loan, and will do so for 40 years, or until the debt is repaid.
Jake says high fees are a big factor in many people’s decisions not to go to university, but also cites rising costs.

“I think the more recent reason people are not going is because of the. This makes people not want to get into debt and instead start working and start saving for a house deposit. I can really see why more and more people are deciding not to go,” he says.
Students get maintenance loans on top of their tuition fee loans in order to cover the cost of attending university, but these have not kept at pace with inflation.
This year for example, students saw a 2.8 per cent increase in the amount they received from a maintenance loan, falling well below inflation, which is 6.8 per cent.

And Marco Logiudice, co-founder at Prograd, which connects students with “side-hustles” and student jobs, added: “A student loan just isn’t enough to cover the cost of university anymore. Education should be about knowledge, not about financial burden.”
But Jake has said that he preferred to work full-time, rather than doing so alongside studying.

“I have no degree in marketing or in business but still have a successful company at the age of 19. If I went to university, I would not even be halfway through my degree yet and would probably have a part-time job, with little amounts of money.”
Jake’s concerns about the affordability of university echo those expressed by headteachers as well.

Earlier this summer, Robin Bevan, headteacher at Southend High School for Boys, told i: “The top questions from sixth form students looking to apply for university used to be about the course of study, grade requirements and opportunities for their preferred social activities. Today, they ask about access to cheap student accommodation, the cost of rent, and how to fund tuition fees.”
And an i investigation in August found many universities were not helping the matter by .
But the government has defended its record on supporting students, saying it was making £276 million available this academic year, which institutions “can use to top up their own hardship schemes”.

title: Banks are pulling their best savings accounts – act fast to get the highest rate
lead: Savers may have to secure deals now before they disappear from the market
author: Grace Gausden

body.text: Savers are being urged to lock in longer-term savings deals now after the top rates have started to be pulled from the market.
Last week, the Treasury-owned bank NS&I was the first major bank to pull its best-buy savings account paying 6.2 per cent – the highest amount a saver could receive since 2008.

The rate, for a one-year fixed-rate bond, had been available for just over a month, and had seen more than a quarter of a million people pour their money into the account, which had come close to matching inflation for the first time in years.

Other banks followed suit – Oxbury Bank, which pulled its one-year fixed deal offering 6.11 per cent, while Nottingham’s Beehive one-year deal giving returns of 6.1 per cent is also no longer available.

Meanwhile, the International Monetary Foundation released a report this week saying that it expected the UK to see higher interest rates for five years, analysis that hadn’t yet had the chance to take into account the impact of a war in the Middle East will have.
So what should your savings strategy be in uncertain geopolitical and economic times?
Experts say that despite longer-term fixed rates currently paying less than shorter term fixed deals, it is still likely to be worthwhile locking in for a longer time.

The best five-year deal is with JN Bank – Jamaica National Bank – offering 5.8 per cent followed by Cynergy Bank offering 5.75 per cent. Both are lower than the best one-year deal, which is with Al Rayan Bank paying 6.12 per cent. The Union Bank of India follows closely behind at 6.11 per cent.
But fixing for longer could still make sense, Anna Bowes of Savings Champion said.

“The fact that longer-term bonds are paying less than short-term ones makes it clear that the market expects the base rate to fall in the future. Although you can get a better return in the short term by locking in for a year or so, you are likely to get a better deal overall by locking in for the longer term.

“This is because rates are expected to fall. So, for example, currently the best five-year deal is 5.8 per cent with JN Bank. If inflation comes close to its target of 2 per cent, you will be earning more than inflation.
“By the time your short-term bond comes to an end, even if it has higher returns, when it comes to finding a new deal, it will likely be much lower.”
Ultimately, she said, it is probably worth having both a long and shorter-term account.

James Blower, founder of Savings Guru, said: NS&I withdrawing their bonds means we will see one year rates fall back towards 6 per cent and ultimately we expect them to go below this level by the end of the year.
“I’d suggest savers take fixed rates now, as we see no reasons at all why fixed savings rates will do anything but fall over the next few months.”
If you are unable to lock your money away for years on end, then there are still other options.
The best easy-access account is offered by Coventry Building Society, at 5.2 per cent, which is still decent.

Other banks are also offering switching bonuses which could increase your funds. First Direct is offering new customers £175 cash plus 7 per cent on its regular saver account. To receive the bonus you need to pay a minimum of £1,000 into your new account within three months of opening.
TSB is also offering an £150 cash bonus plus £10 per month cashback for six months when people join its Spend & Save account.
Nationwide’s Flex Regular Saver offers 8 per cent and a bonus switching offer of £200. Your money will be locked away for a year, although you’re allowed three withdrawals over that time.

Switching could make you more than a high-rate fixed account. Those putting away £1,000 will earn  £61.20 on the best one-year bond with Al Rayan Bank and £58 per year on the best five-year bond with JN Bank, with no switching bonuses.
But with the First Direct account you would make a total of £245, including the bonus; TSB would be £178.90.

Premium Bonds could also be an option. They are an investment product issued by NS&I where you are entered into a monthly prize draw where you can win between £25 and £1m tax free. The estimated prize rate is 4.65 per cent – it’s not guaranteed, but that is what is a typical return, you have the chance of making up to £1m if your  bond gets picked by Ernie. And you can deposit as much money as you like and it will be guaranteed if NS&I goes bust.

An Isa lets you earn tax-free interest on your savings. You can split your allowance across several types of Isas in each tax year including cash Isas. The current annual Isa allowance for the 2023/24 tax year is £20,000.
Savers will generally earn less interest with a cash Isa compared to a normal savings account in return for being tax free.

With Isas, you put money in and it earns some interest, on which you pay no tax. But since 2016, we have had a personal allowance on savings, which means you can make £1,000 interest in a non-Isa savings account without paying tax.
In the past few years,  very few people ever got above £1,000 interest on their savings. And guess what? The banks paid you less interest on your Isa than they paid you on a non-Isa.

Interest rates have gone up, but even so, unless you’ve got a large amount of money – tens of thousands of pounds – you will still be better off in the non-Isa. The exceptions are people who pay higher rate tax, or those who have a lot of savings and have used up their allowance, which is £500 for a higher-rate tax payer.
Most people’s incomes are too low, so Isas are a waste of time. And the financial industry won’t tell you about this.

Currently, the average one-year fixed cash Isa rate is 5.27 per cent, although the best deal is with Virgin Money at 5.85 per cent. The average easy-access Isa rate is 3.28 per cent but Stafford Railway Building Society is offering a return of 5.25 per cent.

The NS&I rate represented how much rates had improved after bank bosses were quizzed by MPs and the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA), following increases to mortgage rates while savings rates remained near static.
Lenders admitted they “needed to do more”, according to the FCA, and they increased rates accordingly, bringing them to the highest level in a decade.
It sparked competition in the market, leading more people to switch accounts, increasing from 105,300 made in May to 114,139 made in June, according to the Current Account Switch Service.

However, after the Bank of England opted to pause increasing interest rates last month, there has been an expectation that banks offering the most generous savings accounts would start cutting their rates.
It is expected that more banks and building societies will soon follow suit and either withdraw or reduce their offerings in the coming weeks.
Bowes said: “There has been a noticeable number of the best buy one-year bonds that have been withdrawn since the NS&I Guaranteed Growth Bond was withdrawn.

“The introduction of the NS&I deal seemed to generate competition which kept the top rates on offer artificially high. Just before the bond was withdrawn on Thursday, the average of the top five was 6.12 per cent and today it’s 6.06 per cent. I expect things could start to drift further down going forward.”

She added: “With market expectations that the base rate is near the peak, the competition that we have seen could soon start to wane. Those who opt to lock some of their cash away for the longer term might find themselves earning more in the long run – and if inflation does fall to closer to the 2 per cent target, importantly your cash savings could be earning more than inflation.”

title: ‘We just thought F**ck it’:  The rise of friends buying a home together to get on the property ladder
lead: Mortgage Mates is a growing trend as seven per cent of all prospective homebuyers now plan to buy with a friend
author: Charlotte Gill

body.text: “F**k it”, is the conclusion Will Mayrick, 25, a TV producer, and his housemate Jacob Little, who works for an airline, 29, came to one day, when deciding to get a together. They had been housemates for around six years and both wanted to buy. When a friend pointed out they get on so well, happily  in all that time, the logic of teaming up seemed obvious. Since then they have been looking around  for a two-bed.
Will and Jacob are far from anomalies. The housing crisis has given rise to a new phenomenon of “mate mortgages”; friends teaming up to get on the ladder.

While it’s more common to think of joint mortgages between romantic partners, according to data from the Mortgage Advice Bureau, seven percent of all prospective homebuyers now plan to buy with a , rising to 23 percent for 18-24 year olds. Ben Thompson, its Deputy CEO, says the attraction is “especially true when the potential of owning with friends is weighed against the alternative option of sharing ever-increasing rent payments with them.”
Miles Sandys, 26, and Katya Sparrow, 23, both single, have been living together for almost a year, after meeting each other at work and becoming friends.

“We lived quite close by” in Peterborough, Miles tells me, “so we spent a lot of time driving in to work together.” Both were keen to move out from their parents to London. Soon they hashed out a plan, finding Shared Ownership through Peabody most suitable for their financial circumstances.

Currently they pay 25 per cent of the price (£187,000 of a £750,000 flat), having put down a deposit of 10 percent (£18,700) and spending around £2/300 in various fees and stamp duty. Their combined annual income is about £80k, and they spend £1,690 per month on their mortgage, rent and service charge. Even if the latter charges rise, Miles says it’s still a “nice deal for us”, particularly when you look at what others pay to rent.

Miles and Katya haven’t discussed what would happen if one of them moved out or found a partner, but Miles adds “we’re quite young” and some of his friends in long-term relationships aren’t living together yet; in other words, he and Katya envisage staying put for a while. They ultimately see their mortgage as more sensible than giving their well-earned money to landlords.

Similarly, Will and Jacob are relaxed about the possibility of one of them moving out. “I think people make it out to be a bigger deal than it is… you have to sell the house. It’s not the end of the world”, says Jacob. That or the housemates can find a new person to take on one half of the mortgage. “People are queuing around the block in London to be able to rent”, says Will.

Like Miles and Katya, Danielle Watts, a 26-year-old , used a scheme to get on the housing, via Fairview New Homes, moving in with a friend. She had saved as much as she could, “picking up extra shifts in my role as a nurse throughout the Covid-19 pandemic”, but was unable to buy solo. Having previously paid £980 per month for one room in a five-bed house, she says she’s now paying half of that, and would have buddied up “way earlier” if she had known how easy the process would be.

Emma Fildes, a property buying agent and adviser, is generally wary of shared ownership schemes, but agrees that “buying with a friend makes a lot of sense”. She adds “you need to set out a clear cohabitation agreement with a solicitor that clarifies who’s responsible for what and get out clauses and mechanisms to do this. Without it, friendships could be tested.”

Ben Thompson recommends that “it’s essential to not make any quick decisions and really take the time to consider who would be a sensible individual to buy with. Consider, for example, how well you know an individual, their financial circumstances, credit history, and your relationship with them.”

By all indications, it’s advice that will become more pertinent in the future. This week, the Home Builders Federation (HBF) found that England has the lowest percentage of vacant homes per capita in the OECD, with a quarter of private renters “overburdened” by housing costs. The executive chair of the HBF warned of “the urgent need to act now”.

Some aren’t waiting to find out what will happen next. During the course of writing this piece, Will and Jacob have had their offer accepted on a flat in Battersea, south-west London, much to their delight. With so many unknowns in the housing market, a friend can offer much-needed predictability.

title: I lost £3,500 on a funeral plan through One Life two years ago… and still have not received a penny back
lead: Many have lost thousands of pounds to funeral plan firms that have got into administration
author: James Daley

body.text: In October 2021, Sijuwade Olaniyi – a carer from Barnet, north London – decided to buy a funeral plan. She had seen several friends and people she cared for die over the pandemic and wanted to make sure that, when her time came,

After doing some research on the internet, she came across One Life. A company that offered affordable funeral plans . The website looked very credible, so, persuaded, she made 12 payments of £304.17 over the next year – a total of £3,650.
“I was so happy,” said Sijuwade. “I called my son and my family – and I told them it was all taken care of. They didn’t need to worry about anything.”
But just a few weeks after her final payment was taken, she heard that the funeral plan company  was going into administration –

Over the course of the next seven months, her worst fears were realised. Not only had One Life gone bust – but by July 2023, as the administration drew to a close, she received a letter of customers’ money was gone.

Sijuwade later found out that she was one of 13,700 One Life customers – some of whom paid over £10,000 to the company to buy funeral plans for their whole family. Another funeral plan company, Safe Hands, collapsed earlier in 2022 leaving almost 46,000 customers out of pocket.

Why she wouldn’t see any of her money back is that, until July 2022, funeral plan companies were not fully regulated by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA). Laws created in 2000 stated that companies could be exempt from full regulation if they followed a handful of rules relating to how they looked after customers’ money.

This included things like needing to place the money in a life insurance policy, or a trust. If in a trust, firms needed to appoint independent trustees, actuaries, and fund managers to take care of the money.

When these laws were created, the funeral plan market was fairly small – around 50,000 plans a year – and mostly sold by funeral directors. But by the middle of the previous decade, dozens of new funeral plan firms had emerged, with sales swelling to more than 200,000.

Fairer Finance, a research and ratings agency that I founded that looks to help consumers make more informed decisions, wrote a research report raising concerns about some of the new firms in the market.

It said that as well as using cold calls and high-pressure sales tactics to offload the plans, many firms were also taking very large commissions and investing customers’ money in ways that suggested they may not be following the laws laid down in the early 2000s.

After being sent to the Treasury, along with campaigns from other firms, new laws came into force in July 2022. It means that, for anyone buying a funeral plan nowadays, there are now much tougher rules which mean their money will be safe. If a firm were to go bust, customers are protected by the Financial Services Compensation Scheme.
But this wasn’t the case when Sijuwade bought her plan, though the FCA had a responsibility to police the old rules – and ensure that funeral plans were looking after customers’ money.

Quite how well it policed these rules is up for debate. The FCA has now admitted that in 2014 when Safe Hands was set up, its unauthorised business unit engaged with the company and raised concerns about whether it was following the rules. It found that its fund manager did not have the right permissions to manage the trust’s money – and forced them to appoint someone else.
However, it seems that while the FCA took early action, it didn’t move again after further concerns were raised in 2017.

In the case of One Life, the firm was set up at the end of 2020 – by which time, the process of bringing the whole funeral plan sector under full FCA supervision was well under way. But it would seem they also didn’t take any action until it was too late. A final notice stating that One Life would not be able to become FCA regulated was issued in July 2022, nine months after it had submitted its application.

In those nine months alone, many millions more pounds worth of plans were sold. Given the that One Life submitted its application in October 2021, why was the alarm not raised at that moment? If it had been, customers like Sijuwade would have lost no more than a few hundred pounds.

The FCA said: “Before regulation came in, we had limited powers to intervene in this market. One Life was not FCA authorised. Where firms were not authorised prior to the 29 July 2022 deadline, HM Treasury granted an extension for firms to transfer their books to an authorised provider until 31 October 2022. Firms covered by this extension were not authorised by the FCA and were outside our regulation.”
The Parliamentary Ombudsman is now starting to look at Safe Hands – and it is vital that parliamentarians continue to investigate what happened here.

Unfortunately, although new rules are now in place, this doesn’t help people like Sijuwade who bought their plan prior to these being enforced. Thousands will have been affected, many of who will have also lost thousands of pounds and still not have any money put aside for their funerals.
As well as compensation for the victims, there needs to be accountability for the failures – and potentially a change to laws and protocol to enable regulators to act more quickly.

If you’re a customer, you may still be able to get your money back if you paid by card by calling on the chargeback scheme. Talk to your bank – and don’t let them fob you off by telling you it’s too late. The time limits on chargeback claims should not apply for services that were pre-ordered. If your bank rejects your claim, then escalate it to the Financial Ombudsman Service.

If you paid by bank transfer or direct debit – then there’s no easy way to claim your money back. But you can still complain to the Treasury, and escalate your complaint to the Parliamentary Ombudsman once it is rejected. And you can complain to the FCA and escalate your complaint to the Complaints Commissioner. There are Facebook sites for both Safe Hands and One Life customers – with template letters you can download – and all the latest updates on these cases.
James Daley is managing director of the consumer group Fairer Finance

title: Money Clinic: ‘I’ve locked £9k in a fixed-rate savings account. When and how will I pay tax on the interest?’
lead: Only some savers have to pay tax on the money they earn from savings
author: Anna Bowes

body.text: Got a question about your ? Email in and we’ll get one of our experts to reply. Anna Bowes, co-founder of Savings Champion, has given her guidance to a reader below. If you have a question for our experts, email us at

Question: I am locking my money away into a one-year  this week that pays 5 per cent returns – but how does paying tax on my earnings work? Do I pay when the one year is over or now, and do I need to do a self-assessment tax return? How can I limit the tax I pay on the earnings?
Answer: The Personal Savings Allowance (PSA) was introduced in April 2016, offering savers a small boost to the amount of tax-free interest they could earn.

Basic rate taxpayers have a PSA of £1,000 per year – so the first £1,000 of interest they earn on their savings (outside of a cash Isa) each year is tax free, so with £9,000 locked away, you’d need to earn more than 11 per cent interest to pay any tax at all. For higher rate taxpayers the PSA is £500 per year (so you’d need to earn more than 5.5 per cent). Additional rate taxpayers are not entitled to a PSA and so if you’re in this bracket, you pay tax on all interest earned in taxable savings accounts.

Those who earn £12,571 to £50,270 in taxable income each year are basic rate taxpayers, those who earn £50,271 to £125,140 are higher-rate payers, and those earning over £125,140 each year are additional rate payers.

Because at the time of its introduction, the PSA was estimated that 85 per cent of people would no longer need to pay tax on their interest any more, there was a radical change to the way savings interest is taxed; banks and building societies stopped automatically deducting 20 per cent tax from interest earnt with the introduction of the PSA and so all interest is now paid gross.

There are some other important points to bear in mind – an increase in income that takes you beyond the higher or additional rate tax threshold will reduce the PSA applicable to you and so may result in an increase in the tax you will pay in more ways than one.
It is also important to note that the PSA reduces as soon as you hit the tax threshold, so for example, even if your income only goes £1 into the higher rate tax threshold, the PSA will drop by £500.

If the PSA applicable to you reduces or you’re likely to breach the PSA limit, it is worth noting that interest earned on cash Isas do not count against the PSA, so will remain tax free regardless. This means that cash Isas still have an important role for savers that are looking to reduce the amount of tax they pay on their savings overall.

In terms of admin, there is little for you to do – if the interest you earn is less than your PSA, there is nothing more for you to do as you have received your interest gross and there is no tax to pay.

However, with the recent increases in interest rates available, more and more savers will be breaching their PSA and will therefore need to pay tax. If you receive interest in excess of the applicable PSA limit, then the onus is on you to pay the tax that is owed.
For many though, the tax will be collected automatically through the Pay As You Earn (PAYE) system – or can be paid through a self-assessment, if you already complete one.

For those on the PAYE system, any tax due will be taken via an amendment of your tax code. But this is being estimated by HMRC, based on previous tax year information supplied by the banks and building societies – the actual interest you are expecting to earn over the coming year may be very different.
So it’s important to check your tax code and inform HMRC if you don’t think it is right.
And as mentioned above, don’t forget you have an annual Isa allowance which is currently £20,000.

Isas are a good idea for those who can no longer avoid paying tax on their savings, even though in many cases the rate would appear to be less on the Isa than the equivalent taxable account. But you need to take a look at what you would earn after tax on the standard account, compared to the tax-free interest on the Isa.

title: ‘I was charged £1k for leaving rhubarb crumble in the oven’: The reasons tenants have deposits docked
lead: i readers tell us the reasons landlords have decided to take money out of their deposits
author: Grace Gausden

body.text: The crisis in the rental market has intensified for increasingly smaller homes.

But one issue that has long been a sticking point for renters is when landlords try to unfairly dock their deposits. Callum Mason, money and business reporter for i, recently  of leaving a flat only to receive an email informing him that his landlord intended to charge him £100 to replace a lightbulb… and an extra £50 to clean the soon-to-be replaced bulb.
His piece received such a large response  a tweet asking you to tell us us of any nonsensical charges landlords have levied for repairs. Here is what you reported back.

I left a freshly made homemade rhubarb crumble in the oven (it was turned off, just cooling). I also apparently left a “some fluff” on the floor (it must’ve blown in from outside) which they photographed. Over £1,000 for the pleasure of those two mistakes.
— Imali Chislett (@inkfirestudio)

£10 for a cloth left accidentally in the sink (having deep cleaned the house) £50 for a crack in my bedroom window which I pointed out had quite evidently been broken from the outside, they agreed and then charged me anyway
— Alice Chilcott (@alchilcott)
Watermarks on the washing machine door because we’d wiped it
— Lucy Miller 🦀 (@lucymiller321)
£50 for “cleaning the dishwasher” (there was a scrap of onion on the inside door)
— Natalie Garland (@natalielgarland)
£20 for a sock under the bed and around 🫠 £50 because the cleaner we paid for at the end of our tenancy left a hand mark on the bathroom mirror
— Sophie King (@SophieeKing)

£200 because we hadn’t paid for a professional clean ( it had apparently had a professional clean when we moved in, but it was disgusting). We cleaned it ourselves and knew it was spotless. They found a soap sud on the washing machine handle so wanted a full deep clean 🙃
— 🌻 Becky – The Owlet 🌻 (@theowletblog)
My toaster had melted about a CM of a kitchen door and landlord argued I had to pay for entire new kitchen. They withheld my £500 depoisit and sent me a bill for £3,000.
— Claudia Tanner (@claudiatanner)
A crack in the plastic fridge drawer!
— Ellen Beardmore (@E_Beardmore)

Our landlord tried to charge us £300 because the man who came to install the internet removed an old Telewest box that didn’t work and had been there since the 90s. They don’t exist any more and have no current use, so he found the old receipt and charged us the original price.
— The Lady of the Green Kirtle (@ladygreenkirtle)

My sons student rental deposit docked for among other things, a dead fly on the window sill requiring extra cleaning. We followed the painful appeals process to the bitter end and got every single penny of the deposit back, minus the £5 it cost us for a solicitor’s signature.
— Darran Hill (@Hill_Darran)
Scott’s landlady in Preston charged him for not defrosting the freezer… even though two other tenants remained living there
— AVB🦥 (@amy_tweetz)

A friend of mine had a fiver taken off him at uni for “not hoovering under his bed”. You couldn’t hoover under his bed, it had wooden sides that went straight to the floor. Such a petty amount that I always remember it
— Hannah Tomes (@hannahtomes_)
Moved a chair from the bedroom to the kitchen and had to pay £50 to replace the chair because it wasn’t in the room on the inventory 😫
— Ella Delancey Jones (@ellaluciewrites)

If you think you have had an unfair charge taken out of your deposit, it is possible to challenge the decision. Below, we reveal what you can do if you think your landlord is trying to take too much money.

1)  Not helpful after you’ve moved out but good advice all the same. Before you move out, it’s a good idea to get evidence of the condition of the property when you leave in case you and your landlord disagree on how much deposit you should get back. This could include photos and receipts if you hired a professional cleaner. The evidence will help you argue you should get all or most of your deposit back.

2) Importantly, your landlord or letting agent should tell you exactly why they’re taking money off. Make sure you get these reasons in writing then you can refer back to them if you need to take action. Sometimes they could be crafty so make sure you know your rights, for example, they can’t take money from your deposit for “reasonable wear and tear”. This includes things that gradually get worse or need replacing over time like paintwork or a piece of furniture.

3) Ask them to explain how they have come to the cost they are charging to ensure they haven’t just plucked a number out of thin air. This means if they’ve taken money off to replace something you damaged, you can ask to see a quote to prove how much the replacement cost. As mentioned above with the lightbulb, some of the quotes can be ridiculous and should be challenged.

4) If you still can’t agree with your landlord, there are things you can do to get your deposit back. They must put your deposit in a tenancy deposit scheme TDS if you have an Assured Shorthold Tenancy. If your deposit is protected, your landlord should have told you what scheme they used – Deposit Protection Service, My Deposits or Tenancy Deposit Scheme.

You can use your scheme’s alternative dispute resolution (ADR) service to help you get your deposit back. It’s free and easy to make a claim. You’ll usually have to make your claim to the ADR service within three months of moving out of the property. If your landlord or letting agent refuses to use the ADR service you can take them to court instead. Although this should be a last resort.

If you agree about part of your deposit, you should get back the money you agree on quickly. You’ll usually get your money back in 10 days. After the ADR service gets evidence from both you and your landlord or letting agent, they’ll send you a final decision within six weeks by email or letter.

6) If, for any reason, your deposit wasn’t protected and you don’t believe a fair deduction was made, you may have to take your landlord to the small claims court. However, this can be costly and time consuming. You may also not win and then be out of pocket by even more than you were in the first place.

title: Interest rates to stay high, but predictably so: welcome to the new normal for our finances
lead: Andrew Bailey votes to pause on rate rises, but leaves wiggle room to increase in the future
author: Jessie Hewitson

body.text: On Thursday we saw something happen last seen in November 2021: the Bank of England opted not to increase the base rate.

The effect in the press room at the Bank of England, where journalists got early sight of the decision, was immediate. There was a ripple of excitement and intakes of breath. Nothing was happening, but this was the best and most exciting nothing we’ve seen for close to two years.

and his colleagues at the Bank left lots of wiggle room to increase rates in the future if necessary – the Governor of the Bank of England repeatedly stated he was not being “complacent” to reassure the markets.
But he will be aware the message he’s sending: that the fastest period of increases to interest rates in modern times is likely to be coming to an end.
This is good news. It means we are moving from a period of uncertainty and financial shocks to a future where rates are likely to be more stable.
But let’s not get out the bunting just yet: mortgage rates won’t go down dramatically, they will just remain predictably high.

The markets are now predicting the base rate to average just above 5 per cent for the next three years, and the GDP data for the second and third quarter of this years show us uncomfortably close to a technical recession, another reason the Bank may not want to have pushed things too far on Thursday.

It will be some time before we get to the next stage of recovery, when the . Inflation is not expected to return to 2 per cent next year, and rates aren’t likely going to go down significantly before the middle of 2024.

So what are the key messages from today? That people with variable mortgages can breathe a small sight of relief that their repayments won’t go up too much higher in the near future and those on fixed rates can assume a rate of 5 per cent (ish) for the next three years or so.

Savers should fix a good rate now ad feel able to tie up their money for several years, if they haven’t already, knowing that rates won’t get much better. Anyone holding off getting a pension annuity can now commit for the same reasons.

Ultimately, while Thursday’s news isn’t a celebration, many people can take a small degree of comfort from knowing that it’s going to be easier to plan our finances. We’re not living with shifting financial sands any longer.

title: Fresh wave of home-loan reductions heralds return of the sub 5% mortgage
lead: Lenders are reducing mortgage rates with several of them now offering cheaper deals and rates below 5 per cent
author: Grace Gausden

body.text: A fresh wave of mortgage rate reductions has led to a number of deals sitting below 5 per cent hitting the market.
The latest cut is from Nationwide, which announced it is reducing its three-year and five year fixed deals, making them

From Wednesday, it will lower existing rates by 0.45 per cent. A three-year fix will be reduced to 4.99 per cent and a five-year fix will fall to 4.74 per cent for new purchases. For those re-mortgaging, the three-year fix will become 5.29 per cent and five-year fix will sit at 4.89 per cent.
The next cheapest rate is with HSBC on its five-year fixed deal at a rate of 4.74 per cent with a £1,499 fee.
Nationwide is the latest lender to cut rates as they start to fall back across the board, following a halt to interest rate hikes.
As a result, swap rates, the rates at which that banks lend money to each other, have remained settled. This has allowed lenders to cut rates and
Experts believe rates could now reach 4.5 per cent by the end of the year.

Nick Mendes of brokers John Charcol said: “I think there is margin for lenders to come down to 4.5 per cent on five-year fixed rates by the end of October. This latest move by Nationwide will strengthen their position but only for a matter of days, as I suspect HSBC will want to regain their hold on the market.”

This week, First Direct has dropped rates by 0.17 per cent, meaning its five-year fix is now 4.87 per cent, while the Co-operative Bank also reduced its two, three and five-year fixed rate products by up to 0.5 per cent.
TSB has also cut rates by up to 0.2 per cent on its three-year fixed rates and 0.1 per cent on its two-year deals.
Aaron Strutt of Trinity Financial said: “Lenders are still lowering their rates as the cost of funding mortgages continues to fluctuate.

“Many of the banks and building societies are a long way off hitting their lending targets and given the reduction in the number of property purchases going through, they know the only real way of getting more mortgages agreed is to lower rates.
“It is good to see more deals getting cheaper.”
The reductions to rates are also now becoming more substantial compared to the previously minimal cuts.
Mendes said: “Each week, we are seeing lenders continuing to reprice their fixed-rate products which show no signs of slowing down albeit for the next few weeks.
“We’re starting to see the repricing typically around 0.25 to 0.5 per cent, rather than the nominal 0.1 per cent reductions.”
It comes as  a new mortgage offering the lowest rate seen on the home loan market for over a year.
It is offering a two-year fixed-rate mortgage with a rate of just 3.35 per cent, available to customers who are remortgaging with the lender and who have 40 per cent equity.
The downside is the fee, which is 5 per cent of the loan – far higher than the average fee of £999.

Mendes added: “We have seen lenders like Skipton show innovative ways of creating a headline rate but higher arrangement fees to compensate. They say if it looks too good to be true then it certainly will be.”

title: How much rent will universal credit pay? DWP support for housing costs explained, and what you’re entitled to
lead: Here’s what support you can get for your housing payments
author: Alys Key

body.text: , the Government’s catch-all benefit for those on low income, out of work or unable to work, has many different elements. One of those is a housing payment, designed to help you with the cost of wherever you’re living, and it can be used for a whole range of living situations.
Here we explain how universal credit housing payments can be used.

Roughly one in five of us rent from a private landlord. The price of doing this has gone up for many people lately, as landlords up rents amid rising interest rates and high demand. If you are eligible for universal credit, you can get help to cover your rent. The money is paid to you, but you then have to hand it over to the. The amount you can receive is based on the needs of your household, with the rules expecting couples to share a bedroom while children under a certain age bunk together. You can work out how many bedrooms you’re eligible for using the Local Housing Allowance bedroom calculator.

If you live in a property managed by a housing association or local authority, such as council housing, you can get support for both rent and service charges. Social renters can also get help with bills from the main universal credit payment. Again, the  payment is made to you, and you then pay it to your landlord. The amount is based on how much space you need, and is reduced if you have more bedrooms than your household needs.

The most common form of accommodation in the UK is a home owned by the resident. More than six in 10 of us own our own homes. But though it is often seen as a route to security, homeowners can still face major costs. Universal credit recipients who own a home on a leasehold basis are eligible for help with service charges. These are the payments required by building owners for the maintenance of shared spaces and facilities such as rubbish collection.

You can apply for universal credit to assist with housing costs if you live in supported or sheltered housing and are not receiving ‘care, support, or supervision’ through your housing. However, universal credit cannot be used for housing costs if you live in supported or sheltered housing that provides ‘care, support, or supervision,’ temporary accommodation arranged by your council (for example, a B&B), or a refuge for survivors of . In these cases, you should apply for housing benefit instead.
Beyond universal credit, there are other avenues for obtaining financial assistance for housing-related challenges.

If you’re on low income or benefits, you could look into securing a council tax reduction. Your local council might also be able to provide additional help if your universal credit is not enough to cover your housing costs. Contact your council and ask about the “discretionary housing payment” to see if you can apply for this.

There is also another form of support for homeowners who have been on universal credit for three consecutive months. Support for  interest (SMI) is different from other assistance because it’s paid as a loan, which you have to repay when you sell your home. It helps with payments towards your mortgage interest or loans taken out for repairs and improvements on your home.
It cannot be used to pay off any of your actual mortgage loan, only the interest accrued on it. SMI is available to people on an income-based benefit such as universal credit or pension credit.

title: ﻿Do you pay income tax on inheritance? How capital gains and inheritance tax work, and who pays them
lead: There are many factors to consider when it comes to deciding if you need to pay income tax on inheritance
author: Alys Key

body.text: When someone close to you dies and leaves you an inheritance, you may need to consider whether any inheritance tax needs to be paid. Because the allows for up to £325,000 to be passed down tax-free, and there are and ways to increase this threshold, many people will never have to pay the levy.  You can read more about the intricacies ofwith our
But that does not mean you can always escape any tax implications. It all depends on what you’ve inherited, and what you plan to do with it.

There are some instances where money you receive from a late loved one can be subject to income tax. For example, if you inherit a  from someone who dies over the age of 75, there will usually be income tax to pay when you withdraw the money.

At the moment, the rules are different if you inherit the pension from someone who was under 75 when they died. In that instance, the inheritance is usually not subject to income tax. But the Government is c, so make sure you check the latest regulations if you are making any decisions on the basis of the current rules.
Another instance in which you’ll pay income tax would be if you inherit a property, and choose to rent it out. This would follow the  on taxing rental income.

In the event that you inherit a house and then decide to sell it, you may have to pay capital gains tax (CGT) on the profits. The rules around CGT stipulate that it should not be applied when selling your own house, so if the property is also your own home and you choose to sell it, you won’t be liable for the levy. But it is applied when you sell a second home.

The way profit is calculated for the purpose of CGT on inherited property uses the value of the house at the time you inherited it. If the estimated price is still the same by the time you sell it, there will be no profit to tax. But if it has increased, you’ll have to pay normal CGT rates.

The same is true for other assets that you might later wish to sell. This only applies to personal possessions worth more than £6,000, perhaps something antique, a valuable collectible, or some jewellery.
Cars, however, are usually not included. You’re also exempt on paying tax on the first £6,000 of your share if you own a possession jointly with other people.
If you then sell an object for more than it was worth on the date it was inherited, the difference is considered to be your “profit” for the purposes of CGT.

title: UK households could face ‘high debt burdens’ in future Bank of England warns
lead: Households and businesses are already facing cost of living pressures and higher borrowing costs but the full effect of higher interest rates have not yet passed through to them
author: David Connett

body.text: The Bank of England is warning that more persistent inflation, higher interest rates and increasing international tension is leading to growing risks for the UK economy.

It said that households and businesses are already facing cost of living pressures and higher borrowing costs but the full impact of higher interest rates not yet passed through to them. If inflation persists, interest rates may need to rise further, it warns in its latest , hitting growth.

As fixed-rate mortgage deals expire and households renew their mortgages, the average cost of mortgage payments is increasing with the proportion of household income spent on mortgage payments expected to continue to rise through this year and next. The Bank believes it will not peak as high as it did during the 2007-08 financial crisis.
but remains low by historical standards it said but fears as some customers try to adapt to high interest rates and dearer living costs they will face greater debt troubles ahead.

“Some mortgage holders facing higher interest rates have extended the period over which they are repaying their mortgages, with a small number moving to interest-only deals. While this eases pressures for these households in the short-term, it could result in higher debt burdens in the future.

The Bank is . While the annual rate of credit card spending has remained steady at steady at 11.8 per cent it warned greater use by some households may “lead to greater debt vulnerability for households in the near-term.”
Banks and bigger businesses are in a “strong position” to support customers in trouble but it expressed fears for many small businesses.

“Overall, we expect UK businesses to be resilient to higher interest rates and weak growth. Smaller businesses and those with relatively bigger debts are likely to struggle more. The  has continued to rise. This trend has been largely dominated by smaller firms so far.

It warned business borrowing from so-called ‘shadow banking’ finance sources which range from hedge funds to insurers, while an important source of funding, remained ‘risky’. It has called for increased liquidity – readily accessible funds – to double from 30 per cent to 50-60 per cent to balance the growing risks to the UK financial markets posed by such funding.
It said it was on alert for continuing to hit the UK.

At present, however, there are limited signs of stress in Hong Kong property markets and there is greater security and seniority on Hong Kong exposures relative to Chinese exposures.”

title: Is Metro Bank in trouble? Why the share price is plummeting and what fundraising plans mean for customers
lead: As the bank goes through an tumultuous period, i examines the situation and how it could affect its customers and their cash
author: Brendan McFadden

body.text: Metro announced today it is looking to .
One of the UK’s biggest is reportedly in talks with investors about raising £250m in equity funding and refinancing £350m in debt to shore up its balance sheet.
The bank, which has around 2.7 million customers, said it was looking at a range of options including a combination of equity and debt, as well as possible possible £100m share sale.
But it stressed that “no decision has been made on whether to proceed with any of these options” and it remains “well positioned” for future growth.
As the bank goes through an tumultuous period, i examines the situation and how it could affect its customers and their cash.
The bank’s announcement spooked its investors and caused its prices to plummet by more than 25 per cent this morning.
Shares in the company, which have already sunk more than 50 per cent down over the past month, fell by as much as 29 per cent early on Thursday.
As a result the bank temporarily halted its shares twice this morning, before being suspended due to the volatility of the .
Due to the recent declines, Metro has been left with a market value of around £60m, compared with its peak of £3.5bn in 2018.
City regulators are reportedly in talks with the bank following the share price drop but the ‘s Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) and the  (FCA) both declined to comment.
In 2019, Metro said its commercial loan portfolio was far riskier than previously reported.
The announcement triggered a 39 per cent fall in its share price in a single day and led to the FCA slapping it with a £10m fine, as a punishment for “misleading investors”.
Earlier this year the bank earlier said it had worked on “fixing issues of the past while positioning itself for the future”, as it revealed it had made a profit over the first half of the year.
But there are some concerns from financial experts whether Metro will be able to raise enough cash to secure its future.
Gary Greenwood, an equity research analyst for Shore Capital Markets, said: “Metro Bank has been struggling for a number of years to establish itself as a profitable and self-sustaining bank.

He also said the bank has over-costed in recent years having put money into opening expensive branches it is narrowly operating within its minimum capital requirements, which could have helped prompt a possible fundraising drive.
The bank has not announced that the fundraising plans will affect its customers, or said that it fears that it could collapse.
Banking insiders claim there is no risk to customer deposits and that the bank is in a strong position.

title: Does an inheritance affect benefits? What inheriting money and property means for universal credit payments
lead: Any benefits which is means-tested, meaning it’s based on your income or savings, could be affected by an inheritance
author: Alys Key

body.text: Whether it gives a little boost to your bank balance or a huge windfall, inheriting money can really change how your finances look. But if you are receiving any benefits that take into account your income or savings, you might need to be careful about how that influx of cash shakes things up.

Any benefits which is means-tested, meaning it’s based on your income or savings, could be affected by an inheritance. The most relevant aspect will usually be when benefits have limits on how much you can have stashed away in savings and still be eligible. For , for example, you can only have up to £16,000 in savings (or £24,000 for couples) otherwise you won’t be able to receive the benefit. And anything over a £6,000 threshold affects the amount you can get.

Pension credit also has a savings threshold, though there is no hard limit. Anything over £10,000 counts towards your income and therefore affects how much you can be paid. While we usually talk about savings when discussing benefits, it might be more accurate to say “capital”, since those thresholds can include not just cash but investments, premium bonds, and even property you own but do not live in. The other way inheritance might affect your benefits is if it changes your income level.

Inheritance is not classed as income and is not taxable – any inheritance tax should have already been taken care of by the estate by the time you receive the money. However, as mentioned above, if you end up with more than a certain level of savings as a result of inheriting money, this can be counted as income.

For example, pension credit recipients with more than £10,000 in the bank are considered to have an extra £1 income a week for each additional £500. The amount they receive in pension credit is then adjusted accordingly.

If you live in a property as your main residence, it will not count towards your savings. Its value is also disregarded for six months if you don’t live in it yet, but plan on moving in. But if you decide not to live in an inherited home, it will count as part of your capital.
Furthermore, any income you receive from renting out a property you don’t live in counts as income for the purposes of working out your benefits eligibility.

However, others think they will remain for a while.
