Some aren’t waiting to find out what will happen next. During the course of writing this piece, Will and Jacob have had their offer accepted on a flat in Battersea, south-west London, much to their delight. With so many unknowns in the housing market, a friend can offer much-needed predictability.

title: I lost £3,500 on a funeral plan through One Life two years ago… and still have not received a penny back
lead: Many have lost thousands of pounds to funeral plan firms that have got into administration
author: James Daley

body.text: In October 2021, Sijuwade Olaniyi – a carer from Barnet, north London – decided to buy a funeral plan. She had seen several friends and people she cared for die over the pandemic and wanted to make sure that, when her time came,

After doing some research on the internet, she came across One Life. A company that offered affordable funeral plans . The website looked very credible, so, persuaded, she made 12 payments of £304.17 over the next year – a total of £3,650.
“I was so happy,” said Sijuwade. “I called my son and my family – and I told them it was all taken care of. They didn’t need to worry about anything.”
But just a few weeks after her final payment was taken, she heard that the funeral plan company  was going into administration –

Over the course of the next seven months, her worst fears were realised. Not only had One Life gone bust – but by July 2023, as the administration drew to a close, she received a letter of customers’ money was gone.

Sijuwade later found out that she was one of 13,700 One Life customers – some of whom paid over £10,000 to the company to buy funeral plans for their whole family. Another funeral plan company, Safe Hands, collapsed earlier in 2022 leaving almost 46,000 customers out of pocket.

Why she wouldn’t see any of her money back is that, until July 2022, funeral plan companies were not fully regulated by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA). Laws created in 2000 stated that companies could be exempt from full regulation if they followed a handful of rules relating to how they looked after customers’ money.

This included things like needing to place the money in a life insurance policy, or a trust. If in a trust, firms needed to appoint independent trustees, actuaries, and fund managers to take care of the money.

When these laws were created, the funeral plan market was fairly small – around 50,000 plans a year – and mostly sold by funeral directors. But by the middle of the previous decade, dozens of new funeral plan firms had emerged, with sales swelling to more than 200,000.

Fairer Finance, a research and ratings agency that I founded that looks to help consumers make more informed decisions, wrote a research report raising concerns about some of the new firms in the market.

It said that as well as using cold calls and high-pressure sales tactics to offload the plans, many firms were also taking very large commissions and investing customers’ money in ways that suggested they may not be following the laws laid down in the early 2000s.

After being sent to the Treasury, along with campaigns from other firms, new laws came into force in July 2022. It means that, for anyone buying a funeral plan nowadays, there are now much tougher rules which mean their money will be safe. If a firm were to go bust, customers are protected by the Financial Services Compensation Scheme.
But this wasn’t the case when Sijuwade bought her plan, though the FCA had a responsibility to police the old rules – and ensure that funeral plans were looking after customers’ money.

Quite how well it policed these rules is up for debate. The FCA has now admitted that in 2014 when Safe Hands was set up, its unauthorised business unit engaged with the company and raised concerns about whether it was following the rules. It found that its fund manager did not have the right permissions to manage the trust’s money – and forced them to appoint someone else.
However, it seems that while the FCA took early action, it didn’t move again after further concerns were raised in 2017.

In the case of One Life, the firm was set up at the end of 2020 – by which time, the process of bringing the whole funeral plan sector under full FCA supervision was well under way. But it would seem they also didn’t take any action until it was too late. A final notice stating that One Life would not be able to become FCA regulated was issued in July 2022, nine months after it had submitted its application.

In those nine months alone, many millions more pounds worth of plans were sold. Given the that One Life submitted its application in October 2021, why was the alarm not raised at that moment? If it had been, customers like Sijuwade would have lost no more than a few hundred pounds.

The FCA said: “Before regulation came in, we had limited powers to intervene in this market. One Life was not FCA authorised. Where firms were not authorised prior to the 29 July 2022 deadline, HM Treasury granted an extension for firms to transfer their books to an authorised provider until 31 October 2022. Firms covered by this extension were not authorised by the FCA and were outside our regulation.”
The Parliamentary Ombudsman is now starting to look at Safe Hands – and it is vital that parliamentarians continue to investigate what happened here.

Unfortunately, although new rules are now in place, this doesn’t help people like Sijuwade who bought their plan prior to these being enforced. Thousands will have been affected, many of who will have also lost thousands of pounds and still not have any money put aside for their funerals.
As well as compensation for the victims, there needs to be accountability for the failures – and potentially a change to laws and protocol to enable regulators to act more quickly.

If you’re a customer, you may still be able to get your money back if you paid by card by calling on the chargeback scheme. Talk to your bank – and don’t let them fob you off by telling you it’s too late. The time limits on chargeback claims should not apply for services that were pre-ordered. If your bank rejects your claim, then escalate it to the Financial Ombudsman Service.

If you paid by bank transfer or direct debit – then there’s no easy way to claim your money back. But you can still complain to the Treasury, and escalate your complaint to the Parliamentary Ombudsman once it is rejected. And you can complain to the FCA and escalate your complaint to the Complaints Commissioner. There are Facebook sites for both Safe Hands and One Life customers – with template letters you can download – and all the latest updates on these cases.
James Daley is managing director of the consumer group Fairer Finance

title: How Ghosts brought the family sitcom back from the dead
lead: Now in its fifth and final series, the BBC has become a modern classic thanks to its silliness and heart, ushering in a new era of British TV
author: Tom Nicholson

body.text: There are cavepeople and mustachioed Second World War captains wandering around Waterloo. A queue of young people – most in their late teens and early twenties, some children with their parents – extends all the way along London’s South Bank, and past the Hayward gallery. Everyone is gathered at the bedside of one of the great British sitcoms as it prepares to join the great streaming platform in the sky, though it looks less like a wake than a cosplay weekend.

The BFI is hosting a special preview screening of the first two episodes of the fifth and final series of Ghosts, the BBC comedy from and Yonderland, which has become one of the most fervently loved shows on British TV.

These fans have brought all kinds of presents with them: hand-drawn cards and zines celebrating the individual ghosts; a whole marble cake for the cast to share; a homemade Ghosts Monopoly board, with caveman Robin in place of Old Kent Road and still-living young couple Alison and Mike in the coveted Park Lane and Mayfair slots. Some people here have Ghosts tattoos.

Innocent and silly while occasionally winkingly saucy too, bright and light but easily able to pivot to heartstring-tugging mode, : a cult hit with a fandom equally happy formulating theories about the past lives of its characters as it is giving away its good Tupperware to its stars, and the last of the great British family sitcoms.

If you’re unfamiliar, a quick primer: Alison (Charlotte Ritchie) and Mike (Kiell Smith-Bynoe) luck into a huge country pile when one of Alison’s distant relatives dies and leaves it to her. Button House is a crumbling wreck, it turns out, but they set to fixing it up. And then Alison falls out of a window, and when she comes round she can see dead people.
There are dead doctors at the hospital, cheery Luftwaffe pilots in the trees, and nine long-term residents of Button House who aren’t happy about having to share their digs with the living again.

There’s uptight Victorian matriarch and defender of propriety Fanny (Martha Howe-Douglas); dippy Georgian romantic Kitty (Lolly Adefope); Byronic poser Thomas (Mat Baynton), who’s in love with Alison; chipper Scoutmaster Pat (Jim Howick); witch trial victim Mary (Katy Wix); leery Tory MP Julian (Simon Farnaby), who died in flagrante and is therefore cursed to an afterlife without trousers; the pompous Captain (Ben Willbond), whose death remains a mystery but who has become an unlikely queer icon; caveman and occasional conspiracy theorist Robin (Laurence Rickard); and Humphrey (also Rickard), a decapitated Tudor lord whose head and body are generally in different parts of the Button estate. Oh, and there’s a plague pit in the cellar.

None of the ghosts can leave the grounds, but Alison and Mike are determined to make Button House into a hotel. So they’re all stuck. Over time they have learned to rub along together, and Ghosts has worked out a particular mixture of Horrible Histories’ extreme silliness and relentless gags that reward repeat viewings, and genuinely moving meditations on death, life, home and family.

When Ghosts premiered in 2019, it fast became the most  new sitcom. It stood out immediately. Our own critic praised its “supreme daftness and a great suggestion of darkness”, and it fit right in the sweet spot between the post-Fleabag run of comedies that mined big, wobbly feelings as much as gags, and more gleefully silly new sitcoms like Stath Lets Flats (with which Ghosts shares quite a few cast members).

But unlike them – and much of TV comedy – it wasn’t an auteurish exploration of real-life trauma, or a vehicle for a single star. For the first time since Gavin & Stacey, Ghosts found a way of doing a big, broad, uncynical family sitcom that didn’t lean on the big, broad, uncynical family sitcoms of which everyone was sick to death.

You only need to compare it with another death-themed series of 2019, , which premiered a month before Ghosts, to see what Ghosts does right: tightly written, moving but not mawkish, light of touch, full of ego-free performances and constantly inventive. Last Christmas its status was confirmed with a , broadcast just as the sherry came out. Another will air this year.

It’s perfect. Younger viewers have the Horrible Histories connection, older viewers love a pretty traditional ensemble comedy that sometimes pitches jokes over the kids’ heads, and everyone’s on board with a sweet-natured, sharply written series with some of the best comic talent around. It’s not embarrassed about appealing to everyone, but never dumbs itself down.

It isn’t just the gags though. Having a chorus of the undead around gives Ghosts a way into every shade of emotion from wildly different perspectives. The ghosts are still trying to get their heads around what happened to them in life, despite having been dead for, in some cases, millennia. And the fact they’re dead, with nothing to do but ruminate on the lives they had, means you can unexpectedly find yourself welling up over Julian, a standard issue Back-To-Basics-era Tory sleazebag, realising that in prioritising work and philandering (mostly the philandering) he missed his kids growing up.

It doesn’t get on its soapbox, but Ghosts is a neat fit with a culture more comfortable with vulnerability and empathy, where therapy-speak is embedded in everyday chat and on TV the emphasis has shifted to warmer, cuddlier shows where getting it wrong is cute (, Would I Lie to You?) and real warmth seeps out of the telly (The Repair Shop, Mortimer and Whitehouse: Gone Fishing).

For me, the first sign Ghosts was something really special was the episode about Pat’s death-story, back in the first series. His death sounds funny – his Scout troupe looked on aghast as he struggled to start the minivan having been shot through the neck during an archery lesson – but full of pain, and not just from the arrow through his larynx. Unknown to Pat, his wife had been having an affair and ended up marrying the other man after Pat’s death, a state of affairs Pat only realises while describing the situation to Alison.

Desperate to feel connected to them again he wrestles over passing on a message to his family via Alison, and eventually relents. They’ve moved on, and he needs to move on too – easier said than done when you’re stuck in the same house for eternity. But when they arrive at Button House to pay their respects, he discovers he’s got a grandson: young Pat. He’s even got old Pat’s stubby legs.

There’s one more lovely, sincere moment that sums up Ghosts completely. Robin, the caveman, who has seen everything before, says: “You die. Time pass. Everything change. Family not come anymore. Is pain, but you heal. Yeah. You remember them here.” He pats Pat’s heart. “And maybe, one day… you find new family.”

Every character gets these little grace notes that open them up a little further and a little further, even 24-carat bastard Julian. Thomas, the tortured poet, was betrayed by his own cousin and realises the woman he loved hadn’t gone off him at all; Kitty was routinely humiliated by her horrible step-sister; the Captain, it’s hinted, loved one of the men in his regiment but didn’t know how to understand what he felt. So far Pat’s been the only one to make me actually cry. Last year’s Christmas episode, in which he saw old home videos of his family lovingly mocking his annual Christmas speech long after he’d died, tipped me over the edge.

Traditionally in , the Fawlty Towers model – two series, maybe a Christmas special, and that’s it – is the ideal trajectory. By the time anything gets to a fifth series there are usually murmurings that it’s in danger of going the way of My Family, and repeating itself endlessly. In Ghosts, the endlessly shuffling dynamics between the nine spirits – well, eight, since Mary got “sucked off” last series to The Other Side – stop things feeling stale.

The Captain and Fanny try to rule things, with Pat the go-between with Alison; Julian, Thomas and Robin tend to undermine them; Kitty and Mary are in their own worlds. But then unlikely match-ups turn into the biggest highlights, like Kitty and the Captain deciding to hang out together watching clouds. “And that one is a pelican,” sings Kitty; the Captain rejoins with “…and that one is a gun”.

All the while Alison is both the ghosts’ consigliere and a total fish out of water, having to work out the rules of the afterlife while trapped in a haunted house, and Mike pinballs between assuming the ghosts can see him all the time and blithely singing “Daddy’s gonna drill a hole in the wall” as he does some DIY. (It’s a mark of how funny Ghosts is that the two straight roles anchoring the whole thing are also really, really funny. Ritchie and Smith-Bynoe are national treasures-in-waiting.)

Then there are the shapes of each episode. The general drift of the four series so far has seen Alison and Mike slowly get closer to their dream of opening Button House as a hotel. There aren’t many sitcoms that could do a Rashomon and play one story out from four different perspectives – as in “The Thomas Thorne Affair”, about the duel over a woman’s honour that killed poor, stupid Thomas – and wear it so lightly.

There’s another clever thing moving Ghosts forward, too. The deaths of the deceased residents have been slowly revealed over the series, pulling you along like a series of whodunits. There’s genuine suspense as we go into the final series: we’re still yet to find out what happened to Kitty and the Captain, and the question of whether the Captain will announce anything more about that man in his regiment. (People really want to know: in one of the episodes screened at the preview, the Captain declared that he had to tell everyone about a man in his regiment, and there were widespread screams and gasps. They were, sadly, disappointed.)

Underneath it all, though, is some absolutely copper-bottomed gag writing, which had been a little out of fashion when Ghosts debuted. “One is reminded of Battersea Dogs Home,” Fanny sighs at one point, as the ghosts practice singing an apology song to Alison. “Really?” asks Humphrey. “Was there a fire?” Or as Thomas observes when Alison restores Lady Button’s portrait: “Oh lucky Fanny, to be touched up by such a hand.” And Fanny herself, on meeting Alison for the first time: “She’s no niece of mine! She’s exposing her knees! And she’s got a tattoo!”

Ghosts is going out at the top: the fandom are as devoted as they’ve ever been, the cast are all still mates, and its final series starts with two of its best episodes yet: an April Fool’s Day caper which brings together Alison and Humphrey properly for the first time, and a big reveal which I’m not going to spoil, but which does result in Robin giving Kitty foot massages. It’s even got an American remake which swaps in a Native American, a Viking, a hippie and several Revolutionary War casualties and which has been recommissioned for a second series.
But over here it feels like a new classic in the . It seems obvious now, but juggling that many great performances and that many great writers shouldn’t look as easy as Ghosts makes it seem.

Ghosts proved that in an ever more crowded TV landscape, there’s still a place for a big-hearted sitcom that plainly wants to be liked by as many people as possible, but is going to do it its own way.

After the BFI has finally been cleared of the fans jamming its foyer, the ghosts mill about in a back room having a drink. Willbond holds a particularly large stack of cards and posters. Baynton has been given a crocheted effigy of his ghost, and he also seems to have commandeered the marble cake. Hours later, there are still fans clustered around a side-entrance waiting to intercept Willbond and Ritchie as they get into their taxi.

The love those fans have is intense; to them Fanny, Robin, the Captain and the gang feel more like friends than characters. Ghosts might be on its way off this mortal coil, but its spirit will linger long after it’s been sucked off.
Ghosts is on BBC One tonight at 8.30pm

title: Ghosts, BBC One, review: How are we going to say goodbye to this joy of a sitcom?
lead: This fifth and final series is a lovely last hurrah from some of the UK’s finest comic actors
author: Rachael Healy

body.text: The fifth and final series of BBC’s spooky sitcom opened with a foreshadowing of how fans will be feeling by the end of the last episode.

Alison Cooper () awoke in her inherited mansion Button House expecting to greet the ghostly flatmates she’s grown to love. But there was no sign of them. That might’ve been a relief back in 2019’s first series, but now, Alison was devastated, and reduced to tears.
Fortunately, she’d only forgotten the date – April Fool’s! – and soon we were back into another episode of gentle mischief with the gang.

The ghosts’ trickery left Alison determined to get revenge by playing her own pranks before midday arrived, leaving husband Mike () to worry about their finances and field suspicious questioning from an insurance investigator probing the fire that drew series four to a close.

Over the past four years, Ghosts has built up a unique internal logic, bringing us into the Button House universe as each episode gradually revealed how each of its spectral inhabitants died. Fans are well versed in the physical limitations of a ghostly existence, and what it takes to finally transcend the material world (in the show’s parlance, being “sucked off” – despite Ghosts‘ generally wholesome tone there’s still room for the odd smutty joke).

Step by step, the show has also divulged more about each ghost – both their pasts and their personalities – with flashbacks to Button House in bygone eras. It’s a refreshing take on the sitcom format, using complex camera tricks and time-travelling storytelling to keep us interested.

The quest to fool each ghost in the opening episode drew on that shared history – the sweet gullibility of Georgian aristocrat Kitty (Lolly Adefope), the lecherous excesses of 80s MP Julian (Simon Farnaby), and the hopeless heartache of Romantic poet Thomas (Matthew Baynton).
Series five continues in the comfortable groove established by earlier series. There are plenty of laughs stemming from light disagreements between the ghosts, and banter between Alison and Mike.
It leans, successfully, on character-led humour, with superb performances from some of the UK’s finest comic actors, with Ritchie and Smith-Bynoe leading the charge.

The show’s core creative team – Baynton, Farnaby, Martha Howe-Douglas, , Laurence Rickard and Ben Willbond – originally worked together on children’s series Horrible Histories. There are echoes of its silliness, historical jokes, and cartoonish moments in Ghosts, but another thing that shines through is the group’s tight bond.

There’s a lovely camaraderie between the characters, providing a warm core to the show that permits a scattering of poignant moments amid the jokes. When Alison dropped the huge news that she’s pregnant at the end of episode one it was a charming flash of shared joy.

The emotional beats didn’t feel over-earnest, but genuine and earned thanks to the foundations the writers have built. While anyone could jump into Ghosts at any point and still grasp the gist, fans who’ve followed from the start get the most out of it.

We know this good thing has to come to an end. There were moments last series where it felt like characters were facing scenarios we’d already seen them in, but with a hard stop now approaching, Alison and Mike have big life decisions to make.

Will they all move on from Button House? With a Christmas special now promised, perhaps not, but as with any good sitcom, Ghosts is about the journey, not where everyone ends up at the end. We’ve got a fun ramble to the finish line.

title: Rick Astley, Are We There Yet?, review: Cements the singer as a music icon
lead: The singer’s first album in five years offers a glimpse at the vulnerable human being behind the joyful persona
author: Ed Power

body.text: “Never gonna….” croons early in Are We There Yet?, his first album in five years. But the veteran vocalist isn’t Rickrolling us by reprising his 1987 Stock Aitken Waterman smash “Never Gonna Give You Up”. He’s negotiating “Never Gonna Stop”, a sinewy ballad showcasing a voice that has become more bluesy and care-worn since his days as a Top of the Pops regular.

The 57-year-old has stumbled upon a strange sort of post-modern fame in recent decades. First, there was the “Rickrolling” phenomenon, whereby clicking on a random internet link would lead to a clip of Astley belting out “Never Gonna Give You Up”. Then stars such as  began to invite him up to perform. The Astley-naissance peaked this year at when he performed a surprise set of Smiths covers backed by indie group Blossoms.

It’s been fun watching Astley transcend his pop background and achieve a credibility that would have been unimaginable in his Smash Hits pomp. But he knows that gimmicks can only get you so far, and it is to his credit that he plays it straight on . There is no attempt to capitalise on his “ironic” stardom or, cheekier yet, chuck in some Smiths covers.

Instead, Astley gets on with business by serving up a satisfying collection of mid-tempo, Motown-inflected rock ’n’ roll (which he wrote, recorded and self-produced at his home studio in London). Finger clicks and funk guitar accompany opener “Dippin My Feet”.  The track reads like a Rick Astley manifesto as he delivers out lines such as “I keep on working till the sun goes down”.

A jangling indie riff follows on “Letting Go” and you wonder if he’s going to “go Smiths” after all. Instead, it morphs into a Stax-infused bopper, confirming Astley as an artist happy to lean into his status as kingpin of easy listening
There is, however, room for one surprise in piano-driven closer “Blue Sky”. Here is a stark torch song where Astley confesses to “hiding the way” he “really feels”.

It offers a glimpse at the vulnerable human being behind the joyful persona – one final quiff-hanger at the end of an LP that proves there is more to this tall-haired pop icon than Smiths covers and wacky memes.
Stream it: Letting Go, Blue Sky

title: PJ Harvey, Roundhouse, review: An extraordinary show of artistry and imagination
lead: At this eerie show, Harvey’s air of mystery and enigma remained intact
author: Shaun Curran

body.text: On her exquisite new album, I Inside the Old Year Dying, has conjured a realist frightful neverland. The rural countryside has been a frequent muse across Harvey’s career, but her tenth album goes further than ever: the songs are based on her 2022 narrative poetry book Orlam, written in the Dorset dialect of her youth, telling the pre-adolescent story of Ira-Abe Rawles, a young child from Underwhelm, a fictional village equally dream-like and disquieting.

At its heart an intricate, pastoral folk record, it is elevated into something altogether more peculiar with the use of electronics, guitar soundscapes and evocative field recordings – children playing, church bells, rivers flowing – that bring the unsettling world to life. It is the latest left turn in a 30-year career full of them.

Harvey presented the album in full on her second night at London’s Roundhouse in an extraordinary show of artistry and imagination. Opener “Prayer at the Gate” established the eerie scene: with the simple stage set that saw a church pew and some wooden chairs overlooked by cracked black skyline, Harvey embellished the song’s slow marching drums and distant synths with striking poses.

Her deliberate moves took stage direction from regular collaborator Ian Rickson – and her beguiling feather-light vocal betrayed the dark subject matter. “So look before, look behind, life and death all intertwined,” she sang, the first of many disconcerting illusions.

The rendition of the album worked especially well given the backdrop of Harvey’s unknowability. The air of enigma she has cultivated since the late 1990s – even in the instance of , she reveals next to nothing; her sole utterance all night came 90 minutes in when she introduced the band and thanked the crowd – means that not only can she fully inhabit a world of her own creation, but it is totally believable. She toyed with this expectation: even something as innocent as counting to 10, as she did during the sparse, murky “All Souls”, became something slightly sinister.

Yet for all of its strange allure – helped by an adept band led by long-time cohort John Parish – the melodies often sparkled in the murk. “Lwonesome Tonight” had a hymnal quality; “A Child’s Question, August” showed a sumptuous chorus was never too far away. The sense of foreboding that built over the album’s ominous back end – “August” was awash with discordant electronics; “A Child’s Question, July” rumbled anxiously – was exorcised by final track “A Noiseless Noise”, a shattering racket that cleansed the unease.

After a brief interlude during which Harvey exited the stage, the show’s second segment revisited her stellar catalogue. There was nothing from her two most accessible records, 2000’s Stories from the City, Stories from the Sea, her first Mercury Prize winner,– it wasn’t that sort of night.

Instead, after two songs from her second Mercury Prize winner, 2011’s war-torn opaque folk masterpiece Let England Shake that sonically bridged the gap between the two halves, we got a deep dive into Harvey’s raw, gritty 90s, including some songs not performed for 15 years until this short UK tour.

It was a potent, dynamic display. Still able to summon her early intensity, Harvey easily switched between the starkness of “Angelene” and “The Garden” and her earliest grunge-era material that the band attacked full-throttle: “Man-Size” and “Dress”, with their fluid, ahead-of-their-time enigmatic themes of early womanhood, play out as tales to heed.

“Down by the Water” maintained its original throbbing menace as Harvey went eyeball-to-eyeball with the crowd; a devastating version of “To Bring You My Love” was full of hypnotic vulnerability, Harvey stood in total darkness as the music slowly ran out of air.

The encore ended with 2007’s “White Chalk”, a creepy folk-adjacent cryptic story that traces a line to her new material. “Dorset’s cliffs meet at the sea, where I walked our unborn child in me, there’s blood on my hands” Harvey sang. What’s happened to the protagonist in uncertain, but it fittingly brought this most absorbing of shows full circle, Harvey’s mystery intact.

title: The Iliad, translated by Emily Wilson, review: Such dazzling clarity makes it perfect for modern readers
lead: From the first woman to translate the Odyssey comes this new way into the world of Achilles that brought me to tears all over again
author: Jennifer Saint

body.text: ’s translation of Homer’s Odyssey, published to great acclaim in 2017, opens with the line “tell me about a complicated man”.

With this, it became immediately apparent that Wilson’s take on the Homeric epic was going to be revelatory: sparkling, fresh and deliciously nuanced. Wilson, a professor of classical studies at the University of Pennsylvania, was the first woman to translate the Odyssey into English, and now six years later she is the second to do the same for the Iliad. It’s bound to open up the world of ancient epic with the same dazzling clarity as she did before, breathing vigorous life into the poem and inviting us as modern readers to feel the weight and grandeur of its tragedy.

Predictably, the fact of a woman translating  so very successfully has troubled the occasional commentator who frets that some mighty quality of masculinity in the epic will be somehow compromised. But that’s a reductive view not just of the skill of translation but also of the epic itself.

The Iliad explores the hyper-masculine world of heroes with immense depth and richness, and Wilson conveys it all with unflinching vividness. The epic poem tells us the story of a man possessed of “cataclysmic wrath”. It is Achilles, perhaps the most famous hero of Greek mythology, legendary for the godlike immensity of his rage and nihilistic capacity for violence – but also for his deep love of his comrade Patroclus, his desperate grief and the inevitability of his fate.

The Iliad begins with Achilles, in the ninth year of the Trojan War, quarrelling with Agamemnon over the enslaved woman, Briseis, that Achilles has taken captive. When Agamemnon loses his own “trophy” – the word Wilson so aptly uses to describe the women who are abducted and enslaved as spoils of war – he takes Briseis from Achilles. Outraged, Achilles not only retreats from the war to his tent, but also entreats his goddess mother to turn the tide of war against his fellow Greeks.

In parallel, we have the story of the Trojan hero, Hector, leaving his loving wife and baby behind so that he can take advantage of the Greeks’ disarray in a series of bloody and terrible battles. All the while, the Olympian gods oversee and orchestrate the death and devastation with callous disregard.

In Wilson’s hands, the poem sings with the clash of bronze, the thundering of hooves, the savage holler of war-cries. Her use of iambic pentameter imbues it with irresistible pace and rhythm. It flows like music – exhilarating, tragic, beautiful and stirring – just as it should, because this was a poem that was heard, not read, when it was first composed around 700BCE.

Her use of language and imagery makes it a visual experience too; one of glittering metal and flame, full of searing light so that we feel entirely transported to an alien, ancient and terrifying world.

But she anchors us in the emotional reality of the epic. There are moments of humour as well as quiet peace and reflection amidst the chaos and violence and when we read this poem we are united across the millennia that separate us from its composition by the shared agony of grief.

Running throughout is a humane, expressive connection of a truth we all know – the shattering inevitability of loss. Rediscovering it through Wilson’s eyes brought me to tears all over again. Her translation is so thoroughly readable that whether you already love the Iliad or are coming to it for the first time, you will be swept away in a story that has endured through the ages.

title: The best new books to read in October 2023, from Britney Spears’ memoir to the latest Lee Child thriller
lead: Inventive murder mysteries, entertaining nonfiction and sweeping reads from literary stars – here are the releases to enjoy this month
author: Anna Bonet

body.text: Yeongju might have appeared to have her life together – a degree, a husband, a high-flying job – but inside, she was suffering. So she walks away from it all and finds new meaning in life by setting up a bookshop in a residential area of . Here, we follow the trials and tribulations of our quirky owner, the young man she employs to make and serve the coffee, and all those who visit the store. Welcome to the Hyunam-Dong Bookshop became a word-of-mouth Korean sensation when it was first published, and now it has been translated to English it isn’t hard to see why. This novel is both a balm for the soul and a glorious love letter to books and reading. (Bloomsbury, £14.99)

“I breathed in stories, as soon as I breathed in air,” wrote the late, great . “Sometimes I think I wasn’t born, but I just came out in an ink blot.” Bringing together her finest nonfiction writing over four decades, A Memoir of My Former self paints a luminous portrait of the author’s life in her own words. Through her journalism, reviews and essays, we glimpse at the childhood fascination with Cromwell which led to the , her years living in Saudi Arabia, the times she battled with her health as a young woman, and her musings on everything from belonging to storytelling. A book to be treasured. (John Murray, £25)

A family are pushed out of the very place they are hoping to settle; a couple return to confront their loss; a pair’s friendship is altered forever. Here is a collection of nine Rome-set stories which are as exquisitely crafted as you would expect from the Pulitzer-prize winning author. (Picador, £16.99)

In 80s Norway, Syvert traces the clues about a father he never knew. In present-day , on the same weekend that a mysterious new star appears in the sky, Alevtina meets with a Norwegian visitor which changes everything. The Wolves of Eternity is an intelligent, expansive novel. (Harvill Secker, £25)

Over 30 years after The Firm cemented Grisham as a major legal thriller author, he returns with a blockbuster sequel which picks up the story 15 years later and thrusts Mitch McDeere into the centre of a high-octane hostage negotiation. (Hodder, £22)

This is the retelling of George Orwell’s 1984 that we didn’t realise we needed. Recasting the classic’s events from the female point of view, our eponymous Julia works as a mechanic fixing the novel-writing machines in the Ministry of Truth’s Fiction Department. Dazzlingly clever and original. (Granta, £18.99)

When DCI Karen Pirie receives a novel manuscript which holds remarkable similarities to a cold case, she realises she might be on the path to some answers. If only the author hadn’t died before finishing their book. (Sphere, £22)

One of the US’s most well-regarded writers spins a visceral and heart-shattering tale about Annis: a girl who grows up on a slave plantation, then is forced on a journey across America when she is sold by the white enslaver who fathered her. (Bloomsbury, £18.99)

When there is a spate of strange, seemingly unconnected deaths across the country, who else should the US government call in to investigate but? Another wild and riveting read in the famous series of thrillers. (Bantam, £22)

In this collection of ghost stories, the feted author explores everything from science to  and our lives online, but does so with wit, a lightness of touch – and plenty of horror. Spine-chillingly good. (Jonathan Cape, £18.99)

From the author of the weird and wonderful novels Milk Fed and The Pisces comes another sublime, fever-dream of a book. Death Valley follows a grieving woman as she flees to California, where she steps through the portal of a towering cactus, into another world. (Bloomsbury, £16.99)

The day that someone unearthed these lost stories from the much-missed author must have been a good one. Written for newspapers in the 70s and 80s under a pseudonym, here are 20 more glimpses at Terry Pratchett’s genius. (Doubleday, £20)

Few authors have managed to write mysteries as fun and inventive as Hallett’s The Appeal and The Twyford Code, so it is quite the treat that the cast of the former are returning for a festive twist – featuring a dead santa and a town full of suspects. (Profile, £12.99)

The Nobel Laureate pens a deft tale about a pianist who becomes infatuated with the woman who helps organise his latest concert in Barcelona; this novella accompanied by five other equally tremendous short stories. (Harvill Secker, £20)

In one of the most unique and meta murder mysteries you will read all year, West Heart Kill takes you to a remote hunting lodge where there is a raging storm – and an omniscient narrator guides you through solving the case of the three dead bodies. (Raven, £16.99)

Yayoi grows up with a perfect family – but is haunted by the idea there is something about her past she has forgotten. So she decides to move in with her strange aunt, and memories begin to be unearthed. (Faber, £12.99)

Both a contributing writer to the New York Times and author of celebrated nonfiction books Hunger and Bad Feminist, Roxane Gay is one of the US’s foremost thinkers and writers. Opinions is a collection of her most incisive pieces over the last decade, interrogating topics politics and culture wars to celebrities. (Corsair, £25)

The cover of this book promises it to be a “joyous journey through science” from the “science teacher you wish you had” – and it delivers. Bouncing between everything from space travel to evolution, it’s rip-roaringly entertaining and brimming with fascinating nuggets. (Viking, £22)

Given his history of novels, it should come as little surprise that le Carré was a man adept at secrecy himself. A whole part of his private life was kept out of his biography while he was alive, but now the biographer has returned with a new book which will help us get to know him a lot better. (Profile, £16.99)

A slim but powerful read, Disobedient Bodies explores the way in which we spend effort and money rectifying our “flaws”, while drawing on examples from other cultures and times to encourage an alternative approach to beauty. (Profile x Wellcome, £7.99)

What is it about the British and their love for dogs? This is the question Balding sets out to answer, and one that sends her (and us) on a delightfully entertaining romp through canine history, from Battersea to Buckingham Palace. (Ebury, £22)

Few people have experienced the white heat of fame quite like Britney Spears. Charting her tumultuous rise in the noughties pop music scene as well as her controversial conservatorship, her first memoir is bound to be a big hitter. (Simon & Schuster, £25)

The megastar actor – of Happy Days, Arrested Development, and Parks and Recreation fame – reflects on his journey from growing up with severe dyslexia, to finding fame as The Fonz, navigating Hollywood and beyond. An endearing, warm read. (Macmillan, £22)

Over the course of her seven decade career,  has played a plethora of Shakespearean roles – Lady Macbeth, Cleopatra, Ophelia – so much so she describes him as ‘The Man who Pays the Rent’. Recalling each experience, this is a wonderful ode to the Bard. (Michael Joseph, £25)

From the author of The Big Short – which spawned a hit film of the same name – comes a thrillingly good account of the rise and fall of Sam Bankman-Fried – also known as The King of Crypto. (Allen Lane, £25)

Safiya Sinclair was raised by a tyrannical father with strict Rastafari ideals. How to Say Babylon is the breathtaking and candid story of how she escaped his oppression, and one which will alter everything the majority of us thought we knew about Rastafarianism. (Fourth Estate, £16.99)

Who needs the hallowed halls of Westminster when you’ve got car parks and seaside resorts? Subtitled “50 Places that Changed British Politics”, herein lie the lesser known spots that key political events have occurred. A juicy, fascinating read, illustrated by cartoonist Morten Mortland. (William Collins, £25)

Recalling his life through a soundtrack of around 30 songs – beginning with Elvis Presley’s “Heartbreak Hotel”, which he heard as a teenager and made him want to be a singer – the star’s memoir is a lovely celebration of music. (Ebury Spotlight, £25)

In Sophie Kinsella’s latest romantic comedy, her protagonist Sasha has hit a brick wall in life. Fed up of having her energy drained by work, she takes herself to a Devon retreat in search of peace and quiet. If only she didn’t have to share a beach with Finn, the grumpy, equally burned-out man with a penchant for .

That you can guess what might happen next does not detract from the enjoyment of The Burnout: rather, you are willing it to happen. And this is precisely the pleasure of reading a novel by the reigning queen of British romcoms, and precisely why she has become a multimillion-selling author with more than 30 books to her name.

Over the past two decades, her set-ups have ranged from coffee shops (I Owe You One) to semi-silent writing retreats (Love Your Life), while she has delved into a fun and frivolous world with the Shopaholic series. So, why turn to the more serious themes of stress and burnout in her latest book?

“I have experienced burnout myself and I have seen it discussed a lot in the media, so I thought a lot of readers might relate,” she explains. “However, I also always finds the funny side of life, so, while respecting the fact that burnout is a big issue, I wrote this book as a comedy.
“For me, the best comedy is rooted in truth – sometimes even painful truth – and laughter is a welcome release,” she continues.
In fact, this is what draws her to the romcom genre as a whole. “I love making myself laugh out loud as I write,” she muses.

But it isn’t all straightforward. “The hardest aspect of romcoms for me is finding obstacles and misunderstandings to throw in the couple’s way,” she says. “This is especially difficult, given that we all have phones and communicate constantly with each other. When I started writing, there were no mobile phones, so it was easier to have messages gone astray.”

She can’t quite believe she has written so many books. Where do all her ideas come from? “I just walk about the world with my eyes open for stories and ‘what ifs’,” she says. “I may run out of ideas one day, but I haven’t yet – so fingers crossed.”
The Burnout by Sophie Kinsella (Bantam, £22) is published 12 October

title: Frasier, Seinfeld, Friends: Leave 90s sitcoms in the 90s
lead: A wave of nostalgia-fuelled reboots is hitting our screens – but we look to these shows for comfort, not something new
author: Emily Bootle

body.text: Could there be any more 90s sitcom reboots?! On Friday a , which from 1993 to 2004 followed a divorced psychiatrist living in Seattle, will begin on Paramount+, and this weekend Jerry Seinfeld hinted at a live show that a revival could be in the works, saying “something is going to happen”, despite having previously vowed it would never happen (and despite the 2009 series of Curb Your Enthusiasm, written by the Seinfeld co-creator Larry David, centring on a fictional Seinfeld reunion).

Early reviews of Frasier 2.0 have been mixed – yet it follows in the footsteps of many more gently pattering, living-room based shows that have been dusted off and repurposed for modern screens, from Sex and the City’s get-with-the-programme And Just Like That to the sentimental in 2021.
So for all their anachronisms – canned laughter, overwhelmingly white casts and heteronormativity – 90s sitcoms continue to reign supreme. Why can’t we get enough?

The Variety review of the Frasier reboot notes that “if fans are looking for something new, they won’t find it here”. Of course, this is a huge part of the appeal. The 90s and early 2000s was a golden era for the American sitcom – arguably ushered in by the success of Seinfeld – and the biggest shows ran for years on end (Friends for 10; Seinfeld for nine; Frasier for 11).

The cast of characters were not just vaguely on the radar – they were everyday features of fans’ lives. The endless patter of these shows cushioned our own life events, provided support, were always watched in context. That they tended to be low stakes – Seinfeld was famously the show in which “nothing happens” – made them all the more compatible and comforting. Many viewers will take any opportunity to revive some of that magic through a reboot.

Because of this captive audience, reviving the classics can be an easy win. TV is an increasingly competitive field, with endless new platforms and shows all jostling for viewers’ attention. The diehard fandoms of shows that did the heavy lifting of finding an audience 20 years ago are a productive demographic for producers to appeal to. In 2004, 10 million people watched the  finale; 36 million watched the last episode of Frasier and more than 50 million watched the final episode of Friends. Six years previously, 76 million had tuned into the last episode of Seinfeld. Carrying even a fraction of those viewers into 2023 would be a decent start.

In the 2000s, after the end of Frasier, Seinfeld et al, TV comedy continued to grow – but the era of New-York-apartment, living-room comedy was over. Both in the US and the UK, political comedy, mockumentary and workplace sitcoms reigned, with shows like , Parks and Recreation, Scrubs, The Thick of It and  taking over. Some were grittier, with more serious source material, and some just had a different cadence to the jokes, focusing on the workplace or deep character examination rather than frivolity. And rather than honing in on one homogenous-looking group of friends, they included a wider variety of characters and character types.

Because as well as being beautifully inane, the cultural landscape of the 90s was overwhelmingly white, affluent and heterosexual, and popular television at the time – notably Friends and Sex and the City – adhered rigidly to those norms. Sex and the City in particular, perhaps because of its reputation for championing the sexual liberation of women, has since been scrutinised for the casual homophobia and racism that occasionally rears its head in throwaway lines.
And so at a time when awareness of diversity and inclusion has never been more important, another reason to revive these shows is a desire to set the record straight.

And Just Like That, is more than aware of the original’s propensity to cause offence and has made an on-the-nose effort to right its wrongs, with trans characters, black characters and – shock horror – an acknowledgement of the relevance of podcasts.

When Frasier announced it was rebooting in 2021, Colin Jost described it on Saturday Night Live as “the show that made Friends look black”. The new cast, predictably, has been reported to be more diverse.

Seinfeld, too, might be hopeful to correct the record, but for another reason. Its finale was widely panned for trying to do too much after years of joyful nothingness. Seinfeld himself told Esquire in 2017 that sometimes he thinks they “shouldn’t have even done” it: “There was a lot of pressure on us at that time to do one big last show, but big is always bad in comedy.” Which begs the question of whether the comparable pressure to do a reunion will come off, or whether it’s better just to let it be.

Jeff Schaffer, Seinfeld’s executive producer in its final season, said in a recent interview of the controversial ending that “finales are hard… it’s sort of a betrayal to the audience. You’re breaking up with them. They’re going, ‘You’re leaving me. Why are you leaving me? All I’ve done is love you.’”

Yet we all know that given a bit of time after a break-up, it’s a different story. We don’t want to know that “you’ve changed” – just as we don’t want a shiny new Frasier trying to insert contemporary references to prove its relevance. The joy of these old shows is in their familiarity and comfort – when we want to be surprised or energised, we can look to countless modern comedies, from Feel Good to Schitt’s Creek.
Getting back with an ex is not for the fainthearted, so enter the 90s reboot with caution: they walk a fine line between invigorating nostalgia and spoiling the original.

title: Who left Bake Off 2023 last night? What happened in week 3, who won star baker and GBBO results in full
lead: The bakers started with a classic cottage loaf in the signature, and then headed to Devon for the technical, before getting themselves in a twist with a plaited bread centrepiece
author: Alex Finnis

body.text: of  was bread week – perhaps the most intimidating of any task with bread master himself Paul Hollywood lurking in the tent.
The bakers started with a classic cottage loaf in the signature, and then headed to Devon for the technical, before getting themselves in a twist with a plaited bread centrepiece.
At the end of the third episode Alison announced that Tasha was the Star Baker – for the second week running – but one contestant’s dreams came crumbling down.
Abbi became the third baker to leave the tent. The 27-year-old veg grower and delivery driver from Cumbia said she “knew it was coming” after a difficult week.

She said after her exit: “I’m going to take away a real sense of achievement of being in the series and also of defining myself as a baker – I feel I have a proper baking style now, and have discovered what I love to do the most and what I am best at. I’m also going to take away a massive amount of love and family from all the rest of the bakers and the crew. It would not have been the same experience without a single one of them.
“I was already pretty sure I was going to be leaving, so I wasn’t that surprised. I was sad obviously but also quite relieved not to have to do chocolate week!

“I knew that the thing I was going to miss the most was all the fun times with my fellow bakers. They did a brilliant job cheering me up by complimenting my nettle bread and reminding me that I’m an amazing baker – and then with drinks later at the hotel!”
From: East LondonOccupation: Mum and PA

Life with four children means that, for Cristy, there always seems to be a birthday to bake for and an exciting party to plan. She describes her baking style as enchanted and pretty – bakes that conjure up a sense of childhood. Cakes are her speciality, and she draws flavour inspiration from her own Israeli heritage and from her husband’s Jamaican roots. She is a dab hand with decoration and gets a thrill out of making sure the results look perfect.
When she’s not organising a celebration, you can find her having an outdoor adventure, letting her hair down with her friends, or solving a Rubik’s cube – in under four minutes!
From: CheshireOccupation: Civil engineering resource planner

Dan’s interest in cooking began when he went travelling in South America in 2007. His particular loves are pies and puddings: before he and his wife bought their first home, they lived with his in-laws, during which time his mother-in-law taught him how to make perfect shortcrust pastry. Subsequently, his passion for pies has evolved into a penchant for patisserie!

Perfectionist Dan loves a baking challenge and will often find the hardest bake in one of his many (more than 300!) cook books and start there, throwing everything he’s got at creating a masterpiece. When he’s not baking, he loves to play football with his two young sons, work out in the gym, or forage for edible treats in the countryside around his home.
From: EssexOccupation: Database administrator

Dana’s passion for baking started at the age of 16 when she identified a gap in her family’s traditionally Indian culinary repertoire. As a self-professed untidy baker, Dana would avoid stepping on her mum’s toes in the kitchen by catching the bus to her dad’s house to indulge her need to experiment with her bakes.

Now she has a kitchen of her own (and a cockapoo, Gracie, to clean up after her), Dana has become the family’s go-to celebration cake-maker. Her style is rustic and homely, but always pleasing to the eye. She loves a semi-naked cake with neat lines, pretty piping and minimalist decoration; and although she likes to keep her flavours safe, Dana will often incorporate a twist or two, adding in familiar spices associated with her Indian heritage.
From: LeicestershireOccupation: Post-doctoral research associate

Josh is a chemist by trade and brings his scientist’s precision and keenness to experiment into the kitchen, taking careful notes on each part of the baking process and perfecting all his techniques for gorgeous results. He likes to take his inspiration from old baking books, reinventing classics to give them a modern twist, often by introducing alternative flavours and including the seasonal fruit and vegetables from his kitchen garden.

Josh has been playing rugby for his local team for more than 15 years, and once a month he bakes lots of treats to reward his teammates after a rigorous training session. He dreams of having his own artisan bakery one day.
From: CambridgeshireOccupation: PE and science teacher

Matty is the type of baker who swats up on online patisserie videos before bed. No matter how good he gets, though, he strives to equal the impressiveness of the bake that first caught his imagination: a teddy-bear cake that his late grandmother made for his fourth birthday.

Now the family’s designated baker, he always has a list of cake requests for upcoming celebrations. He describes his style as rustic but neat, and his flavour preferences as quite traditional – he particularly loves chocolate, citrus and nuts. Once his days in the tent are over, his next – and even bigger – challenge will be to make his own wedding cake, a special commission from his fiancée, Lara.
From: West MidlandsOccupation: Retired cabin crew and volunteer

Nicky describes her baking as “like a pair of comfy old slippers; little traditional bakes that evoke fond memories”. For Nicky herself, those memories are of her gran’s kitchen table where, as a little girl, she would roll out pastries and decorate cakes – which she says was as much fun then as all her baking is to her now. Her favourite bakes are still pastries, but she also loves making breads, and fun birthday cakes for her niece and grandchildren.
When she’s not baking, Nicky volunteers for a pet-therapy charity (along with her dog, Bracken) and loves to ski, which she has been doing since she was only three years old.
From: West YorkshireOccupation: Student

“Go big, or go home” is Rowan’s motto, and one that he has always applied to his bakes. His earliest baking memories are of scones, pork pies, shortbread and traditional jam tarts (which he claims as a northern delicacy). A student of English literature, when he’s not writing up a storm, Rowan is also a keen host, applying his creative eye to his cooking – he aims for clean lines and interesting decoration in his finished bakes.

Just like his much-admired, knock-out cocktail-making skills, Rowan expresses his grand, opulent side in his bakes, wowing his uni friends with his creations. He made his own 21st birthday cake – a three-tier, 12-layer extravaganza.
From: HerefordshireOccupation: Intelligence analyst

Sri Lankan-born Saku places the traditional flavours of her heritage at the heart of her baking – particularly the curry spices, which she claims make for the best pie fillings, while liberal sprinklings of cinnamon, cardamom and nutmeg find their way into her sweeter bakes.

At her family home in Sri Lanka, Saku didn’t have an oven until she was 18, so she turned to baking only when she moved with her husband to the UK in 2003, and particularly when she became a mum – rustling up treats for her children’s lunchboxes by replicating the snacks she saw in the supermarket. Self-taught, she is now a dab hand with a whisk and relishes using her homegrown ingredients from her pride and joy – her vegetable patch.
From: BristolOccupation: Participation officer

The best thing Tasha remembers about baking as a child was licking the sugar icing from the tops of the fairy cakes she, her mum and her grandma used to make. At secondary school, she made cakes for her friends and was soon encouraged by her food technology teacher to develop her skills as a hobby.

Much like her attitude to life, Tasha’s baking is fearless. She uses it as a way to express herself creatively, often embarking upon near-impossible designs – with impressive results! When she’s not baking, Tasha loves going to the theatre to see a West End show and has a passion for travelling the world.

title: Ed Byrne: ‘Covid killed my brother. If you think it’s a hoax, f**k off’
lead: The Mock the Week comedian on turning tragedy into comedy in his new show, Tragedy Plus Time
author: Rachael Healy

body.text: Until this year,  had always felt most comfortable doing stand-up. He’s hosted his own show on Irish TV, been a regular on , and made an adventure show with Dara Ó Briain, but alone on stage was where he felt safest. But when he had to perform his new show, Tragedy Plus Time, at the Edinburgh Fringe every night, things were different.

“The first couple of nights, I was heading into the theatre like a condemned man. I remember thinking: ‘I’m not sure I can do this every night,’” he says. “Because the show is about my little brother dying.”

Last year, Byrne’s brother Paul died from liver failure at the age of 44. As the elder Byrne visited his sibling in hospital, the pair naturally found humour amid the darkness. Turning Paul’s final months into a stand-up show felt right, says Byrne: “It’s what he would’ve wanted. It’s exactly what he would’ve wanted. There’s no two ways about it.”

Paul worked in comedy too, as a director, writer and producer. He developed work with Andrew Maxwell, Roisin Conaty, Glenn Wool, Sarah Keyworth, Sindhu Vee and many others. At his funeral, as per his wishes, he was cremated to the sound of “Disco Inferno” – the lyrics “Burn, baby, burn”, as his brother points out on stage, offering a pleasing pun on his status as younger sibling. “Death is an inevitability and what else are you going to do but laugh at it and stick two fingers up to it,” Byrne says.

This is the first time Byrne has fully embraced such difficult and emotional subject matter in his comedy, which has spanned everyday gripes and drawn inspiration from his personal life, from marriage to children.

“It isn’t what people necessarily expect when they come and see me, but needs must,” he shrugs. “I’ve never done a show that’s had serious bits in it. I’ve never done a show where people have said afterwards that they cried and then they laughed. That usual feeling of knowing exactly what I’m doing wasn’t as prevalent. It was slightly uncharted waters for me.”

Tragedy Plus Time started out as an exploration of how dark humour can help us through tough times. “In our family, we’ve always dealt with things through jokes,” Byrne says. “Some of them are quite shocking. Literally after Paul died, we got in the car to go home from the hospital and I turned to my older brother and said: ‘It should’ve been you.’ And we laughed!”

When he began writing the show, Byrne didn’t know how heavily Paul would feature, but it quickly became all about him. As he reveals on stage, for 12 of the final 16 months of his brother’s life, the pair were not speaking. A silly argument had blown out of proportion, and it was only Paul’s worsening health that led the two to reconcile. “The show is more about the importance of not letting arguments fester with loved-ones because you never know when they’re going to pop their clogs.”

Creating comedy out of tragedy can be cathartic. But the reality is revisiting that experience every time you perform it. Byrne’s brother was a firm fixture at the , helping shape many successful stand-up shows, so performing the show there was tough at first.

“It felt weird, him not being there,” Byrne says. “There are two or three bits in the show where I have to just hold it together. Depending on the night and depending on how emotionally fragile I am, sometimes you can just perform it like an automaton, but most of the time those moments just catch me.” It did get easier as the festival wore on, especially as Byrne received warm feedback from friends of Paul.

Byrne deftly examines the complex circumstances around his brother’s death. The “user error” that caused his initial liver failure 15 years ago, leading him to quit drinking. The Hodgkin’s lymphoma that reared its head a decade ago, necessitating chemotherapy that further assaulted his liver. Then the pandemic, which prompted a series of events that sealed Paul’s fate in a way that caused anger and despair for his loved-ones.

led to a breakdown in Paul’s relationship, plus a sudden halt to his beloved comedy industry. Isolated at home, after years of abstinence, he turned back to drink. When his liver issues re-emerged, he struggled to get a doctor’s appointment as the NHS buckled under the strain of Covid.

By the time he secured an appointment with liver specialists, his flatmate came home with Covid and infected him. The impact of the virus and that missed appointment caused irreparable damage. “The pandemic is literally what killed him,” Byrne says.

Byrne makes a series of precise jokes about the Government’s poor handling of the pandemic, and the conspiracy theories that proliferated as the pandemic progressed, ensnaring many people’s family and friends.

“One of the nights in Edinburgh, as soon as I started talking about conspiracy theories and particularly Covid denial, two guys walked out,” Byrne says. “The fact that Paul’s death was exacerbated by lockdown, then the final nail in the coffin was Covid itself, I’m just not very well predisposed to people who say Covid is a hoax.”

In the past, Byrne might’ve shied away from controversial jokes that could alienate segments of the audience. “I would’ve been a bit more diplomatic, trying to please all factions and make all people laugh. Whereas I just don’t give a f**k any more. If you don’t like being called an idiot for suggesting that Covid doesn’t exist, then you can f**k off.”

The show prompts us to consider the importance of accepting when we’re wrong. Byrne has little time for the conspiracy mindset that closes people off to other sources of information. He’s also taken time to reassess his own stubbornness.

“The massive argument Paul and I had, at the time I was like: ‘That was entirely, 100 per cent his fault.’ I’ve had to re-examine what I did wrong. In finding the humour in the situation, I realised his point of view. Too late to talk to him about it. But at least enough to have learnt the lesson.”

Byrne is clear that, despite the tragedy at the heart of it, this is a comedy show. “I’ve been careful not to make it one of these shows where towards the end I stop doing jokes and just talk about how miserable I am,” he says.

He spoke to comedians his brother had worked with, sussing out Paul’s directing style. “His thing was: you can be as serious, as heartfelt, as emotional as you like, but there has to be a joke. I adhered to that. I was determined it was going to be a funny show and it is a funny show.”

In life, Byrne never worked with his brother. In a way, this is their first collaboration. “It’s weird when people die, because you keep going to phone them. You keep forgetting you can’t. I had that a lot when I was trying to do this show,” Byrne says. “I’m not going to say he’s directing me from beyond the grave, but it does feel as close to a collaboration as I’m ever going to get. I’ll take that.”

Tragedy Plus Time is on track to be Byrne’s most acclaimed show, but there isn’t the usual banter and photos after a performance. Instead, “a lot of people want to tell you about their losses,” Byrne says. “All the reviews were amazing, but the best review was from a guy who was there with his wife and had a fractious relationship with his brother, who died of Covid. This guy just said: ‘I now feel that my wife understands me and what I’ve been through.’ And I went, ‘OK, my work here is done.’”

In Edinburgh, Byrne was restricted to an hour-long show. On tour, audiences will hear an extended version of the story. “I’m looking forward to letting it breathe,” he says. He wants people to know how deeply funny his brother was, how much he cared about comedy and the people he worked with.
“You’re getting to tell people about a guy that you loved. By the end, there’s 600 people who didn’t know who Paul was, who now know who Paul was.”

title: Nicole Eisenman: What Happened, Whitechapel Gallery, London, review: Queer, sexy, violent – and funny
lead: Her work is carnal, polemical and deliberately shocking, but this supremely skillful and thoughtful artist never takes herself too seriously
author: Hettie Judah

body.text: Nicole Eisenman offers a world of distinctly adult pleasures. Emerging onto the New York scene in her twenties, the painter tested the limits. How much was too much? A group of adult women in a Trevi Fountain-like arrangement of twisting, urinating bodies who pass their pee out to be sold on a kid’s lemonade stand? A separatist community of arctic lesbians using a man as fishing bait? A birthing scene involving a hanged woman?

As a chronological retrospective, Nicole Eisenman: What Happened opens with this in-your-face 90s work, and it’s… a lot. Queer, sexy, violent, funny, mannered and deliberately shocking. A crammed display of small drawings and sketches on the opening wall includes a filthy painting on an Alice-in-Wonderland theme involving Alice and Wonder Woman.

Eisenman is a fabulously deft painter and flits elegantly between styles and references, from the grim realism of  to the grand narrative works of Pieter Bruegel, to strip cartoons. She’s also pretty funny. In the doldrums after early acclaim, she painted From Success to Obscurity (2004) in which Marvel monster The Thing is pictured reading a letter. “Dear Obscurity…” it opens.

In the mid 2000s Eisenman commenced a series of “history paintings” engaging with social and political phenomena of her time. Painted during the subprime mortgage crisis, in The Triumph of Poverty (2009) a procession of grotesque and harried figures cluster around a doorless and stationary car while a clapboard house in the background belches smoke. Eisenman portrays the Brooklyn art world gathered in beer gardens or for political protests: crowd scenes populated by the artist, her friends and community.

One upper gallery is given to the interaction between bodies and screens. In Weeks on a Train (2015) the poet Laurie Weeks is pictured slumped in her seat beside a cat carrier, attention entirely absorbed by her MacBook. Breakup (2011) offers a face fragmenting into crude planes of paint as it stares obsessively at a phone.

The artist reserves her darkest humour for political critique. Tea Party (2011) plunges us into a basement bunker amid  assembling a cartoonish bomb. In the foreground, Uncle Sam hunches shabby and exhausted in an armchair, trailing the teabag from his American Eagle mug on the floor.

The show closes with the clumpy, sprawling sculpture Makers Muck (2022), in which Eisenman presents herself as a half-formed hapless figure attempting to shape a lump of clay. God forbid this supremely skillful and thoughtful artist take herself too seriously.
, Whitechapel Gallery, London, 11 October 2023 – 14 January 2024

title: Why Holly Willoughby’s exit from This Morning signals the ends of a TV era
lead: Willoughby had little choice but to move on after the show became mired in a series of scandals
author: Michael Hogan

body.text: Farewell then,.

The beleaguered presenter stepping down from the daytime stalwart had become something of a grim inevitability. It surprised precisely nobody when Willoughby announced via Instagram at Tuesday teatime that she was quitting after 14 years “for me and my family”. Frankly, who can blame her?

Willoughby has been absent from the famous sofa since last Wednesday, when an . Under police protection at home, it’s small wonder she’s chosen to prioritise her loved ones’ safety over light banter and lifestyle featurettes.
The news comes five months after This Morning became mired in scandal when Willoughby’s former co-hostir with a younger male colleague.

Willoughby had already been “hurt” by her supposed best friend Schofield not telling her that his brother Timothy was facing sexual abuse charges. Now she was “shaken, troubled and let down” by his deceit while still married.

After being dealt such a string of blows, Willoughby had little choice but to move on. Back in May, she expressed sadness at Schofield “stepping down from a career he loved”. Now she has done likewise. It’s a bleak way for the former dream team to be dissolved. What was once so wholesome is now indelibly tainted.

Will it also spell doom for This Morning? Quite possibly. ITV has been at pains to point out that despite its recent travails, no decision has been made about the programme’s future. This Morning remains the commercial channel’s biggest daytime brand, ahead of noisy relative newcomer Loose Women and dear old . Scheduled back-to-back across nearly five hours, this triptych of shows form the spine of ITV’s pre-primetime offering, bridging the gap between breakfast news and afternoon gameshows.

There’s an argument to say that This Morning could simply replace its presenters – and perhaps its production team – and undergo one of its own trademark makeovers. Fresh faces, fresh content, a whole new era. Over the course of its 35 years on air, after all, it has already undergone more reinventions than Madonna.

It was once. When they defected to Channel 4, John Leslie and Fern Britton took over. Schofield replaced Leslie. Seven years later, Willoughby replaced Britton. It’s been like a broadcasting version of musical chairs. Phil and Holly seems to have been around forever but actually their reign represents just 40 per cent of This Morning’s total lifespan. Less, in fact, when you consider that they only worked four days per week and took long summer breaks. So another round of musical chairs is certainly one option. Now might be the time, however, to gently put the programme out to pasture.

Many mainstream media fixtures – from the News Of The World to the X Factor, from Ken Bruce on Radio 2 to Holby City on BBC1 – eventually have their day. At first you can’t quite imagine the pop cultural landscape without them. Then suddenly they’re gone and within months, everyone has moved on. The X what? Holby who? Hey, that’s showbiz.

Daytime TV is traditionally cosy, cuddly and reassuringly safe. This Morning has become anything but that, suffering a social media backlash and a. From queue-jumping at the Queen’s lying-in-state to age-gap affairs with runners, from allegations of a toxic workplace culture to criminal conspiracies – it’s a sad and undignified way for this TV era to draw to to a close. This Morning has gone from a comforting cuppa to a poisoned chalice. No wonder Willoughby has decided to stop serving it up.

title: The Rolling Stones, Hackney Diamonds, review: the rock veterans have never sounded more vital
lead: The album is a reassertion of their louche genius – and a reminder that the 2023 vintage Stones are more than a monolithic touring machine
author: Ed Power

body.text: When the  snarled into life in the early 60s, they were scrawny kids barely out of school who had modelled themselves on the ancient bluesmen of the American South.

Half a century later, the Stones have travelled full circle. With their excellent new album, Hackney Diamonds, (80),  (79), and Ron Wood (76) are now the antediluvian musicians. But they’ve never sounded more full of vitality. Age has not withered them – in fact, it seems to have barely intruded on their thoughts.

Hackney Diamonds is a lot of things. It is a reminder that the 2023 vintage Stones aren’t simply a monolithic touring machine cranking out moss-worn hits. The project is a reassertion of the louche genius that crackled through classic LPs such as Exile on Main Street and Let It Bleed – proof that nothing in rock’n’roll sparks like Jagger and Richards going at it full pelt.

Above all, however, it’s a delightful repudiation of the idea that musicians in their twilight years are obliged to reflect on their mortality. Hackney Diamonds is the opposite of that: it’s hard to think of an album further removed from the melancholy of Leonard Cohen’s You Want It Darker or  (recorded when he was 69, a full 11 years younger than Jagger).

The passage of time is referenced once or twice. “These streets I used to walk on/ Are full of broken glass,” observes Jagger on “Whole Wide World”. But unlike many of his peers, he doesn’t pine for the good old days. Being young, poor and obscure was a grind. What came next was much better – “You think the party’s over/ It’s only just begun.”

People have been writing the Stones off as decrepit fossils since the 90s – when they were only just out of their forties. So perhaps it is no surprise they seem indifferent to the wear and tear of the decades.

This point is made thrillingly with the opening number and  – a blistering Richards barrage that lands its punches with aplomb. The track sets the tone for the rest of Hackney Diamonds, recorded in LA, New York, London and the Bahamas – well, this is the Rolling Stones – and produced by Andrew Wyatt.
Wyatt comes to it fresh from 76-year-old . He works a similar magic with The Stones, refining the clichéd elements of their writing into a sound both familiar and full of zing.

There are lots of surprises. “Come on Paul, let’s hear something,” declares Jagger on “Bite My Head Off”. “Paul” would be Paul McCartney, who happened to be working in an adjoining studio and was  to a tune that bristles with attitude.

There is also a cameo of sorts by Charlie Watts, the Stones drummer who , by which time he had played on two of Hackney Diamonds’ 12 songs. His place is elsewhere filled by Steve Jordan, who lacks Watts’s jazzy nuance but brings plenty of the oomph this band demands.

Hackney Diamonds concludes with a glittering one-two.  provides dazzling backing vocals on the gospel-fuelled “Sweet Sounds of Heaven”: a seven-minute belter so quintessentially Rolling Stones you can almost see that giant lips logo materialise as it unfurls.

And then there’s the comedown: a raw, rootsy cover of Muddy Waters’ “Rolling Stone Blues” where Richards bashes an acoustic guitar and Jagger takes on the role of the haggard bluesman. It’s the only moment when he acts his age on a record that functions as an irresistible valentine to growing old with a wink and a roar.
Stream: Bite My Head Off, Sweet Sounds of Heaven
